Financial stock ETFs jabbed higher Tuesday as the big money-center banks gear for earnings kickoff this week.JPMorgan Chase (JPM), the largest U.S. bank, reports Wednesday. A slew of peers follow: Bank of America (BAC) and Wells Fargo (WFC) on Thursday, Citigroup (C) on Friday, and Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS) on Monday and Tuesday, respectively, next week.Some market analysts caution that a tough first quarter is likely to weigh on their reports. They point out that the Federal Reserve's wariness on raising interest rates, coupled with global growth concerns, continue to weigh on the financial sector.Energy loans are particularly in focus as banks report, following JP Morgan's recent decision to raise energy-loan loss reserves.Despite oil's rebound from 2016 lows, cash-flow woes persist for many shale companies that bet big when crude was trading at $100 a barrel.Not all analysts share the concerns about the banking sector's health. Some say that U.S. bank stocks are the healthiest they have been in decades.Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) gained 1.3% on the stock market today. XLF invests in banks, insurance companies, capital markets companies, diversified financial companies, consumer banks, mortgage finance, REITs and real estate management companies.Financial Services Select Sector SPDR (XLFS) reversed from a 1.5% loss intraday to a 1.1% gain at the close. XLFS invests in the same S&P 500 financial companies as XLF, but shuts out the REITs and real estate management companies.XLF and XLFS are down 5% and 8%, respectively, this year -- putting them at the bottom of the heap of 11 Select SPDR ETFs tracking S&P 500 sectors.One market technician says the chart picture for banks remains poor."Banks remain troubled and should be avoided based on our work," said Ari Wald, executive director and senior technical analyst at Oppenheimer & Co. "We see it as concerning that the KBW Bank index is showing signs of turning lower below its multiyear breakdown point."Wald said the trend should be considered bearish while the index is below this important resistance. In addition, he noted that while (bank stock prices) have bounced from the February low, the industry’s relative strength has continued to trend lower -- a sign that banks continue to underperform.SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) offers targeted exposure to the banking industry.According to Wald, banks tend to perform well when interest rates rise, and vice versa, making it hard to recommend them in the current economic scenario."We expect long-dated interest rates to remain anchored by global growth concerns," he said. "Specifically, it’s difficult to make the case for U.S. rates to move significantly higher due to their relatively wide spread vs. ultralow interest rates in Germany and Japan."As such, he recommended reducing positions in financial ETFs following the sector's bounce from its February low. At the industry level, he suggested buying the property and casualty insurance industry on weakness and selling life insurance on strength.Major stock indexes reversed sharply higher Tuesday as oil prices rose.West Texas Intermediate oil surged 4%, settling at $42.17 a barrel, its highest level in 2016. The gains came as major oil producers Russia and Saudi Arabia reportedly reached an agreement to cut output.Energy led the S&P 500 sectors Tuesday. Real estate trailed.Here's a look at how the major exchange traded funds tracking various asset classes performed today.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +0.9%, RS 63PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +0.8%, RS 63SPDR Dow Jones industrial average (DIA), +0.9%, RS 66IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +1.1%, RS 63IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +1.1%, RS 44IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +1.5%, RS 38Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +1.5%, RS 55SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), 0%, RS 83IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), -0.2%, RS 59PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), 0%, RS 41IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -3.4%, RS 20

Men may have long dominated the financial advisory field. But increasingly, signs show women are finally getting their shot.Amid a growing awareness of the “female market” for financial advice -- some data show women now controlling 51% of America’s personal wealth -- and the aftermath of some bias lawsuits, evidently more financial advisory firms are inviting women to be advisors as well as clients.“It’s a big deal,” said Michelle Lynch, vice president of Raymond James Financial’s (RJF) Network for Women Advisors. She added, “All the firms have some initiative now around women.”To be sure, female advisors are still comparatively few. Although women comprise more than half the population, they account for only 31% of financial advisors and 23% of certified financial planners (CFPs), according to a 2014 CFP Board report. And experts say that many women still aren’t even aware of the profession.But these days, programs in colleges, professional groups and company recruitment aim to boost the ranks of women advisors. Indeed, at Prudential Advisors, “our goal is to reflect the marketplace,” said Catalina Camoscio, the firm’s vice president of recruiting and development. Reflecting the marketplace would eventually mean “50% of (our) advisors” would be women.At big advisory firms, strategies to attract women -- often part of a firm’s broader “diversity” initiatives -- can include mentoring programs, college recruitment, hiring women returning to work after an extended leave, and the use of team advising.An example of the latter: A year and a half ago, Merrill Lynch Wealth Management (MLWM) expanded its training and development lineup with a Team Financial Advisor (TFA) offering. Participants take on one of five specific roles within an existing advisory team and receive 31 months of training.TFA recruits might include those starting a second career or new college graduates. Among TFA's attractions for women: It allows them “to work collaboratively with other advisors while contributing their expertise to the group,” said Linda Houston, division executive for New England at MLWM.Apprenticeships appear to be among the draws at Morgan Stanley Wealth Management (MSWM). For a year, apprentices work with a team of wealth advisors to broaden their skills before starting their own advisory practice within Morgan Stanley (MS). Results so far: about half the apprenticeship program’s hires have been women, reports Kara Underwood, MSWM’s head of diversity. (Morgan Stanley did not provide specific numbers of hires.)This year, Prudential (PRU) hopes to launch its team approach to financial advising and include recruitment as part of it. While this initiative could involve anyone, “we expect it to attract women because of the mentorship and collaboration it offers,” Prudential's Camoscio said.So how can women learn of, and tap, such opportunities? Experts cite key steps to consider:

It is POST TIME! That time defined as the 'specific time' when the race begins.....when all participants need to be locked and loaded in the narrow gates awaiting the starters call......Yes folks - its RACE day or rather RACE month....when the CEO's & CFO's must confess the financial condition of publicly traded companies....and on each race day - the grooms - in this case the IR guy/gal leads the 'horse' to the 'saddling paddock'. The identifier checks the horse's identity (listed company) to make sure that the results correspond with the proper 'horse'. Then the horse is saddled up and the jockeys (usually the CFO) are given instructions on how to proceed. The jockey adorned in the 'silks' of the horse's owner ( in this case the CEO) are given instructions on how to proceed and together the jockey and the owner take their places....And they are OFF!Last night - post close - we got the first taste of what is expected to be a tough race.....Alcoa (AA) comes out of the gate stumbling....1Q earnings of .07 cts/sh were down 92%, Yes - earnings BEAT the estimate but top line revenues missed big time......coming in at $4.95 bil vs. the expectation of $5.20 bil....... Klaus Kleinfeld (CEO) discussed weak aluminum prices (down 40% over the last 5 yrs) and the state of the global economy.....2000 jobs are on the line because of weak mkts around the world......The stock fell 4% in after hours trading and is currently trading at $9.34 down 0.40 cts off of last night's close....'and so it was written' the season has begun.....'Stocks popped at the open but the rally was short-lived....stocks failed to sustain the early upside spike and stocks turned lower...sellers dominating the day and selling into the rally. The pullback attributed to the beginning of what is predicted to be a disappointing earnings season.What also added to the sour mood was the double secret meeting between Yellen and the Fed governors. Following this surprise expedited meeting, Janet Yellen met with President Obama to discuss the state of the economy. Now just an FYI - this was the first time since November 2014 that the sitting Fed chair has met one on one with the president....and the media was not invited...so what did they discuss? Rate hike - nah, GDP - maybe, the real unemployment rate? Doubtful - as Obama thinks it's all a bed of roses.....How about the state of the banking industry and how the global contraction has affected the industry....How about the quality of assets, how about margin compression and growth prospects in this less than stellar environment....... especially after two central banks - the ECB and the BoJ initiated negative interest rates. Oh boy.....so much to say....Now as discussed - we are expecting earnings to be down y/y - and as of the end of March - that number has been 'adjusted' to -8.5%....(slight improvement...) Energy, financials and industrials to take the brunt of the blame...... this will be the 4th straight qtr of EPS (Earnings per share) declines....but do not be concerned.....because as usual - expect to see 70% of those earnings 'beat the estimates' - but like Alcoa - will they beat due to cost cutting or will they actually GROW top line revenues? The jury is still out - but my money says - the majority of the 'beats' will come from 'expense management' vs organic growth.....Today we get a bit of a reprieve before the financials line up in the starting gate.....Wednesday - look for JPMorgan Chase (JPM) followed by the usual suspects - Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC), Goldman Sachs (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS) and Bank Of America (BAC)..... Will weak earnings be discounted? Are we really expecting that 'hockey stick' recovery in the second half of 2016? And if so then this is a gift for the longer term investor...because if this as bad as it gets - then future action can only be UP......unless of course the mkt does not believe it and the guidance is less than stellar.....Now the VIX - is giving us a whole different storyline.....this index (otherwise known as the FEAR Index) - has fallen to a 7 month low.... What its telling us is that the mkts are not concerned about almost anything at the moment and some of the industry's recent surveys confirm this lack of concern.......The American Association of Individual Investors (AAII) reveals that pessimism is at a 5 month low of 32.2% - well below the historical average of 39%. Bank of America's "Bull & Bear" index recently surged to 4.1, up dramatically from the March low of 0.1......,suggesting the most bullish reading in 9 months. So when everyone is so bullish - what's left??? But buyer beware....this can change in a heartbeat - as any number of things could cause a change in psychology....or sentiment.Yes - it's all nice when everyone plays nice on the jungle gym....but as soon as we get something unexpected then we could see a rather swift and painful sell off...Remember - as I have pointed out - the next two months is traditionally weak and with the US in the middle of a nasty presidential election cycle - so much can happen that will change the direction of the conversation.Risk remains high.....FED policy is uncertain and if the FED is forced to raise rates too quickly - then prepare for the massacre, Europe's economy is on the edge, China is slowing, a Yuan devaluation is NOT out of the question, negative interest rates causing concern around the globe, and continued currency wars and the geopolitical risks of terrorism, war and immigration could easily ignite mkt volatility and are only a few of the risks that exist.US futures are higher by 5pts this morning - no matter what the Alcoa earnings say.....The mkt remains stuck in the 2040/2070 range but feels a bit heavier each day.....a decisive break below 2040 will take us back to support at 2014. Remember - the underlying tone of the mkt is suspect at best......Bank earnings are now the next big thing for investors to watch and mkts to digest.We have 3 FED speeches today....Philly's Patrick Harker at 9 am, San Fran's John Williams at 3 pm, and Richmond's Jeffrey Lacker at 4 pm. Can't wait to hear what prophetic words are on the teleprompter....How will mkts react or have the mkts now decided that all of this FED speak is just noise?Take Good Care

The horrendous start to the first quarter for stocks, coupled with losses in energy and commodities, is expected to kick bank earnings in the teeth as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and others report this week. Plunging oil prices in January and February sent the market into a tailspin, lodging its worst-ever start to the year. Accordingly, a…

The horrendous start to the first quarter for stocks, coupled with losses in energy and commodities, is expected to kick bank earnings in the teeth as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and others report this week.Plunging oil prices in January and February sent the market into a tailspin, lodging its worst-ever start to the year. Accordingly, a weak environment for trading and capital markets is expected to hurt banks. JPMorgan and Citigroup (C) are among the lenders who have issued warnings on trading revenue.JPMorgan, which reports Wednesday, is expected to see its earnings decline 13% to $1.26 a share, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue is expected to fall 5.5% from a year earlier to $23.4 billion. The New York-based bank’s shares tumbled 10.3% during the first quarter.In February, the nation's largest bank warned that its trading revenue should decline 20% in the quarter. The drop in trading revenue is expected to be exacerbated by the surge of the Swiss franc in January 2015, resulting in tough year-over-year comparisons. But CEO Jamie Dimon said at the time that improved market conditions in March could help.Dimon himself helped out in February, when he bought $26 million of JPMorgan shares.The bank also boosted its energy loan-loss reserves by $500 million for the quarter, though oil prices have rebounded somewhat since falling below $27 a barrel earlier in the quarter.Bank of America, which reports Thursday, is seen earning 21 cents a share in Q1, down 22% from a year earlier, while its revenue is expected to decline 5.2% to $20.4 billion. The Charlotte, N.C.-based lender’s shares plunged 20% in Q1.Q1 typically is the strongest quarter of the year, but weak trading and investment banking revenue this year "would set up for a tough operating environment through the rest of 2016," according to Jason Goldberg, an analyst at Barclays, in a research note last week.Wells Fargo (WFC), which is also slated to report on Thursday, is expected to earn 97 cents a share, down 6.7%. But revenue is expected to grow a modest 1.6% to $21.6 billion. Its stock slipped 11% in Q1.The San Francisco-based bank focuses more on lending to consumers and businesses. As a result, it isn't quite as exposed to stock market fluctuations as some of its rivals.But Wells Fargo set aside $1.2 billion last quarter for nonperforming energy loans.Also looming overhead is the constant concern over how many times the Federal Reserve will hike interest rates this year. After December's 0.25 percentage-point increase, some Fed officials talked about four hikes in 2016. But the stock market's gyrations, coupled with weak overseas economic growth, has led some to speculate that there will be two rate hikes -- or maybe even none.In a healthy economy, higher interest rates help boost banks' net interest margins, a key measure of profitability. A bank's net interest margin is the difference between the interest it pays out to depositors and the interest it charges borrowers."We want to see higher rates for the right reasons," said Jeffery Harte, an analyst at Sandler O'Neill & Partners. "If the economy is strong enough to handle higher rates, that’s good news for the banks as well."Analysts at Barclays said they're closely watching Wells Fargo's mortgage activity. UBS analysts last month rated Wells Fargo a sell, arguing that its portfolio is tilted toward risky energy and auto loans. Most analysts remain positive on Wells Fargo.Citigroup will earn $1.06 a share, a 30% decline, analysts expect. The revenue forecast is for a tumble of 11% to $17.6 billion. The New York-based bank’s stock fell 19% during Q1. Citi reports Q1 results on Friday.In March, CFO John Gerspach warned that fixed-income trading is expected to fall 15% in Q1 and investment banking revenue is seen declining 25%.Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS) report Q1 results next week. Both investment banks are expected to post year-over-year declines in EPS and revenue.Image provided by Shutterstock.

A provision of the 2010 Dodd-Frank law that takes effect in December forces banks to keep a stake in the commercial-property loans they package into securities and sell off to investors. The rule is intended to deter the type of risky lending that helped fuel the last decade’s boom and bust. Under the current business model, banks are encouraged to issue as many loans as they think they can securitize and sell, with underwriting standards sometimes falling by the wayside, said Lea Overby, a debt analyst at Nomura Holdings.“Originators know their product better than anyone, and they are less likely to underwrite really bad stuff if they have to hold it,” Overby said in an interview.The biggest players in the $550 billion market for commercial mortgage-backed securities, such as Wells Fargo (WFC), Deutsche Bank (DB) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM), are juggling multiple scenarios as they prepare for the new rule, according to bankers with knowledge of the deliberations. Banks may be required to hold as much as $50 million in capital for a $1 billion deal, a tough prospect to stomach with banks under pressure to keep their balance sheets in check. The rule also creates an opportunity for investors to team up with banks on the debt.Turmoil in global markets is exacerbating the uncertainty surrounding how lenders will adjust to the new regulations. The CMBS market is already on shaky ground as the rout in oil prices, slowing growth in China and uncertainty over the Federal Reserve’s course on interest rates spook investors in stocks and bonds around the world.The extra yield buyers demand to own commercial-mortgage bonds relative to benchmark interest rates has surged to the highest since 2011, meaning investors view the securities as increasingly risky, according to Morgan Stanley (MS). Since January, the spread between the benchmark and CMBS rated BBB-minus, the lowest investment-grade ranking, has jumped 240 basis points, or 2.4 percentage points, the bank’s data show. Morgan Stanley analysts led by Richard Hill cut their 2016 CMBS sales forecast to $70 billion from $100 billion as lenders pull back.Dealers are struggling to sell CMBS deals that have been in the pipeline for months, according to Leo Huang, who oversees commercial real estate debt at Ellington Management Group.“Money is being lost in amounts that haven’t been seen in years,” Huang said. “This should remind people there is substantial risk in this business.”The new requirement, dubbed risk retention, applies to all types of securitization, the process by which debt is pooled together and sliced into bonds of varying risk and reward. Such offerings backed by home loans were ground zero for the financial crisis.The changes are creating an opportunity for real estate investors. Industry lobbyists won a concession from lawmakers to create an exemption for the CMBS market, allowing a third party to take on the risk on behalf of lenders as long as they agree not to sell their investment for at least five years. Banks will be held legally accountable if the firm they sell to violates the rules.The CMBS market has a built-in cohort, called B-piece buyers, that buys the riskiest portions, absorbing losses first in exchange for a hefty yield. Firms including Ellington, DoubleLine Capital and KKR & Co. (KKR) have entered the space in recent years, which was dominated by a handful of specialists prior to the financial crisis. Several B-piece buyers are seeking to raise funds to step in for the banks, though it may be difficult to find investors willing to lock up their cash for five years or more, said Warren Friend, an executive managing director at Situs, a commercial real estate consulting firm.Wells Fargo, Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan are among lenders weighing the costs of tying up their own capital versus the economics of compensating B-piece buyers for buying and holding large chunks of new deals, according to bankers at the firms who asked not to be identified because talks aren’t public. Banks with larger balance sheets are more likely to take on the risk themselves, they said.Representatives for Wells Fargo, Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan declined to comment on regulatory issues.One option is for B-piece buyers to buy loans from the banks -- as opposed to just buying a slice -- with the banks selling securitized debt to investors on behalf of the B-piece buyers, said Huang of Ellington, the hedge fund firm founded by Michael Vranos. The bank’s role in the deal would be more of an agent, as opposed to taking on principal risk, Huang said.“Our vision is for banks to do what they do well: using the relationships they have to originate loans and distribute bonds through their sales and trading desks,” Huang said.Some lenders probably will get pushed out of the business by escalating costs, said Overby of Nomura Holdings. Recent volatility has already claimed at least one of the smaller firms. Redwood Trust (RWT) , a Mill Valley, Calif.-based real estate finance company, said this month that it’s exiting the business of making loans for CMBS deals, citing the challenging market and escalating risks. About 25 employees will be cut, the company said.Other lenders are likely to become pickier about the commercial-property loans they issue as the end of the year approaches, said Friend of Situs. That may make it harder for property owners to refinance just as a wave of loans made during the market’s 2007 peak starts to come due, and some borrowers will have to swallow higher costs passed along by lenders, said Friend, who spent more than 14 years as a managing director in the CMBS groups at Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank.“Rates will have to go up,” he said, “and the amount of equity they will have to put in the deal will increase.”Related:U.S. Property Companies See Israel As A Promised Land Of InvestorsMortgage Bankers Would Swap More Risk For Lower Fees

Big tech stocks sold off hard earlier this month, but Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) felt less pain than most -- and the online behemoth's efforts to compartmentalize may have had something to do with it. Thank robust revenue and profit gains, as well as investors who have followed the money, largely on hefty gains from Google’s core online search and advertising businesses.…

With Frank Caruso at the helm since mid-February 2012 -- almost exactly four years -- the $2.7 billion AB Large Cap Growth Fund (APGAX) has topped 98% of its peers tracked by Morningstar Inc. through Jan. 31.The fund notched a 14.55% average annual gain in that time vs. 10.71% for its direct rivals and 12.08% for the S&P 500. It garners an A+ 36-month Performance Rating from IBD, meaning it's performance is among the top 5% of all mutual funds in that time.Lately, the mutual fund has shown it can outperform in ugly markets as well as in beautiful ones. By losing less than its peers and the broad market over the turbulent past three months, the fund ranked in the top 8% of its category. It fell 6.08% last month, a little better than the average U.S. diversified stocks fund's 6.25% decline.Caruso, who is 59 years old, is a member of the AB fund complex, which last year changed its name from AllianceBernstein. Caruso, the lead manager on this fund, discussed with IBD at his Manhattan office how his team invests.IBD: How have you achieved outperformance in bad markets as well as good?Caruso: It's our focus on great businesses, our obsession with the fundamental integrity of holdings and the way we manage risk. Looking at data from March 31, 2012, through Dec. 31, in the 28 up months in that time we were in the 23rd percentile of our peers. In the down months, we were in the 2nd percentile, beating 98% of our peers. The risk-adjusted performance of the portfolio is extremely good.IBD: Business cycles are not your focus, right?Caruso: I don't want people to associate with us any overarching concern about business cycles. We look for consistent performance. That's particularly important in growth stock investing. Companies we want need to have the kind of business that has a long runway to invest those high returns and earn returns in excess of their cost of capital. So it's a combination of persistence and duration that creates and unleashes the power of compounding. Rather than saying we look for high-growing companies, we look for returns and look for that in these really good businesses.IBD: You are looking for companies that can meet your requirements for several years, right?Caruso: Our window is three to five years. For companies in the Russell 1000, you've got a high-teens number of earnings forecasts for this year and next, then it falls off a cliff. As you get fewer estimates three, four, five years out, the variability about forecasts increases a lot. Longer time horizons lead to inefficiency in growth stock investing.IBD: In other words, by having a longer time horizon than most other investors, it's easier for you to find companies that are priced inefficiently?Caruso: It is. Absolutely.IBD: What's a recent example, please?Caruso: Most investors look at Nike (NKE) and see one of the most efficiently priced stocks in the market. But that changes longer-term. What's provocative is that they've been experimenting with new manufacturing technology, a weaving technology. Most people would say Nike's biggest cost is labor. But it's not. It's shipping, tariffs and duties. You can eliminate a lot of those if you localize manufacturing. Weaving technology might let them do that. Instead of (needing a lot of low-paid) workers cutting, banging, stitching, gluing, coloring and packing products, what if they have . . . smaller factories all over the world, decreasing those shipping, tariff and duties costs?So when we model Nike, we can push the profitability up by hundreds of basis points. That gives us confidence in the long term. It informs us about how we might want to behave in the short term if there's volatility.IBD: For a manager who pays little attention to the short term, you're doing well in the short term. Luck or design?Caruso: The fact that stocks go up and down doesn't impact the way we manage the portfolio. Having said that, a year ago we had had good, consistent performance for the last four years. We started to see a lot of risk exposure to momentum (stocks), and we spent the entire year managing that down to more conservative levels. And we have seen reversion to the mean.IBD: In the recent months of volatility, what have you trimmed and what have you added to?Caruso: Part of why we've done well in 2016 is that the market continues to be concerned about earnings, and our portfolio is delivering. But we've reduced our size in excess winners last year and redeployed into more, not defensive, but more edgy, controversial companies that had not been leadership stocks. Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) is one of those names.IBD: Which of the FANGs do you own, and which have you trimmed?Caruso: We don't own Amazon.com (AMZN) or Netflix (NFLX). We have Facebook (FB) and Google (Alphabet (GOOGL)), and haven't trimmed them.We've been more inclined to trim some discretionary stocks. We took profits and reduced positions in Starbucks (SBUX) and Nike because we thought in the moment it was pretty fully valued. But we would welcome an opportunity to build that back through volatility.Disney (DIS) was trimmed. Monster (MNST) and Staples (SPLS) -- which has been a phenomenal performer -- were trimmed.What we've added to: Last summer, we were basically market weight in health care, a little overweight. Those were put through the grinder in late summer, early fall. Into and emerging from that correction, we started increasing our exposure there. We added to Intuitive Surgical last summer. We rebalanced into Biogen (BIIB). We introduced (a position in) Edwards Lifesciences (EW).We did a number of things in tech. We introduced Adobe (ADBE) and Cognizant (CTSH), and we did some adds to longer-term positions, such as ServiceNow (NOW).IBD: Why do you like Intuitive Surgical?Caruso: The company has unbelievable returns. It has $3 billion in enterprise cash and no debt. We’re seeing the utilization of robotics in an ever-increasing number of procedures.For this company to win long-term, we must see more surgeon adoption of robotics, and we’re seeing that. The stock suffered a fair amount of underperformance the past couple of years. But we stuck to our knitting. We added to our stake opportunistically, and we’re starting to see a contribution to fund performance from this stock.IBD: You weren’t in on Facebook’s IPO, but you bought when many others were fleeing. What’s your thesis?Caruso: We were controversial buyers when the rest of the Street was puking it out. We’re proud of that.If you go back to the IPO in the summer of 2012, every banker that bought them had a five-year forecast model -- 2016 was the terminal year. Now their current forecasts are 40% to 60% higher than they were back then. My point is that fundamentals overachievement is really hard to model. But Facebook has potential to drive tremendous excess performance.IBD: Go back to Monster Beverage: Why did you trim it?Caruso: They were on the verge of deploying a lot of capital to be able to sell overseas. Then Coke (KO) took a strategic position in the company. As shareholders, we appreciated before many others that Monster would not have to spend $1 billion to become a global company. They would be able to leverage Coke’s best-on-the-planet global distribution platform. They would get to profits we thought they'd see in 2017-18 in the year 2016.The growth opportunity is increasing exponentially. So the sizing decision was really another one of those Starbucks-type decisions, where these have been unbelievably successful stocks. But the valuations got a little uncomfortable in the short term, so we reduced our exposure. There’s no diminution of our long-term conviction.IBD: You boosted your current stake in Cognizant in between September and November. What’s the attraction?Caruso: They bring a level of expertise in software-as-a-service and mobility solutions to companies that are trying to figure out how to get their IT architecture to the next level.Positioning in key technologies interests us. Cognizant was a stock we talked about at the end of 2013. We stepped away and more recently started to build it back.IBD: Adobe posted earnings-per-share gains for five quarters after suffering EPS declines in seven of the eight prior stanzas. What’s the crux of why things are working?Caruso: They used to put a product in a shrink-wrapped box and sell it. They’ve switched to a subscription model. That allows them to be consistent in how upgrades are managed and deployed. Customers don’t have to wait for upgrades. That model is destined to compress the ups and downs of their business. The lower volatility that results is good from a valuation point of view. And this model lets them manage the risk of piracy in a more head-on fashion. So the long-term value of their subscription model is more attractive than their old model.IBD: Are you among the investors who started to like Alphabet more when the company brought in Ruth Porat as CFO?Caruso: Yes, we became excited when they brought in Porat from Morgan Stanley (MS).Google had a great business, focused on search. But they used cash flow to fund a variety of initiatives that in many cases didn’t appear to make a lot of sense.With the appearance of a strong CFO, we hoped there was finally an adult in the room who would bring financial discipline to the way they thought about allocating capital. So far, she’s done that.Now they’ve got two companies, basically. One is focused on advertising, whether it’s YouTube, which is growing into an economically handsome property, or search.Then you’ve got essentially all of these call options about driverless cars, robotics. They’ve been deploying capital to build out telecom networks in cities. So it’s a portfolio of early-stage companies, some acquired, some nurtured, some ready for prime time, some needing more incubation.The split in the company lets investors have more transparency to properly value the businesses.

Exposure to energy in Wells Fargo (WFC) and an underwhelming global banking performance for Citigroup (C) factored in as they, along with U.S. Bancorp (USB) and PNC Financial Services Group (PNC) reported fourth-quarter and full-year earnings Friday.

Wells Fargo said it earned $1.03 a share for the quarter, up 1% from a year earlier and beating by a penny the estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 0.7% to $21.6 billion, missing estimates of $21.8 billion. Full-year EPS was $4.15 a share, up 1.2% from 2014's total and matched views. Full-year revenue rose 2% to $86.1 billion, missing views of $86.5 billion.

As of Dec. 31, total assets rose 6% to $1.8 trillion compared with a year earlier. Total loans rose 6.3% to $916.6 billion. Total consumer loans grew 2.7% to $460 billion. Commercial loans grew 10% to $456.6 billion.

Wells' net interest margin, the difference between what banks earn in loans vs. what they pay out to depositors, slipped to 2.92% from the third quarter's 2.96% and 3.04% a year earlier. The Federal Reserve's decision to boost interest rates by 0.25% last month — the first interest rate hike since 2006 — is seen as helping boost banks' profitability. But the brutal start to the year for stocks, weak global growth and underwhelming inflation numbers could mean that further hikes could be delayed.

The sagging energy sector also weighed on Wells Fargo to some degree. The San Francisco-based bank reported $831 million in credit losses in the fourth quarter, up 18.2% from the quarter before, primarily due to $90 million in higher oil and gas portfolio losses as well as seasonal increases in non-real estate consumer portfolios. Costs decreased 2% to $12.4 billion from $12.65 billion, reflecting savings on employee benefits and commissions.

Shares tumbled 4.2% to 48.51 on the stock market today. Wells Fargo's IBD Composite Rating is 64 out of 99, meaning it is outperforming 64% of other publicly traded companies. It is trading well below its 50-day moving average, and that fell below its 200-day line back in September.

Meanwhile, Citigroup reported quarterly earnings of $1.06 a share, also beating views by a penny. The New York-based bank earned 6 cents a share in the year-ago quarter because of legal expenses. Revenue rose 4% to $18.6 billion, beating estimates of $17.9 billion. Full-year EPS was $5.35 a share, missing views by 9 cents, but during the year the bank earned $17.2 billion, its biggest profit in nearly a decade. For all of 2014, Citigroup earned $2.20 a share. Full-year revenue fell 1.5% to $76.1 billion, but beat estimates of $75.6 billion.

Allowance for loan losses was $12.6 billion at the end of the quarter, or 2.1% of total loans. A year earlier, that total was $16 billion, or $2.5% of total loans. Citi set aside $250 million to cover losses to its energy portfolio.

Operating expenses fell 23% to $11.1 billion, driven by lower legal costs. Loans fell 4% to $618 billion while deposits rose 1% to $908 billion. Net interest margins slipped to 2.92% compared with 2.94% in the third quarter.

Profit at Citi Holdings, Citigroup's "bad bank" that has housed the company's sour assets since the 2008-09 financial crisis, soared to $704 million from $87 million a year earlier, thanks in part to the sale of OneMain Financial Group, Citi's subprime lending unit. Net income at Citi's global banking unit fell 20% to $1.3 billion and income from its institutional clients group dropped 18% to $1.4 billion.

Citi has sought to become leaner and meaner since the financial crisis. It has sold off a number of its overseas assets in order to slim down. Total assets as of Dec. 31 were $1.7 trillion, putting it behind Wells Fargo in that department.
Citi's shares sank 6.5% to 42.43, well below its 50-day line, which fell below its 200-day moving average in October. Its IBD Composite Rating is 48.

Elsewhere, U.S. Bancorp earned 80 cents a share for the quarter, up 1.3% and beating views by a penny. Revenue fell 0.2% to $5.2 billion, beating estimates of $5.1 billion. Full-year EPS was $3.16, up 2.6% from the previous year, matching views. Full-year revenue rose 2.5% to $20.1 billion, missing views of $20.2 billion.
The Minneapolis-based bank earned $294 million in fees from credit and debit cards, up 8.1% and helping to offset declines in mortgage banking and investment product revenue.

Net interest margin rose to 3.06% compared with the third quarter's 3.04%, but fell from Q4 2014's 3.14%. Average total loans grew 4.2% from a year earlier to $256.7 billion while total deposits grew 6.9% to $294.5 billion. As of Dec. 31, 2015, total assets were $421.9 billion, up 4.8%.
U.S. Bancorp.'s provision for credit losses rose 5.9% to $305 million. The allowance for credit losses was $4.3 billion, down 1.6% from a year earlier.
Shares fell 3% to 38.72, well below its 50-day average. U.S. Bancorp's IBD Composite Rating is 64.

Finally, PNC Financial Services Group earned $1.87 a share, up 1.6% year over year and beating quarterly views by 7 cents. Revenue fell 2.4% to $3.9 billion, beating estimates of $3.8 billion. Full-year EPS was $7.39 a share, up 1.2% from 2014, and beat views by 9 cents. Full-year revenue was $15.2 billion, a 1% decline, but ahead of estimates of $15.1 billion.

The Pittsburgh-based bank's net interest margin was 2.7%, down from 2.89% a year earlier, but an improvement over the third quarter's 2.67%. Total assets were $358.5 billion as of Dec. 31, up 3.9% from a year earlier. Total loans grew 1% to $206.7 billion. Total deposits grew 7% to $249 billion.
Provisions for credit losses were $74 million compared to the third quarter's $81 million while PNC's allowance for loan and lease losses fell 18% to $2.7 billion.
Shares fell 1.4% to 85.66, below both their 50- and 200-day moving averages. The company's IBD Composite Rating is 57.

Big banks' earnings season resumes Tuesday when Bank of America (BAC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) report their Q4 and full-year results. Goldman Sachs (GS) reports on Wednesday. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) issued its quarterly and annual earnings report on Thursday.

Yet her husband, Bill Clinton, reportedly made $10 million as an advisor and an occasional partner in the Yucaipa Global Partnership, a fund registered in the Cayman Islands. A $5 billion legal settlement Goldman Sachs (GS) reached with regulators slashed its Q4 profit along with less-than-stellar trading revenue.The New York-based bank earned $1.27 per share, down 71% from a year earlier and missing by $2.26 estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. The settlement concerning residential mortgage backed securities reduced earnings by $3.41 per share. Including this total, Goldman Sachs would have earned $4.68 a share, easily beating analysts' expectations of $3.53 a share.Many other banks, including JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C), reported lower litigation-related costs vs. a year earlier.Goldman Sachs revenue fell 5.4% to $7.3 billion, beating estimates of $7.1 billion. It's the third consecutive quarter of declining revenue.Goldman stock fell 2% to close at 153.75 the stock market today as the major averages plunged and pared losses Wednesday.Trading revenue fell 9% from a year earlier to $2.9 billion as big banks were hindered by stock market volatility. Revenue in stock trading tumbled 9% to $1.8 billion. Fixed income, currency and commodity trading revenue fell 8% to $1.1 billion, thanks to slumping commodity markets. There have been reports that Goldman will cut a significant number of bond traders and salesmen this quarter.M&A advisory revenue surged 27% to $879 million, Goldman's best performance in that area since 2007. Last year saw $4.7 trillion in announced deals, and Goldman was the No. 1 Wall Street advisor in 2015.The bank's compensation and benefit expenses were $12.7 billion last year, essentially unchanged from 2014's total.Full-year EPS was $12.14, down 28.9% from 2014's total, and missing views by $2.46. Full-year revenue fell 1.3% to $33.8 billion.Big Bank Earnings Season OverGoldman rounds out earnings season for the six largest U.S. lenders. JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup reported last week. Bank of America and Morgan Stanley (MS) reported their results on Tuesday.JPMorgan fell 2.6%, Wells Fargo 1.8%, Citigroup 3.3%, Bank of America 2.8% and Morgan Stanley 3.5% Wednesday. Concerns about loans to the energy sector are also hurting banks.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

The volatility that roiled stock exchanges in 2015 hurt banks' fixed income trading revenue in Q3…

Friday — January 15th…..stocks sold off hard amid the continued global beating….Oil cracks $30 (again) and China’s stock mkt continued to get hammered….anxiety builds around the world causing investors to be very cautious — sending them in treasuries, (flight to safety)  while traders contemplated what to do ahead of a 3 day weekend.  The Dow, S&P & Nasdaq, are now solidly in correction territory — defined as 10% off their most recent highs….  while the Trannies and the Russell are well into BEAR mkt territory - defined as a 20% move off their most recent highs;  investors have been voicing concern for months about the state of the economy — yet the talking heads (Analysts, Strategists, Elected Officials and the FED) have stayed firm to their outlook saying that the US economy is strong, healthy, robust and vibrant and that all of this concern is a bit overblown…… On Friday - NY Fed President William Dudley told a crowded audience that "In terms of the economic outlook, the situation does not appear to have changed much since the last Fed meeting"   (really?) and  Obama told us in his state of the Union Speech last week that "Anyone claiming that America's economy is in decline is peddling fiction."  (Fact check please Aisle 2). Well — not so fast cowboys…..there are 4 common themes playing out —  A.) Broken crude oil as the cries for $20/barrel grow louder and louder;    B.) the looming US recession — that anyone in DC refuses to acknowledge;   C.) concern over 4th qtr earnings and future guidance and D.) Weakening China accompanied by an imploding Chinese stock mkt.

Look Friday’s eco data did little to suggest that we are not in recession……… The tell tale signs?  Lower retail sales;  another weak regional manufacturing report; (this one known as the Empire Manufacturing survey) and slowing industrial production.  The Commerce Department’s retail sales report for December showed a drop in retail sales — albeit modest — but it was DECEMBER…….the supposedly best month of the year — expectations were running high about the health of the consumer - I guess the consumer is not as healthy as they expected...  In a surprise move - Wal-Mart  (WMT) announces 296 store closures and a loss of 16k jobs - 10K of those here at home.....a shift to digital (online shopping) and the previously announced increase in wages are now coming back to take a bite out of profits -so the answer is - CUT JOBS, REDUCE OVERHEAD, AUTOMATE.......  How's that working for you?  Next up was the NY regional manufacturing report suggests that the economy should be moved to ICU — as the general conditions business index (Empire Manf) fell 13 pts to a NEGATIVE 19.4……recall a negative number indicates contraction and while a slightly negative number is nothing to be alarmed about — a LARGER than slightly negative number is a different story…..( and -19.4 is larger than slightly negative…)  add this weak report to the chorus of other weak regional manf reports  and guess what it screams?  Does WAKE UP mean anything?     But that was then — this is now…… This morning US futures are skyrocketing higher...currently UP 31 pts at 1905....Why?  Overnight China reports on 4th qtr and annual GDP….The headlines are a bit confusing…because 4th qtr came in at 6.8% and full year at 6.9% - in line with almost all analysts expectations…..so this is not a bad number — based on expectations.  Yes, it is down from the hey days of 10%+ GDP growth, but the world is a different place today — nothing lasts forever — we knew this…we have been talking about a slowing China for over a year now……Estimates have been coming down — in fact this rate WAS  expected.   The mkts were not surprised at all…if anything — I guess you could say that the mkt was surprised that it actually came in at that number…. CNBC reports that:

“China’s Economy Grew 6.9% in 2015, a 25 year LOW”  “The growth figures, still respectable by global standards, were in line with estimates for quarterly growth of 6.8 % on year, down from the 3rd qtrs. 6.9%, according to a Reuters poll, which also found economists expected full year growth at 6.9%, down from 2014’s 7.3%”So essentially — they nailed it — “This is a good number” — said Jahangir Aziz — Head of Emerging Mkt Economic Research at JPM, “We’ve known for the last 3 years that the Chinese authorities are slowing down the economy.  Notwithstanding the recent equity market turmoil, there are no signs of a more drastic slowdown.”

OK — so we’ve known for the last 3 yrs that they had every intention of slowing down their economy — so what’s the issue?   The issue?  Does anyone really believe that stat?  I mean - it is China we are talking about.....and history suggests that the info is not always what it appears.......

Dr. Doom & Gloom - otherwise known as Marc Faber - suggests that the latest read on China is make believe,  and that the real growth rate for China is nearer to 4%.  Now for those of you who are unaware of Marc Faber - he is a perma- bear and has been calling for the end of the world for 2 yrs now.....saying back in April 2015 - that "for two years now, (since 2013),  I've been thinking that US stocks are due for a correction.......but I always say that a bubble is a bubble and if there's no correction, the market will go up and one day it will go down, big time"

Don't you just love that.....essentially IF the mkt doesn't go down then it will go up until it doesn't and then it will go down!  Brilliant! (And people pay a lot of money to get that kind of analysis....)   So from when he told us of the imminent break - the S&P rallied 43%.... and has since given back 12% off the highs - leaving us still ahead by 31%.......!  I mean you can't make this up....who would believe it?  Now that doesn't mean that the mkt can't go lower - I just sayin.....Either way - Asian mkts surged on the news — the speculation is that the latest data will cause the gov’t to stimulate the economy to make sure that growth stays in this range….….Japan +0.55%, Hong Kong + 1.94%, China + 3.22% and ASX +0.91%.

In Europe this morning — mkts are tracking the Asian action....all are in positive territory in early trading....Mining, energy - basic resources all surging.   Earnings season sending mixed messages there as well as daily reports create very stock specific action.  Thursday is the ECB governing council meeting and while no change is expected - the statement is expected to remain dovish suggesting more stimulus could be in the offing....FTSE + 2%, CAC 40 + 2.51%, DAX + 2.23% EUROSTOXX + 2.25%, SPAIN 1.96% and ITALY +1%. This morning US futures are skyrocketing higher...currently UP 31 pts at 1905...Oil is rallying and all is good in the world!   This is clearly a bit of a relief rally - and one that we should not get too excited about...... I would expect a move to 1925 before we hit any real resistance.  Today's earnings include some big names - Charles Schwab  (SCHW), Delta  (DAL),United Health  (UNH), (they beat), Comerica (CMA) (they beat), M&T Bank  (MTB) (they beat), BankAmerica  (BAC) (they beat) and Morgan Stanley  (MS)-  and as we see - we already have 4 of them 'beating the expectations' and this will surely add to the feel good mood.  ** I will be late tomorrow so next note is Thursday**
Take good care.
Kp

Friday — January 15th…..stocks sold off hard amid the continued global beating….Oil cracks $30 (again) and China’s stock mkt continued to get hammered….anxiety builds around the world causing investors to be very cautious — sending them in treasuries, (flight to safety)  while traders contemplated what to do ahead of a 3 day weekend.  The Dow, S&P & Nasdaq, are now solidly in correction territory — defined as 10% off their most recent highs….  while the Trannies and the Russell are well into BEAR mkt territory - defined as a 20% move off their most recent highs;  investors have been voicing concern for months about the state of the economy — yet the talking heads (Analysts, Strategists, Elected Officials and the FED) have stayed firm to their outlook saying that the US economy is strong, healthy, robust and vibrant and that all of this concern is a bit overblown…… On Friday - NY Fed President William Dudley told a crowded audience that "In terms of the economic outlook, the situation does not appear to have changed much since the last Fed meeting"   (really?) and  Obama told us in his state of the Union Speech last week that "Anyone claiming that America's economy is in decline is peddling fiction."  (Fact check please Aisle 2). Well — not so fast cowboys…..there are 4 common themes playing out —  A.) Broken crude oil as the cries for $20/barrel grow louder and louder;    B.) the looming US recession — that anyone in DC refuses to acknowledge;   C.) concern over 4th qtr earnings and future guidance and D.) Weakening China accompanied by an imploding Chinese stock mkt.Look Friday’s eco data did little to suggest that we are not in recession……… The tell tale signs?  Lower retail sales;  another weak regional manufacturing report; (this one known as the Empire Manufacturing survey) and slowing industrial production.  The Commerce Department’s retail sales report for December showed a drop in retail sales — albeit modest — but it was DECEMBER…….the supposedly best month of the year — expectations were running high about the health of the consumer - I guess the consumer is not as healthy as they expected...  In a surprise move - Wal-Mart  (WMT) announces 296 store closures and a loss of 16k jobs - 10K of those here at home.....a shift to digital (online shopping) and the previously announced increase in wages are now coming back to take a bite out of profits -so the answer is - CUT JOBS, REDUCE OVERHEAD, AUTOMATE.......  How's that working for you?  Next up was the NY regional manufacturing report suggests that the economy should be moved to ICU — as the general conditions business index (Empire Manf) fell 13 pts to a NEGATIVE 19.4……recall a negative number indicates contraction and while a slightly negative number is nothing to be alarmed about — a LARGER than slightly negative number is a different story…..( and -19.4 is larger than slightly negative…)  add this weak report to the chorus of other weak regional manf reports  and guess what it screams?  Does WAKE UP mean anything?     But that was then — this is now…… This morning US futures are skyrocketing higher...currently UP 31 pts at 1905....Why?  Overnight China reports on 4th qtr and annual GDP….The headlines are a bit confusing…because 4th qtr came in at 6.8% and full year at 6.9% - in line with almost all analysts expectations…..so this is not a bad number — based on expectations.  Yes, it is down from the hey days of 10%+ GDP growth, but the world is a different place today — nothing lasts forever — we knew this…we have been talking about a slowing China for over a year now……Estimates have been coming down — in fact this rate WAS  expected.   The mkts were not surprised at all…if anything — I guess you could say that the mkt was surprised that it actually came in at that number…. Ok...so what happened last night? All that hype about the China macro data kept everyone on edge over the weekend...what would they report? Would it be a disaster? What would that say about the health of the Chinese economy and then by default the global economy? In the end - it was NOT a blockbuster, in fact it was rather boring really....

At 10:00 pm est - China released a bunch of data - and it was mixed.....no disasters but no upside surprises either.........3rd Qtr GDP came in above expectations at 6.9% (exp was for 6.8%), Industrial Production did rise 5.7%, but that was below the exp of 6%. Fixed Asset Investments (FAI) - a key reading - came in at 10.3% - below the expectation of 10.8% and Retail Sales - that beat at 10.9% vs. the exp of 10.8%... So what does it all mean? Well - to start with - the data implies that the world is not ending and that the Chinese economy appears to be stabilizing - which in the end is a positive.
Angus Nicholson - Market Analyst at IG sums it up like this:

"It's hard to be overly optimistic about the headline number, especially given the range of other data released today. Nonetheless, markets have clearly been buoyed by the better than expected headline number, and it shows that China's economy has not deteriorated as much as some had thought"
James Laurenceson - Deputy Director of the Australia-China Relations Institute added that:

"The data show a rebalancing away from growth driven by investment and secondary sector production towards consumption and the services sector. It's time we accept that Chinese growth isn't solely at the mercy of industrial production and fixed asset investment"

So maybe, just maybe this is the 'new normal' for China. Maybe the world will see a China growing at a 6 handle and that's ok. Analysts are already looking out to the 4th qtr and suspect that by year end China will achieve annual growth of 6.8% -7% on continued fiscal and monetary support.

Global markets are not panicking with on these reports. In fact - there appears to be a little bit of 'risk on' as the investors/traders are relieved that the data was NOT as bad as analysts had prepared us for. Asian markets essentially ended flat. Japan - the worst performer - ended the day -0.88%, Hong Kong + 0.04%, China + 0.14% and ASX +0.03%.
European markets are also higher - discounting the China data and refocusing on earnings. FTSE flat, CAC 40 +0.32%, DAX + 0.86%, EUROSTOXX + 0.53%, SPAIN flat, and ITALY + 0.61%.

France's Danone Group up 2.5% beat estimates, Germany's Deutsche Bank +3.1%, announces a big management shakeup and restructuring plan - heads to roll and that is helping to send other financials higher. German retailer Metro - announces a rise in sales and is talking all bullish about the coming Christmas season sending this stock up by 3.7%. Air France- KLM announces job CUTS in 2016 and investors love it - sending that stock higher.... and not to be left in the dark - Italian carmaker Ferrari is getting ready to price its IPO tomorrow and will start trading on the NYSE on Thursday.

This morning US futures are off 1 pt.....Now prior to the China report - US futures were pointing lower on the expectation that we were gonna get hit hard....and when that did not happen - Futures moved to the plus side and are now flat. I suspect that the market will test resistance at 2040 and then back off trying to find support in the 2025 range - if not, then definitely the 1980 range.

As much as there is plenty of US macro data this week - the focus will now return to US corp earnings. This week and next week will see hundreds of reports for investors to chew on. Earnings to include: HAS, MS, HAL, GPC, IBM, ZION, AXP, BA, KO, MCD, MSFT, and PG to name just a few.
NOTE: Fed's Lacker is due to speak today at 12 pm.

Up til now - earnings have been, well, not so good. Not horrible, but not great. 70% are beating the estimates while only 48% of those are beating on top line revenue growth. Despite the economic weakness and a bunch of downgrades - stocks have not done so badly.....with the DOW, S&P and Nasdaq all closing close to 2 month highs.... All of these indexes have now pierced their down trending 50 dma's and are now challenging their intermediate term resistance - or 100 dma's. Now here we may hit some trouble - but I think that is just a matter of time....unless earnings completely implode - then I suspect that we will test resistance one or two more times before 'breaking out' and challenging the longer term resistance levels defined by their 200 dma's. And as is usual - as we move thru the 4th qtr - FOMO (fear of missing out) will help to lift stocks going into year end.

Now on the other hand - small caps are lagging...... The most recent lows for small caps came early October and it was much lower than the August 24th sell-off lows. The most recent highs were just two weeks ago and those highs were lower than the highs set in mid-September. - suggesting that a bearish downtrend (lower lows and lower highs) remains intact from a small cap perspective. And why would this be so?

Well - it is earnings season, and it is more common for the large cap/mid cap companies to be able to borrow money to buy back shares which will serve to 'doll up" their earnings per share. (Small cap companies are not nearly as active buying back stock to create the illusion of better earnings and so you have the disconnect.) Or it could be that small caps are more risky and at a time of global nervousness - investors may want the security of large cap, liquid, dividend paying names....It's just a thought.....

The fact that small caps continue to lag might suggest that the selling pressure is not over yet....but until we get thru earnings season the divergence will continue. Then it will be Thanksgiving, and the debt debacle in DC, and then the FED December decision.... so there is plenty ahead to keep investors on their toes the question is: Does the market have enough strength to support another "Santa Clause" rally into the end of the year?
Take good care
Kp

"Words of War" - A special evening in support of comprehensive mental healthcare for Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans will take place tonight - Monday, October 19th, 2015 - Freedom Tower - NYC.

The Headstrong Project - a veterans charitable organization begun by a returning Iraqi War Veteran - A US Marine - that not only saw but understood the impact that this war was going to have on a nation of Americans, will hold their 3rd Annual Fundraiser to help 'heal the hidden wounds of war'. In partnership with Weill Cornell Medical College - One of this nation's leading mental health care centers - The Headstrong Project has developed the first of its kind, comprehensive treatment program for veterans in need.

I am proud to be on the host committee and I am proud to participate as the evening's Live Auctioneer as we raise money to support the very men and women who answered the call. I am looking to break the record and raise $1 mil this evening and I could use your help. Please visit
Getheadstrong.org/words-of-war/
Getheadstrong.org/donate-support/
as we honor the men and women who fight valiantly for our freedom.

Revenue — and how to grow it — were the name of the game for Wells Fargo (WFC) and Bank of America (BAC) in Q3, and one bank succeeded where the other didn't.San Francisco-based Wells Fargo earned $1.05 a share, up 2.9% from a year earlier, on a profit of $5.8 billion. Earnings per share beat analysts' estimates by a penny. Revenue rose 2.6% to $21.9 billion, topping estimates of $21.8 billion.The bank's net interest margin fell 1 basis point from Q2 to 2.96%. A year earlier, that number was 3.06%. The net interest margin measures banks' profitability from interest charged on loans vs. interest paid out in deposits. Banks' margins have been squeezed as the Federal Reserve has kept benchmark rates near zero since December 2008.Loans rose 7.7% year-over-year to $903.2 billion, with commercial and industrial lending up 15%, commercial real-estate mortgages up 8.2%, total consumer loans up 3%, and auto loans up 7.1%.Wells Fargo's mortgage business generated $1.6 billion in fees, down 2.7%. Total assets expanded by 7% to $1.8 trillion as of Sept. 30. Expenses grew 1.2% to $12.4 billion.Shares were down 0.7% to 51.50 in the stock market today.Wells Fargo has been buying some General Electric (GE) assets and recently announced the purchase of GE Capital's $30 billion commercial leasing and lending unit. Earlier this year, the bank bought $9 billion worth of General Electric property loans.Bank of America swung to a profit of 34 cents a share in Q3, beating estimates by a penny, from a year-ago loss of 4 cents a share. Net income in Q3 2015 was $4.5 billion.Revenue fell 2.4% to $20.9 billion, beating estimates of $20.8 billion but marking the sixth time in seven quarters that BofA has posted a revenue decline.But shares rose 0.8% to 15.68.Total assets grew 1.4% to $2.2 trillion as of Sept. 30. Residential mortgage and home-equity loan originations rose 13% to $17 billion. Excluding an accounting adjustment, trading revenue fell 3.8% to $3.2 billion — better than the predicted fall of 5% to 6%. Fixed-income, currencies and commodities sales and trading revenue dropped 11%, hurt by declines in credit-related businesses.Expenses sank 31% to $13.8 billion. Legal expenses plunged to $231 million from $6 billion a year earlier, primarily because of the $17 billion settlement Bank of America paid to regulators last year.BofA is seeking to boost its revenue while waiting for the Fed to raise rates. Cost-cutting has been among the methods applied.The bank's core net interest margin fell to 2.10% from 2.37% in Q2 and from 2.29% in Q3 2014.It was an eventful quarter for BofA, which saw its CEO Brian Moynihan successfully fight off an effort by some shareholders to strip him of his chairmanship. The bank also had to resubmit a stress test to the Federal Reserve.Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS) will report third-quarter earnings Thursday. Rounding out the big six, Morgan Stanley (MS) reports Q3 results on Monday. Citigroup stock fell 1% Wednesday, Goldman lost 0.8% and Morgan Stanley 0.2%JPMorgan Chase (JPM) reported its quarterly results late Tuesday, with revenue falling in a number of its units. JPMorgan shares were down 2.5% Wednesday.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

Electronic payments processor First Data plans to raise $3 billion in what is set to be the largest initial public offering this year. First Data, which KKR (KKR) took private eight years ago for $25.6 billion, is offering 160 million shares at 18 to 20. That would value First Data at about $17.6 billion. It's among seven IPOs planned for this week.
The IPO would surpass Tallgrass Energy (TEGP) as the largest this year. Tallgrass raised $1.2 billion when it priced 41.5 million shares at 29 on May 6.

First Data provides a range of credit card and electronic payment processing services, among other services such as fraud prevention, for banks, merchants and financial institutions. In 2014, it processed 74 billion transactions globally, the company said. In 2014, First Data reported revenue of $11.2 billion and a net loss of $458 million.
First Data is set to begin trading Thursday on the NYSE under the ticker FDC. The lead underwriters are Citigroup (C) and Morgan Stanley (MS).
Albertsons IPO Also Over $1 Bil

The second-largest initial public offering this week — and this year — comes from supermarket chain Albertsons, which is set to raise $1.6 billion. It will offer 65.3 million shares at 23 to 26 each, giving it a fully diluted market value of about $11.9 billion.

Albertsons is the third-largest U.S. grocery store chain, behind Wal-Mart (WMT) and Kroger (KR). An investment group led by Cerberus Capital Management bought Albertsons nine years ago and combined it with Safeway, acquired for $9.4 billion last March. The company operates 2,205 stores across 33 states.
Albertsons is set to begin trading Thursday on the NYSE under the ticker ABS. The lead underwriters are Goldman Sachs (GS) and BofA Merrill Lynch.

Also on the IPO docket this week is Adesto Technologies, a provider of flash memory chips intended for connected devices, also known as the Internet of Things. Adesto plans to raise $45 million by offering 4.1 million shares at 10 to 12.

Adesto follows the tech IPO of Pure Storage (PSTG), a provider of data storage devices based on flash memory chips for the enterprise market. Pure Storage raised $425 million with its IPO last week, offering 25 million shares at 17. Pure Storage stock was up 10% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, above 18.
Adesto is scheduled to begin trading Friday on the Nasdaq under the ticker IOTS.

The third-largest IPO this week is American Farmland, which plans to raise $114 million by offering 12 million shares at a range of 8.50 to 10.50. The company is a real-estate investment trust that owns farmland in California, Illinois and Florida. American Farmland is scheduled to begin trading Friday on the NYSE under the ticker AFCO.
IPOs Were Delayed A Week
Three other IPOs this week are holdovers from last week. They are Stonebridge Biopharma, SynCardia Systems and Cerecor.

Stonebridge Biopharma looks to raise $76.5 million, offering 4.25 million shares at a price of 18. It trades on the over-the-counter market in Norway. Stonebridge is developing therapies for rare endocrine disorders. It will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker SBBP.

SynCardia Systems looks to raise $28 million, offering 2.5 million shares in the range of 10 to 12. SynCardia is a medical technology company focused on developing an implantable system designed to assume the full function of a failed human heart in patients with advanced heart failure. It will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker TAHT.
Cerecor plans to raise $27 million, offering 4.2 million shares at 6 to 7. Cerecor is developing therapies for depressive disorders. It will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker CERC.
A trading date for all three is listed as day to day.

Investor enthusiasm for tech stocks showed continued signs of weakness, as Pure Storage opened below its initial public offering price Wednesday and closed down 5.8%, while wireless provider Digicel Group postponed its IPO.

Pure Storage (PSTG), a maker of flash-chip-based storage products for the enterprise market, priced late Tuesday at 17, the midpoint of its expected range. The stock opened at 16.74 and closed at 16.01, down 5.8%.
The IPO raised $425 million by offering 25 million shares. The lead underwriters were Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS).

Investors had hoped for a strong showing, since Pure Storage was the first tech IPO since the July 17 debut of Rapid7 (RPD), a data-security and analytics firm. Rapid7 was the only tech IPO in Q3, marking the fewest quarterly tech IPOs in more than six years, according to Renaissance Capital.
In Q3, the IPO market slowed to 34 deals, down 43% from Q3 2014, amid a broad market sell-off, Renaissance said.

Since launching its first product in May 2012, Mountain View, Calif.-based Pure Storage says it's signed up more than 1,100 customers. They include large and midsize organizations in many industries, including cloud-based software and service providers, consumer Web, energy, financial services, governments and health care. Its competitors include much-bigger companies EMC (EMC), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and IBM (IBM).

Pure Storage is growing fast but remains deep in the red. For the 12 months ended Jan. 31, Pure Storage reported revenue of $154.8 million, nearly four times its $39.2 million in revenue for the year-earlier period. But it reported a net loss of $183.2 million as it spent more on research and development and sales and marketing.
For the three months ended April 30, Pure Storage reported revenue of $74 million, up 200% from the year-earlier quarter, but it posted a net loss of $49 million.
Pure storage is one of some 130 "unicorns" — venture capital-backed technology companies with valuations of at least $1 billion.
Before going public, Pure Storage had raised more than $470 million in venture capital, giving it a market valuation of about $3 billion, according to CB Insights.
Box Down, New Relic Up

Other post-IPO unicorn companies have had mixed results. Online-storage provider Box (BOX) was the most recent to go public, on Jan. 23, pricing shares at 14. While the stock popped 66% on its first day of trading, Box closed Wednesday at 11.09.
New Relic (NEWR), a provider of software analytics, went public last December. Shares priced at 23 and popped 48% on its first trading day. New Relic closed Wednesday at 39.31.
Overall, the highest-valued unicorn is ride-hailing firm Uber, at $51 billion. Home-rental service Airbnb is valued at $25.5 billion.

The weak market for tech IPOs is a deterrent for many of these companies to list, but several are expected in the fourth quarter, according to Renaissance Capital. The largest is mobile-payment services company Square, which has an estimated market valuation of $6 billion.
Another is Cloudera, a provider of data analytic services, with an estimated valuation of $4.1 billion.
Square's CEO and co-founder, Jack Dorsey, on Monday was named permanent CEO of Twitter (TWTR), where he had been acting CEO and which he also co-founded.
The $450 million raised by Pure Storage marked the second-largest tech IPO this year.
The largest was website-hosting services provider GoDaddy (GDDY), which raised $460 million. GoDaddy priced at 20 and rose 31% on its first day of trading April 1. GoDaddy closed Wednesday at 25.78.

Box had the third-largest tech IPO, raising $175 million. Shopify (SHOP), which helps small and midsize retailers build and manage online stores, raised $131 million with its May 21 IPO. Shopify stock priced at 17, and it closed Wednesday at 37.33.

While the IPO market has been slow, mergers and acquisitions activity among venture-backed companies was healthy in Q3, marking the strongest quarter this year, reports the National Venture Capital Association.
Digicel Postpones IPO
Meanwhile, Digicel Group, which had planned for a $1.8 billion IPO this week, has decided not to proceed at this time.

"Given our growth outlook, an IPO for Digicel was optional and predicated on achieving fair value for the company," said company Chairman Denis O'Brien in a release issued late Tuesday. "Recent volatility in equity markets has seen a number of IPOs listing at a discount to their signaled price range, and this was a less attractive route for us."

Digicel was slated to price Wednesday and begin trading Thursday. Payments startup Square plans to file an S-1 document for its initial public offering within two weeks, Fortune reported Friday, and what that could mean for microblog Twitter (TWTR) remains to be seen.Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey is interim CEO at the microblog while also serving as CEO at Square, which he founded. But Dorsey has been the top pick of many on Wall Street to take on the Twitter post permanently.Should Dorsey be selected to become Twitter's permanent CEO, he wouldn't be the first to run two firms simultaneously. Elon Musk is the CEO of Tesla (TSLA) and of privately held SpaceX, while also serving as chairman of solar installer SolarCity (SCTY).And Steve Jobs ran Apple (AAPL) and Pixar at the same time.Twitter's directors have said the company would only consider as a full-time CEO someone in a "position to make a full-time commitment to Twitter."But Dorsey "is rumored to be well respected inside Twitter, and he has a thorough understanding of the inner workings of the product," Chilton Capital Management analyst Sam Rines told IBD in an email Friday."Square moving forward with an IPO may force Twitter's board to come to terms with having a CEO with two jobs. There are other tech companies with similar set-ups, and Dorsey has a proper team around him with Twitter's head of global revenue and partnerships Adam Bain and CFO Anthony Noto," Rines said. "Dorsey may be able to handle both jobs, and the clarity would be a positive for internal Twitter sentiment and external perception of the company."Dorsey took over in July as interim CEO following the departure of embattled CEO Dick Costolo.When tapped to step up at Twitter, Dorsey continued as CEO of San Francisco-based Square, which Bloomberg said submitted a confidential filing designed for companies with less than $1 billion in annual revenue earlier this summer, paving the way for an IPO.Fortune's report Friday said Goldman Sachs (GS) will serve as lead underwriter, with Morgan Stanley (MS) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) also participating.Square's latest round of private funding valued the company at around $6 billion, Fortune said.Twitter stock fell 4.9% Friday to 25.29, below its IPO price of 26.Since hitting an 11-month high of 53.49 in April, Twitter stock has tumbled more than 50%.In July, Twitter posted a Q2 earnings beat, but investors focused on stalled user-growth.In Q2, the company's monthly active user base — including SMS Fast Followers who can get tweets on their phone without being registered users — rose 15% year over year to 316 million, below the 322 million that RBC Capital Markets had expected.Connect with Michele Chandler on Twitter @IBD_MChandler and Facebook .

Biotech Acorda Therapeutics (ACOR) said Monday that it had reached a settlement with Actavis, the generic-drug arm of Allergan (AGN), agreeing that Actavis' generic version of Acorda's drug Ampyra won't come out until 2027. Acorda stock rose sharply while Allergan's fell.The news, which was revealed only through a terse SEC filing, came as a big surprise to Wall Street. Most had expected the generic version of Acorda's multiple-sclerosis drug to come sooner."We and many investors have perceived Acorda as having little negotiating power to generate a favorable settlement," wrote Leerink analyst Paul Matteis in a research note Monday. "The agreement that Actavis cannot market generic Ampyra until 2027 represents a best-case scenario for a settlement, in our view."Ampyra provides virtually all of Acorda's current revenue, running at $437 million over the past 12 months, so Acorda stock responded favorably with a 12% spike to above 31 in afternoon trading in the stock market today. Allergan was down 3% near 279. Teva Pharmaceutical Industries (TEVA), which has agreed to acquire the Actavis business in a deal closing early next year, was down 3% near 58."If the Ampyra franchise really does go out and have increased visibility to 2027, or anywhere in the 2020s, then the current $420 million Ampyra business should be worth more like comparables of four to five times sales, implying Ampyra could be a $1.6-2.0 billion equity value business or $35-44/share just for the MS indication alone," wrote RBC Capital Markets analyst Michael Yee in a research note. "Of course, the Phase III post-stroke indication would add significantly to this if that study is positive, given the potential to double sales."However, Matteis pointed out that there are nine other generic drugmakers who've sued to make generic versions of Ampyra, so the business is hardly settled. He also wrote that it was possible that the Teva acquisition influenced the settlement more than the fundamental legal issues, especially since Teva itself was one of the other filers contesting the patent."Eliminating one of two filings for Ampyra may be a strategic move ahead of FTC review/approval of the (Teva-Actavis) deal, or could be merely driven by a desire to save money and avoid redundant legal expenses," Matteis wrote. "If this were the case, the readthrough onto other (filers) would be limited; however, we are unsure if this was a motivating factor."Follow Amy Reeves on Twitter @IBD_Areeves and on Facebook.
