Stock futures held healthy gains as the market prepared on Tuesday to roll out for a holiday-shortened week of trade. Dow futures were steady, 230 points above fair market value, suggesting an opening gain of around 1.4%.
S&P 500 futures traded up 28 points, and Nasdaq 100 futures snapped up 66 points — 1.6% above Friday's close.
The stock market today took some of its early strength from overseas markets, which climbed after data released on Monday showed China's Q4 GDP growth slowed to its lowest mark in a quarter-century.

That sounds bad, but the 6.8% GDP gain remained within the government's target boundaries and stirred some relief among those expecting more dour results. China's markets surged, possibly also aided by speculation of further government stimulus intervention. The Shanghai Composite leapt 3.2% on Tuesday. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index swung up 2.1%.

The rally skipped Tokyo's Nikkei, which added 0.6% Tuesday after a 1.1% slip on Monday. Europe's markets were in an optimistic mode, with leading indexes in London, Frankfurt and Paris all up more than 2% near midday.

Oil prices were uneven, with West Texas Intermediate up 1% and Brent crude almost 4% higher, but both still trading below $30 a barrel. Gold slipped and other metals rose, with copper grabbing a 3% gain.

A big week for housing news kicks off with the January Builder Confidence Index from the National Association of Home Builders at 10 a.m. ET. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury International Capital flow at 2 p.m.

Some interesting early stock moves included a 12% spike by electrical utility AES (AES). Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) ran up 9%. Jewelry retailer Tiffany (TIF) slumped 4% after announcing its global same-store-sales slipped 6% during the Christmas season. It lowered its full-year EPS guidance and now expects a 10% decline for 2016.
Earnings season picks up momentum this week, with IBM (IBM), Netflix (NFLX), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Cree (CREE) all scheduled to report after today's close.

Bank of America (BAC) jumped 2% after reporting Q4 EPS narrowly above and revenue a shade below consensus expectations. Revenue from investments made modest gains while net chargeoffs also increased to $1.1 billion, up from less than $1 billion a year ago.

Morgan Stanley (MS) climbed 4% after its Q4 report. The investment bank turned to profit from loss during the period, and earnings easily topped consensus projections. Revenue declined less than expected. Both Bank of America and Morgan Stanley are wrestling with deepening consolidations.

New Oriental Education & Technology (EDU) shares were unchanged as investors reviewed a fiscal second-quarter report showing earnings and revenue easily topped analyst expectations while student enrollments soared 35% during the quarter. Management's Q3 revenue guidance was in line with consensus projections. New Oriental has posted three tight weekly closes, ending Friday 17% below its Dec. 15 high.Stock futures held healthy gains as the market prepared on Tuesday to roll out for a holiday-shortened week of trade. Bank of America (BAC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) reported Q4 and full-year earnings that highlighted big banks' tough revenue environment amid low interest rates and a sagging energy sector.Charlotte, N.C.-based Bank of America earned 28 cents a share in Q4, up 12% from a year earlier and beating by two cents estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 3.2% to $19.6 billion, missing estimates of $19.8 billion.Full-year EPS was $1.38, beating views by three cents. EPS for 2014 was 36 cents, due in large part to massive legal bills, including a mortgage-related settlement worth nearly $17 billion that BofA paid out to regulators. Full-year revenue was $84.2 billion, down 1% from 2014's total but beating views of $84.1 billion.As of Dec. 31, 2015, total assets rose 1.9% to $2.14 trillion. Total deposits rose 7% to $1.2 trillion. Excluding an accounting adjustment, trading revenue rose 11% year over year to $2.65 billion, but tumbled 16% compared to Q3's total.Consumer banking revenue barely rose — just 0.4% — to $7.8 billion. Global banking revenue inched upward 0.9% to $4.4 billion.Non-performing loans, leases and foreclosed properties fell 22.1% to $9.8 billion. Allowance for loan and lease losses fell 15.2% to $12.2 billion.Reflecting declining oil prices, commercial loan defaults rose by $75 million, and BofA has set aside $144 million to prepare for future defaults in its portfolio. CFO Paul Donofrio said during BofA's earnings conference call Tuesday that the bank's $21.3 billion energy portfolio comprises only 2% of its overall loans.Expenses fell 2% to $13.9 billion. Headcount fell 5% to 213,280 employees. The number of BofA branches fell 3% to 4,726.Shares fell 2.3% to 14.13 on the stock market today, trading well below their 50- and 200-day moving averages. Bank of America currently has an IBD Composite Rating of 45, meaning it is outperformed by 55% of other publicly traded companies. Investors have been concerned that a slumping stock market will stay the Federal Reserve's hand in further raising interest rates, which could harm banks' profitability. Other investors are worried about banks' potential exposure to bad loans from the tumbling energy sector.Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley earned 43 cents a share excluding items during the fourth quarter, beating estimates by 10 cents. The New York-based bank earned 39 cents a share once costs were included. In Q4 2014, the bank reported a loss of $1.6 billion, or 91 cents a share, as a result of a $2.6 billion settlement over the sale of mortgage bonds.Fourth-quarter revenue fell 1.8% to $7.9 billion excluding items, beating views for $7.6 billion. With items included, Morgan Stanley earned $7.7 billion. Full-year EPS was $2.70, compared with $1.39 in 2014. Full-year revenue rose 2.8% to $34.5 billion, missing estimates of $35.1 billion.Investment banking revenue fell 10.3% to $1.31 billion. Fees from advising on deals rose 5.7% to $516 million, while underwriting debt fees slumped 25.1% to $346 million. Employee pay and benefits fell 10% to $16 billion. Fixed-income trading revenue fell 8.2% to $550 million.Morgan Stanley shares rose 1% to 26.23 Monday, well below their 50- and 200-day lines. The bank's current IBD Composite Rating is 20.Big banks' earning season wraps up Wednesday when Goldman Sachs (GS) reports. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C) reported their Q4 and full-year results last week.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

An early rally for the stock market faded Tuesday, but stocks still held decent gains about two hours into the session. The Nasdaq gapped up at the open and rose 1.4% but gave back a good chunk of gains. It was up 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.7% and the S&P 500 picked up 0.6%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking lower than Friday's levels in the stock market today.The Shanghai Composite liked news of China GDP growth of 6.8% for Q4 and 6.9% for 2015. The index rallied 3.2%, with the Hang Seng up 2.1%.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, benchmark WTI crude oil was trading around $29 a barrel, down 1%. Brent went the other way, up nearly 3% to $29.35 a barrel.Managed care firms outperformed after UnitedHealth (UNH) reported adjusted earnings of $1.40 a share, down 15% from a year ago but slightly better than expected. Sales rose 30% to $43.6 billion. Shares rose 3%.Inside the IBD 50, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) looked poised to halt a three-session slide. Shares gained 3%. More than 80% of IBD 50 components are below their 50-day lines, including Ulta.In the financial sector, Morgan Stanley (MS) rallied 2%. The investment bank turned to a profit from a loss during the period, and earnings easily topped consensus projections. Revenue declined less than expected.Cruise line operators outperformed in heavy volume. Royal Caribbean (RCL), Carnival (CCL) and Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH) delivered gains of 1%-2%.Earnings season picks up momentum this week, with IBM (IBM), Netflix (NFLX) and Interactive Brokers (IBKR) all scheduled to report after today's close. Netflix rose 2.5% ahead of its results after finding support at its 200-day moving average last week.Connect with Ken Shreve on Twitter: @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook

Major index ETFs surged back bullishly after a choppy start Thursday, but didn't quite erase Wednesday's deep losses. Oil nudged higher even as it continues to trade near multiyear lows. West Texas Intermediate crude settled just above $31 a barrel. Stocks gained as the key commodity showed hints of recovery after eight losing sessions.All 11 Select SPDR ETFs tracking S&P 500 sectors gained Thursday. Energy and biotech climbed most.All but two of the 30 blue-chip stocks in the Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced.Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) rose 5% each, and Apple (AAPL) and Intel (INTC) more than 2% each.Intel fell nearly 5% in after-hours trading despite reporting better-than-expected earnings and sales.There was more corporate earnings news today.SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) popped 1.1% on the stock market today. The ETF holds 62 equal-weighted stocks, but shuts out nonbank financial institutions, such as REITs, insurance companies and pure-play investment banks.KBE slumped sharply in January along with the broad stock market. It is sitting 18% off its 52-week high of 37.28.Its holdings include JPMorgan Chase, the nation's largest bank, which early Thursday reported double-digit bottom-line growth in the fourth quarter. The firm benefited from lower legal expenses and a strong showing from its consumer bank unit.Earnings were up 10.9% from a year earlier, and revenue rose 0.8% to $23.7 billion, both topping estimates.More banks are set to report quarterly and full-year earnings in the coming days, marking their first reports after the Fed's historic decision to raise interest rates by 0.25% in December.Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C) report Friday; Bank of America (BAC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) are slated for Tuesday; and Goldman Sachs (GS) is due Wednesday.Besides JPMorgan Chase, KBE also holds Wells Fargo, Citigroup and Bank of America.Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) advanced 0.9% in above-average volume.Despite gains Thursday, the broad U.S. stock market is an unsettled state.Anxiety about the relentless commodity slump and volatility out of China precipitated a sharp sell-off in January.The Dow and Nasdaq Composite indexes are 10% and 11% off their 52-week highs, respectively. In stock parlance, that marks correction territory.The S&P 500 is 9% off its old high.Small-cap stocks have fared worse: The Russell 2000 is 21% off its June high, indicating a bear market.Gold And DollarHaven assets got a setback as investors piled into stocks Thursday.Gold ETFs sliced below their 50-day lines as the dollar gained. They are 17% off their one-year highs, set last January.ETFs tracking the value of the euro, yen and British pound vs. the greenback all posted losses.10 Bellwether ETFs:Here's a look at how the major exchange traded funds tracking various asset classes performed today.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +1.6%, RS 64PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +2.1%, RS 71SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +1.4%, RS 62IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +1.1%, RS 49IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +1.4%, RS 45IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +1.3%, RS 52Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +1.3%, RS 31SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), -1.6%, RS 62IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), 0%, RS 78PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), +0.3%, RS 86Follow Aparna Narayanan on Twitter @IBD_ANarayanan.

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) saw double-digit bottom-line growth in the fourth quarter, thanks to lower litigation expenses and a strong performance from its consumer bank division.The nation's largest bank earned $1.32 a share, up 10.9% from a year earlier and 7 cents ahead of estimates from analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Net income was $5.4 billion. Revenue rose 0.8% to $23.7 billion, topping views for $22.9 billion.Full-year earnings per share rose 13.4% to $6 a share. Full-year revenue declined 1.3% to $96.6 billion.JPMorgan is the first bank to report quarterly and full-year earnings after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter point last month. Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C) report Friday.JPMorgan's net interest margin, the difference between the interest it charges on loans vs. what it pays out to depositors, increased to 2.23% compared with 2.16% in the third quarter.The bank's shares rose 1.5% to 58.20 after sinking nearly 3% on Wednesday and 13% in 2016 to an 11-month closing low. Wells Fargo climbed 1.8% to 50.64, and Citigroup advanced less than 1% to 45.38.Energy 'Stress'In a prepared statement, JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon saluted the bank's "strong loan growth and credit quality" but warned of "some stress in energy."Tumbling oil prices have been blamed in part for the year's awful start in the stock market, which hurt banks' trading revenue. Also, if the Fed doesn't raise interest rates as quickly as originally thought, that may hurt banks' profitability this year.The bank's provision for credit losses was $1.3 billion, up 49%, reflecting an increase in reserves of $149 million, with $124 million in the oil and gas portfolio and $35 million in mining.The fact that its energy credit reserves are modest suggests that JPMorgan isn't hitting the panic button when it comes to commodities, said Jeffery Harte, an analyst at Sandler O'Neill & Partners. "The fact they're not building more reserves ... suggests they don't see the need to build more. The commentary on energy credit was pretty supportive."As of Dec. 31, JPMorgan's total assets fell 9% to $2.4 trillion. Total loans grew 11% to $837.3 billion. Excluding credit card loans, consumer loans surged 17% to $344.8 billion. Wholesale loans rose 9% to $361 billion. Credit card loans rose a fraction to $131.5 billion.Deposits DownTotal deposits fell 6% to $1.3 trillion. Head count dropped 3% to 234,598 employees.Legal expenses for Q4 were $644 million, down more than 41% from a year earlier. For 2015, legal expenses were $3 billion.Consumer banking net income rose 10% to $2.4 billion. Total non-interest expenses fell 7% to $14.3 billion as JPMorgan and other banks looked to curb expenses in a slow environment.The bank's estimated Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio — which measures core equity capital and indicates a bank's financial strength — was 11.8% in the fourth quarter compared with 10.2% the year before.Net income at JPMorgan's corporate and investment bank surged 80% to $1.7 billion, thanks to lower legal expenses.Investment banking revenue fell 11% to $1.5 billion. Lower debt underwriting fees were offset in part by higher advisory fees. Fixed-income trading revenue fell 3% to $2.6 billion due to reduced activity in commodities and credit markets.Rounding out the six largest U.S. banks, Bank of America (BAC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) report earnings on Tuesday. Goldman Sachs (GS) reports fourth-quarter results on Wednesday. Goldman Sachs is mulling big cuts to its fixed-income staff, reports say.Bank of America rose 0.6% to 14.99. Goldman Sachs tacked on 1.5% to 161.39. Morgan Stanley was up nearly 1% to 27.15.

And the FLUSH continues......by now I am even wondering....who is the TAIL wagging the DOG?   Have we just allowed the roles to reverse?  Can the Chinese stock mkt really hold this much sway over global mkts?   I mean - it's the Chinese stock mkt..... it says nothing about the state of the Chinese economy.......their mkt is not connected to their economy the way Europe and the US is.....I mean our mkts are developed, liquid and thick......everything the China mkt is NOT.(Let me remind you....it is an EMERGING mkt, not very thick and not very liquid, difficult to trade and subject to rule set changes on the fly......)That being said - the Chinese economy IS important to the global economy - no doubt - but my argument is that the Chinese economy is NOT nearly as gloomy as the most recent performance of the Shanghei Index.The Shanghei Index shot up 40% from February 2015 to June 2015   (4 months),  the same move in the S&P at that time would have meant....we went from 2,020 to 2,828  - a bit ridiculous no and very unlikely...............and it was not like the concerns about a slowing China did not exist.....they  did - but no one seemed to care......Chinese RETAIL investors  and some global asset managers were tripping over each other to buy stocks as the search for yield continued..........So what happened?  Well - oil started to crack in June -  when it was trading at $60/barrel, global investment banks began to forecast a break in oil and concerns over weaker commodities, concerns over a slowing Europe (or so they told us), and the increasing likelihood of a change in US FED policy etc. all contributed to a change in mind set.........Aisle 1 - REALITY CHECK!So as the global weakness story builds - they start to run for exits - the Chinese authorities then impose new regulations on the fly....causing more anxiety and  concern.....so that 40% move higher in 4 months does a 180 and collapses under its own weight - taking that mkt right back to where it was almost 1 yr ago....but has the Chinese economy story really changed that much?  No - and that was made clear in the Alcoa  (AA) earnings on Monday......Klaus Kleinfeld is looking at China as an opportunity and not as a drag on his businesses....What will other earnings reports say?  We are about to find out......In spite of deeply oversold mkt, investors continue to be fearful..... The fear trade continues to be gain momentum  - 'selling begets more selling......and it becomes a self fulfilling prophecy...... fear of the 'possible' of weak earnings, fear of an imploding China (unlikely), fear of the FED (overblown), fear of a slowing Europe (in fact not happening),  never mind fear over renewed geo-political issues - all coming together - to paint a picture of doom and gloom.....Remember - mkts tend to overshoot especially when the HERD mentality takes over.....Technically, the S&P is now testing the August lows and is in a deeply oversold  condition.  Note that on January 8th - the 50 dma crossed over the 200 dma - sending out that 'death cross' signal......an indicator that signals a bear mkt on the horizon.....but I have found that by the time the death cross happens - most of the move lower has already happened and in fact it tends to find support and begin the process of repair......I am still willing to bet that this will be the case here as well....That does not mean it rallies right back to S&P 2000. it just means that it churns as the mkt assesses the latest damage vs. the outlook........and the outlook  will become  clearer over the next couple of weeks as the qtrly confessional period heats up.......... Earnings will have to completely blow up for the mkt to implode....Speaking of -

JP Morgan  (JPM) just announced.......4th qtr profit RISES, expenses DECLINE - earnings 'BEAT THE ESTIMATE' -  The biggest US investment bank reported that 4th qtr profits rose 10%, Net Income at $5.43 bil vs. $4.9 bil yoy...... Analysts looking for $1.27 (adjusted) and JPM reports $1.32....the stock is up 80 cts in pre-mkt trading....

Eco data today includes - Import Price Index exp of -1.3%, Initial Jobless Claims of 275k, Cont Claims of 2.21 mil.  Look for a revision to the Philly Fed Index at 8:30 am.European mkts are all a bit lower this morning - but again are they reacting to our action yesterday , or Asian action overnight, or are they leading global mkts thru this turmoil......My sense is that they are reacting....the BoE (Bank of England) voted today to leave rates at 0.5% (no change) while Reuters reports that the ECB is standing pat - choosing not to do any more at the moment - this is NOT new news....Terrorist threats and action in Jakarta, Indonesia calling attention once again to the  'idiots'....causing renewed angst for investorsUS futures are up small - currently +2 pts.. trading at 1882......after having tested 1873 overnight and holding.   They are not GAPPING HIGHER like they have done for the past 2 days only to fail....... The focus will surely be on JPM today and what it says about its peer group - GS, MS, WFC, C, BAC, etc.....  The other biggie today is INTC and they report after the closing bell... - what will they say about China?

Now on the bright side - think  about all the benefits that will accrue to so many industries with lower commodity prices - and that is across the board....lower lumber, copper, steel, along with oil... Housing, construction, manufacturing, consumer retail - discretionary and non-discretionary.... at some point - all the weakness has to translate into a positive for so many industries -  and for the long term investor that has the vision and the iron stomach - this may very prove to be a silver lining.......Now - we need leaders - in DC on BOTH sides of the aisle -  that can institute solid fiscal policy initiatives that will take advantage of this opportunity.Tonight is another GOP debate - FOX is culling the field....Tonight will only feature the top 7 - Trump, Cruz, Rubio, Bush, Kasich, Christie and Carson and out of that group the focus will be on the expected fight between Trump and Cruz.....Get the popcorn....

Stocks struggled yesterday as a weak US eco data point revealed that pending home sales fell by 0.9% vs. the +0.2% expectation and another decline in oil prices ripped thru the mkts.....sending the broader mkt a bit lower while energy stocks went into a tailspin...or at least that is what they want you to believe.... Look - the curtain is about to come down on 2015, volumes light, asset managers taking advantage of some last min window dressing - traders jumping in and out as they try to ring the register....and the mkt did not collapse at all.  We remain well entrenched in the trading range we have been discussing which will leave us essentially flat on the year - add in dividends and maybe the S&P registers a small gain of 2%.....Chalk it up and let's move on.  Yes...oil fell by 3+%, - ending the day at $36.60/barrel,  crude oil supplies rose by 2.9 mil barrels and the Saudi's re-iterated their commitment to keep producing oil at a record pace to try and choke out everyone else.....Ok..but this is getting a bit long in the tooth now, no?  This has the story and will continue to be part of the story in 2016, so there is nothing new here at all...... Themes for 2016......oh boy.....This is sure to set up for an interesting year.....First we have the US Presidential election - and while the Democrats seem to have already anointed their candidate - the Republicans are still trying to clear the field.  There are still some 11 GOP candidates in the race - it is time for them to bow out and coalesce around SOMEONE - my sense is that the longer this circus drags on - the weaker the party gets.....Someone needs to take control... Next up - the FED and Monetary Policy  - Do we need to discuss?  Third will be a continued focus on China and the role it is playing in the global economy..... Fears of a continued slowdown will permeate the analysis and chatter - How will the global economy respond? Next - Oil - is the worst over or will we see another leg down and if we do - what are the implications for the world economy?   Yesterday - the IMF's (International Monetary Fund) Chief - Ms. Christine Lagarde - warned us of 'disappointing global growth for 2016' -  How's that for a  'Happy New Year Toast!' And the list goes on..... Technically speaking - we continue to get mixed signals from the mkts - We have a long term signal  that is hovering on the edge.....suggesting the beginning of a pullback....  Add this to the range of other early warnings - indexes that have already entered bear mkts and you need to at least be aware of a broader mkt pullback.   This signal is nothing more than the simple 10-month exponential moving average on the S&P 500 Index.  Back in August - this signal flashed a HUGE warning as the mkt crashed........ The October rally  took it back up and thru resistance on the S&P - causing some to think it was just an aberration.....Since then, the S&P has gone mostly sideways, gradually turning lower again in December - bit still not sending the definitive signal....which is why we are 'hovering'....Next look at the DOW Industrials vs. the DOW Transports.  If we are to believe that the bulls remain in control then the Transportation Index should be mimicking the Industrial index, according to the DOW Theory - which it is NOT. Since November -  the transportation index has been in a harsh and steady decline - vs. the sideways pattern of the industrials.   The decline in the Transports reflects a lack of shipping demand. So, regardless of headline reports about how much Amazon shipped and the role that UPS and FEDEX played - raw materials and finished goods are in serious trouble — evidence of serious demand degradation. Now I am not screaming FIRE at all - I am just putting it on the table to consider....add in the  'unknown exposure'  in the derivative mkts and you can see how it could get a bit dicey. Think August 24th....... (and I say unknown for a reason - because it IS UNKNOWN - no matter what they tell you.... - think the housing crisis and all of the insurance products created to protect everyone from loss - REALLY???)  I'm just sayin.......   If - like in August - the mkt hits a pocket of air and goes into free fall - the additional pressure created by all of the varied 'synthetic products' - products that are highly leveraged -  will only exacerbate the move......and then we'll get another SEC report 8 months later -  that will try to explain the move.......it's fairly simple - They have allowed the level of complication and risk to rise beyond what is reasonably considered to be controllable.......what do we need to see next to wake them up?This morning we see global mkts under a bit of pressure and as the year ends here are the ytd numbers: Japan +9.9%, Hong Kong -7%, China +9.4%, ASX -2.1% FTSE -4.8%, CAC 40 +9%, DAX +9.5%, EUROSTOXX +4.1%, SPAIN -7%, ITALY +12.6%US Futures are flat this morning.....as the S&P  ended the day at 2063 yesterday - essentially flat on the year.  I suspect that they will work hard to close the mkt above 2058 and they may even try to rally it to 2100......(wishful thinking.). For us - the year looks like this:  DOW -1.2%, S&P +0.22%, Nasdaq +7%.Let me take a min to thank each and every one of you for being a Morning Thoughts reader.   I appreciate the comments that you send back as I try to respond to everyone that  offers opinion or analysis.  It has been my pleasure to both feed you financially as well as physically.  I hope you enjoy the 'boots on the ground' down home style.  I wish each of you - continued good health, prosperity and love of family and friends as we enter the new year.    Take Good CareKPKenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O’Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. The Labor Department said that the total nonfarm payroll employment rose by 211,000 jobs in November, keeping…

And the battle goes on...Stocks did nothing yesterday,chopped back and forth all day to finish the month essentially right where it started, now although there had been volatility during the month — you would not know it by looking at last night's close, only emphasizing the battle of the Bulls and Bears.  The weakness or rather the lack of interest in yesterday action reflected a range of issues, the lackluster Black Friday results, the coming deluge of macro date, mkt exhaustion, uncertainty over what’s next for monetary policy, what is in store for the ECB and what will come out of the mouths of all the different Fed speakers this week…..it is a lot to chew on..Now stocks remain a bit overextended which should cause it to pull back just a bit  but it is also the final month of the year and equities have made significant gains in  22 of the last 27 yrs during the month of December A recent Bank of America  (BAC) survey shows that global stock allocation is now at a 6 month high with investors betting on more stimulation from the ECB and a 'take it slow' approach from the FED if she pulls the trigger on December 16th (the jury is still out on that decision but the sense is that she is trapped like a rat and has to move on rates to establish credibility now). So it’s anyone’s call on what’s next.

Investors and the mkts expect both the ECB to add more stimulus and for the FED to move on rates while remaining cautious in the months ahead, anything short of those expectations will cause the mkts to convulse meaning that if Uncle Mario Draghi does not deliver or that the mkt senses that Yellen (or other Fed members) thinks the economy is 'over heating'- thus sending the message that rates will rise faster and steeper than expected — then watch for a major revaluation of asset prices. You see — they have tried to assure the mkts that it's all good and now the mkt is ok with that.

I think the biggest risk is what the FED says next and how they say it. The problem is that when you have 12 people trying to say something — it is never the same message, the wording, the intonation, the body language, the slight wink or awkward smile all reveal how that person really feels. So after they move on rates in December investors/traders will want to know what the plan is going forward. When can we expect the next move?  Can we assume that 25 bps increases will be the norm?  Does the FED think that the US economy is overheating causing new speculation on the rate/pace of further tightening?  All very valid questions — and the economic macro data is telling.

Econ data of late has not been so healthy; Friday - Milwaukee ISM plunges to 45.34, Yesterday the Dallas Fed manufacturing survey printed at -4.9 (11 months is row of negative prints) , Chicago’s Purch Managers survey — dropped to 48.7. (Now remember - a print below 50 on any of these regional FED surveys signals ‘contraction - so that is 3 in a row). Pending home sales worse than expected and this morning's Journal - well don't look for presents under the tree in terms of the economy.

"Companies Shy Away from Spending" - Investment is 'fizzling'; Companies are reluctant to spend on capex the most recent measure shows a decline of 3.8% in the first 10 months of the year; Stock buybacks are up 10.4% in the 3rd qtr alone suggesting that companies see little reason to achieve good return via capital investments.

"Morgan Stanley  (MS) to CUT a Quarter of Bond, Currency Trading Jobs" - Trading revenue slump prompts a review of staffing needs. Morgan plans to slash hundreds of jobs, joining their peers in the annual slash and burn of employees. But finance jobs are not the only ones at risk, retailers, manufacturers and energy companies have all signaled tougher times ahead, and job cuts on the table. Diesel engine manufacturer Cummins's (CMI) CEO Tom Linebarger lays it out clearly, "With no clear signs of improvement in the near term, we are now implementing additional restructuring - which includes 2,000 layoffs and a widespread review of manufacturing capacity...."  On the positive side of the ledger sheet - our friend Chris Concannon - CEO of BATS Global Markets -  announces a 2016 Plan to IPO.....saying that they are worth more than $2 bil. or more than 3X their 2012 $760 mil valuation. Amazing what HFT and sub-pennies will do for valuations. The only question is - Can they IPO without blowing up again?

Ok...so back to the FED......and the argument that they must raise rates to get out in front of this overheating economy is almost laughable..... with every economic report showing signs of an  economy that is gasping for breath as we battle possible deflation.  But - as noted above - Yellen and her band of merry men are backed into a corner.....so a 25 bps rise is sure to happen......but my sense is that she will back off of any further talk of hikes in the near term.....which should serve to stabilize the mkts and allow for more time for the economy to catch up......so is there really any reason for the mkt to 'surge' from here....not so much, but is there any reason for the mkt to plunge either....again, not so much...... and so the churn continues....

US futures are up 7 pts this morning at 2087.........ok...great - down 10 yesterday, up 7 today......get the picture?  We are still in the 2065/2100 range...and that my friends is where I suspect we will remain for now.   Eco data today includes US Market Manf PMI - exp of 52.6, ISM Manf of 50.5, ISM Prices Paid of 40.....and don't forget the FED speakers....Evans at 12:45 and Brainard at 8 pm......

Overnight in Asia - Mkts rallied....Japan pierces 20k on the Nikkei,  In China - more disappointing macro data.....Manf PMI declined to 49.6...while the Services PMI rang the bell at 53.6.....so you have ying and yang....and the promise of more stimulus.....In another move - the IMF has admitted the Chinese Yuan into the Big Boys Room - making it a reserve currency starting in October 2016......with Christine Lagarde saying that it was "a recognition of the progress that the Chinese authorities have made in the past years in reforming China's monetary and financial systems."    Japan +1.34% , Hong Kong +1.75%,  China +0.32% and ASX +1.9%. In Europe  mkts are mixed but mostly higher..... The Eurozone unemployment report shows that unemployment is falling -  going from 10.8% to 10.7%. - OK...nothing to write home about BUT it did fall!    The countdown is on for Thursday's ECB statement..... FTSE+0.52%, CAC 40 -0.11%, DAX -0.02%, Eurostoxx +0.09%, Spain +0.48% and Italy +0.36%.   Take good care —  Kp

Stocks fell hard yesterday, as energy names got clobbered; Spdr Energy  (XLE) -3% because oil came under new pressure - breaking $40/barrel sending the algo's into a tailspin, Utilities under the gun; Spdr Utilities  (XLU) - 2.3% on the prospect of the coming rate hike, the dollar showing strength  because of that same rate hike all causing the broader mkt to come under pressure.

Toss in the speech that Yellen gave yesterday at the Economic Club of Washington and you have the perfect recipe for disaster.....First of all....I have to ask - Why does the media find it so important to broadcast a speech that Yellen is giving to a local Economic club?

[Their own home page says it like this: The Economic Club of Washington, D.C., has, since its founding, played a vital role in shifting the perception of Washington, D.C., from a focus on the city as the center of our national government to a growing awareness of the region as a global business destination] Now yes....it is a Washington DC club and has access to so many people - BUT it is NOT national policy, it is NOT where FED decisions are made, and it is NOT the FED....it's a local club...... So - This was NOT an FOMC speech, it was NOT a formal policy speech, it was NOT a press conference...in fact all it was - was a scheduled speech delivered by the FED Chair.....ok...I get it, She is the FED chair.....but in the end who cares?  Why does this matter when she is just giving a prepared speech to a group of economists (well educated but none of which will influence policy) .....

Did anyone think she was making 'the announcement'?   This was NOT an announcement about new monetary/economic policy....it was just more of the same.....hash and re-hash...because in the end she played both sides of the fence leaving it open to speculation/interpretation and conjecture - for WHAT?  Is this not clear? “On balance, economic and financial information received since our October meeting has been consistent with our expectations of continued improvement in the labor market,” Ms. Yellen said in her speech. “Continuing improvement in the labor market helps strengthen confidence that inflation will move back to our 2% objective over the medium term.”.......She went further and said:

“Were the [Fed] to delay the start of policy normalization for too long, we would likely end up having to tighten policy relatively abruptly to keep the economy from significantly overshooting both of our goals,” she said. “Such an abrupt tightening would risk disrupting financial markets and perhaps even inadvertently push the economy into recession. Moreover, holding the federal funds rate at its current level for too long could also encourage excessive risk-taking and thus undermine financial stability.”  The longer she spoke the worse it got....the Twitter sphere, the business news channels offering up min by min analysis.....what did that word mean?  What did that sentence mean?  Did you see the look on her face - surely that must mean that rates are not going to rise or maybe she is just playing us....????  Blah, blah, blah....and so we have more of the same.  And today we get to do it all again as Janet now addresses the Jt Economic Committee of Congress....expect more of the same again......it's exhausting really......all this transparency is BS......In the end - she made it clear that she is ready.....enough of the foreplay......let's get to it!

This was clear in what she said about possible dissension in the ranks - which some expect will only complicate her position....“I don’t need unanimity. I think we have to tolerate some dissent,” Ms. Yellen said Wednesday, in answer to a question after delivering a speech on the economic outlook. “I wouldn’t try to stifle dissents, and I would even expect some at critical junctures.”

And there it is.....she just laid it out...SHE DOES NEED UNANIMITY.... and chiming in from FL - was Atlanta FED pres Lockhart.....saying: “Absent information that drastically changes the economic picture and outlook, I feel the case for liftoff is compelling"

Now back to OIL.... We have been talking about the importance of paying attention to the oil market for a long time now....as this is so crucial in understanding the dynamics at play.... Oil prices fell below $40 a barrel yesterday amid this growing global glut which only puts  more pressure on an industry that already is already bleeding....Yesterday we got a report that signaled the 10th straight weekly rise in U.S. inventories of crude oil at a time of year when they are expected to shrink.....but the real problem is global production......as  OPEC, the U.S. and other non OPEC members  are locked in a battle for market share that has left the world flooded with oil.  This will all come to a head tomorrow...at the OPEC meeting...what will the Saudi's do?  Will they play nice in the sand box?  Doubtful....so oil will almost certainly remain under pressure.... which will continue to put pressure on the energy space......and until we see total capitulation we have not seen the bottom....but it feels like we are one step closer to the 'flush'.  There is plenty of room for crude oil prices to continue to collapse, based on this chart — given that support has now been violated.   $30/barrel is not out of the question at this point... and given that rising rates will only further strengthen in the dollar - is that what  the Fed wants, perhaps believing that if gas prices collapse then that could actually help the economy?  This morning - the humans got to re-think all the noise - and realized that the action created by the algo's yesterday was ridiculous....the mkt and investors are now conditioned to accept a 25 bps hike... but they are also keen on going slow in the new year....and that is exactly what Janet intimated yesterday.....and so after  the  selloff yesterday - US futures are up 10 pts at 2092.........volleying between 2065 and 2100.....Does this sound like a broken record? Eco data today includes Challenger Job Cuts - came in at -13.9% which is a positive number - because it says that job losses were 13.9% lower than last year...... We will also get US Services PMI at 56.5, and ISM Non Manf Composite read of 58.  Factory orders to show a gain of 1.4%. European mkts are all higher as they await the Draghi news conference and announcement...the chatter in Europe is that he has to deliver something really BIG....More Park Sausages, MOM!!!  If he fails to deliver that then look for  a selloff  - but I do not believe that will happen...  Here comes Santa Clause....the FTSE+0.12%, CAC 40 +1.07%, DAX  +0.68%, Eurostoxx +1%, Spain +0.86% and Italy +1.13%. Take good care —  Kp

Why does the media find it so important to broadcast a speech that Yellen is giving to a local Economic club?[Their own home page says it like this: The Economic Club of Washington, D.C., has, since its founding, played a vital role in shifting the perception of Washington, D.C., from a focus on the city as the center of our national government to a growing awareness of the region as a global business destination] Now yes....it is a Washington DC club and has access to so many people - Facebook (FB) COO Sheryl Sandberg, Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned YouTube's CEO Susan Wojcicki and former…

The stock market shuffled the cards Friday and came up with new winners and losers for the day, as a strong payrolls report increased the odds of an interest rate hike. The Nasdaq posted an 0.4% gain, while the S&P 500 fell less than 0.1%. Small caps led as the Russell 2000 added 0.8%. The IBD 50 advanced 0.4%. Volume…

JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and other bank stocks rallied on October's strong job report, which makes an interest rate hike likelier, especially after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen said a December rate hike is a "live possibility." U.S. banks have found their net interest margins increasingly squeezed, thanks to interest rates being at near-zero levels since the height of…

Square has provided IPO pricing guidance that values the company at less than its private valuation. The San Francisco-based payments startup plans to sell 27 million shares at an expected price range of $11 to $13 each, according to documents filed Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Square held its most recent private-funding round in October 2014, which reportedly…

Stocks chopped around, but ultimately squeezed out gains Monday, extending their winning ways. Thanks in part to megacaps Intel (INTC) and Priceline (PCLN), the Nasdaq outperformed with a 0.4% gain. Intraday, the index was off as much as 0.4% and up as much as 0.6%. The S&P; 500 bounced back from a 0.5% loss to end fractionally higher. Strength in…

The Federal Reserve Board proposed long-awaited rules for reining in losses from institutions deemed "too big to fail." It requires the eight largest banks to raise a total of $120 billion in debt that could be converted into equity in a crisis.New guidelines, known as "total loss-absorbing capacity," or TLAC, will increase the amount of capital, defined as a combination of shareholder equity and debt, that large banks will need to have. Regulators believe that banks need bigger cushions in case of crises like the one in 2008 that required taxpayer bailouts.The Fed set the TLAC at a minimum 18% of risk-weighted assets. Banks affected by the rules will have until January 2022 to comply, although a months-long comment period will occur before the Fed issues a final rule.Some of the largest banks will need to have more capacity. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), the largest by assets, will see its ratio rise to 23.5%. Citigroup (C) will have a 21.5% minimum. Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) will have 20.5%, with Wells Fargo (WFC) at 18.5%.JPMorgan, Citigroup, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo stocks all fell 1%-2% Friday.

Swiss pharma giant Roche (RHHBY) was a rare drug stock moving up Monday after its U.S. biotech arm Genentech said its drug candidate succeeded against primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS) in a clinical trial. Roche said its drug ocrelizumab had met the late-stage study's primary endpoint of showing significantly reduced progression of clinical disability, compared with the placebo group, after…

Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. Stocks hung in mixed territory early Monday as company news drove the lion's share of opening trade. The Nasdaq led with a 0.2% advance. The S&P 500 slipped 0.3%, and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume was soft, down 38% on the Nasdaq and 56% lower on the NYSE, compared with options-expiration-boosted levels at the same on Friday.

Economic news in the stock market today opened with the National Association of Homebuilders' Housing Market Index, which jumped to 64 for October. That was up from September's 62 reading, better than consensus expectations for no change and the gauge's best showing since late 2005.

In stocks, Morgan Stanley (MS) dived more than 5% after a disappointing third-quarter report. Halliburton (HAL) backed off more than 1% after beating earnings forecasts but coming up short on the revenue line.

Hasbro (HAS) crumbled 6%. Its 8% EPS gain topped Q3 expectations, but revenue rose only a fraction, a shade below forecasts, and entertainment and licensing revenue declined 2%. The loss sent shares back below their 50-day moving average in heavy trade.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) tanked 6% despite easily clearing consensus earnings and revenue estimates for the third quarter. Fourth-quarter sales and earnings guidance was in line with expectations.

SanDisk (SNDK) surged 5% after news reports said the maker of memory chips might be an acquisition target for South Korea's Samsung Electronics (SSNLF) . SanDisk has climbed sharply in the past three weeks and is up 65% from an August low, buoyed largely by chip-industry consolidation.

Hard drive manufacturer Western Digital (WDC) popped 3%. The Irvine, Calif. company said a decision by China's Ministry of Commerce allowed it to integrate its China-based HGST and WD subsidiaries under the parent company. The company says the integration should result in "significant opportunities for growth, synergies and cost savings." Western Digital is up from an early October low but still deep in a 10-month consolidation.

Among leaders, Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) scrambled 3% upward, seizing a new high on powerful trade. The egg producer/distributor is now almost 4% above a 60.20 buy point, formed from a handle in a double-bottom base.Stocks hung in mixed territory early Monday as company news drove the lion's share of opening trade. Stock futures slipped into moderate losses early Monday as the week edged toward a quiet start. Dow futures were down almost 60 points and falling. Nasdaq 100 futures backed out of thin gains to trade down 8.4 points. S&P 500 futures were off 7.5 points.
Small caps were taken a beating, with Russell 2000 futures lagging by more than 8 points.

The stock market today opens atop three straight weekly gains, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 both back above their 50-day moving averages and eyeing the underside of their 200-day lines with a confirmed uptrend in play.

In economic news, China pulled the big headlines Monday, reporting Sunday night the country's Q3 GDP grew 6.9%, a shade below its official 7% target rate, but above consensus expectations of 6.7% reported by Bloomberg. The Financial Times quoted an HSBC Bank economist saying the number probably represented a floor in how bad things will get in China.

The data showed services grew 8.6%, up from 8.4% growth through the first half of the year. Separate data for September showed monthly growth in industrial output slowing to 5.8%, near a six-year low. September retail sales narrowly topped expectations, rising 10.9% vs. the 10.8% consensus.

U.S. data rolls out at 10 a.m. ET with the National Association of Home Builders' October builders confidence index. Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker is scheduled to speak at noon.
Third-quarter earnings season continues to unfold. Of the 74 companies reporting results last week, 41 topped earnings expectations, 20 missed, 13 met.
Halliburton (HAL) and Petmed Express (PETS) both traded lower after reporting mixed quarterly results early Monday.
Morgan Stanley (MS) added to the misses tally, diving almost 6% after reporting Q1 earnings and revenue well below expectations.

The investment banker pointed to its fixed income and Asian merchant banking units as particularly weak during the quarter. Revenue from its wealth management business slipped nearly 4%, but accounted for almost 47% of total revenue, up from 42% a year ago. Shares are in a three-month consolidation.
Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) slipped 2%. The Quebec-based drug maker reported Q3 earnings up 30%, vs. expectations of 28% growth. Revenue jumped 36%, also easily above forecasts.

Its U.S. dermatology and contact lens businesses met or beat expectations and results in China, South Korea and Mexico were strong. Guidance just met current consensus projections. Valeant shares rose last week for the first time in four weeks, and remain 33% below their August high.
Weight Watchers International (WTW) zoomed ahead 53% on news that Oprah Winfrey had taken a 10% stake in the company, with options for an additional 5% and had joined its board of directors.

"I believe in the program so much I decided to invest in the company and partner in its evolution," Winfrey said in a statement. Weight Watcher shares are up 85% since July, but still down more than 90% from a May 2011 high.

Chip maker PMC-Sierra (PMCS) popped 13% ahead of the open, after announcing Microsemi (MSCC) made a cash-stock bid for the company valued near $2.4 billion. The offer tops a $2 billion offer made earlier this month by Skyworks Solutions (SWKS).
Overseas, China's markets closed narrowly mixed. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slipped 0.9%. Europe's top indexes were also locked in tightly mixed trade heading into the lunch hour.
The dollar rose vs. the euro, slipped against the yen. Bonds were effectively flat. Oil and gold both traded down about 1%.

Major averages closed in the black Monday after spending most of the session near either side of the flatline, as investors weighed more earnings reports and weak economic data out of China.

The Nasdaq led with a 0.4% gain, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each closed up less than 0.1%. Volume was quiet across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.

Steel, toymakers and energy stocks saw big losses. Online travel bookers, airlines, and shoe and apparel makers led the upside. Winners outpaced losers by about 7-to-5 on the NYSE and by a smaller margin on the Nasdaq.

Nike (NKE) ran up 2% in fast trade, extending its winning streak to four sessions. BB&T upgraded the athletic wear powerhouse to buy from hold. Shares are 5% past a 126.59 three-weeks-tight buy point initially cleared Oct. 12.
But earnings reports roiled some big names. Hasbro (HAS) sank 7% after its Q3 earnings topped views but revenue slightly missed. The stock sliced its 50-day moving average in busy turnover.

Morgan Stanley (MS) also had a bad day, gapping down and shedding 6% in heavy volume. Shares hit resistance at their 50-day line Friday. The financial giant reported Q3 profit that missed forecasts by a wide margin.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) sank 8% despite reporting Q3 results that topped views and raising its full-year sales guidance. The stock has been trading well below its 200-day line since late September.
After the close, IBM (IBM) reported Q3 earnings that topped views, but shares were down about 3% in extended trading.

On the IBD 50, Cal-Maine Foods (CALM), Hawaiian Holdings (HA) and LGI Homes (LGIH) soared more than 4% each in above-average volume. But Microsemi (MSCC) fell 5% on news that it offered $2.2 billion to buy PMC-Sierra (PMCS), above Skyworks Solutions' (SWKS) earlier $2 billion bid. PMC-Sierra jumped 14%.

Stocks' roller-coaster third quarter — punctuated by a "Black Monday" in August — hurt Wall Street banks' performance in Q3, as Goldman Sachs (GS) and Citigroup (C) joined JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) in reporting lower trading revenue.Goldman, which has the most Wall Street exposure of any of the biggest U.S. banks, earned $2.90 a share in Q3, down 36.3% from a year earlier and missing by a penny estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue fell 18.3% to $6.9 billion, missing views of $7.1 billion. That's the third time in four quarters that Goldman's revenue has declined.The volatile markets, fueled by concerns of slowdowns in China and other emerging markets, hurt a number of Goldman Sachs units during the quarter. Institutional client services revenue fell 15% to $3.2 billion. Fixed-income, currencies and commodities tumbled by one-third to $1.5 billion. Equities trading revenue rose 9% to $1.8 billion.Investment-management revenue fell 3% to $1.4 billion.Investment-banking revenue continued to be a strong point for Goldman, climbing 6% to $1.6 billion. Financial-advisory revenues soared 36% to $809 million as Goldman remained one of Wall Street's top banks for mergers and acquisitions.Total underwriting fell 14% to $747 million. Equity underwriting plunged 55% to $190 million, as fees on initial public offerings and stock sales declined. Debt underwriting rose 25% to $557 million.Goldman's expenses fell 5% to $4.8 billion.Return on equity was 7% in Q3. Total assets under supervision rose 3% to $1.2 trillion as of Sept. 30.Goldman shares rose 3% to close at 184.96 in the stock market today. Its current IBD Composite Rating is 47, meaning it is being outperformed by 53% of other publicly traded companies.Citigroup Legal Costs DiveCitigroup also was impacted by choppy stocks, though it benefited from favorable comparisons to the year-earlier period, when it had to restate earnings due to mammoth legal costs.The New York-based bank earned $1.31 in Q3, up 13.9% from a year earlier, topping estimates by 3 cents. Net income jumped 51% to $4.3 billion, thanks to significantly lower legal expenses. Revenue fell 7.4% to $18.496 billion, missing views for $18.541 billion. That's the seventh time in eight quarters that Citigroup's revenue has fallen.Operating expenses dropped 18% to $10.7 billion, with Citigroup joining Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America in cutting costs as business flagged.Citigroup's overall trading revenue slipped 7% to $3.6 billion, slightly worse than the bank had forecast last month. JPMorgan Chase reported a 6% decline in trading revenue, while Bank of America trading revenue fell 4%.Citi's return on average common equity was 8%, compared to 5.3% in the third quarter of 2014. Its common-equity tier 1 capital ratio was 11.6%, compared to 10.6% a year earlier.Net interest margin, which measures banks' profitability via the difference between loans and deposits, was 2.94%.Citi Holdings, a subsidiary at which Citigroup stores the bad assets it wants to sell, was profitable, and its assets declined 20% to $110 billion. Citicorp, which contains the bank's corporate-banking and global consumer units saw a 62% profit increase to $4.3 billion.Legal expenses fell dramatically to $376 million, compared to Q3 2014's $1.6 billion.Citigroup is in the process of slimming down its operations, exiting its consumer-banking businesses in 11 countries.Shares climbed 4.4%, finishing at 52.97 and passing its 50-day moving average, though the 50-day line has crossed below the 200-day. Its current IBD Composite Rating is 52.Big banks' Q3 earnings season wraps up on Monday when Morgan Stanley (MS) reports. Wells Fargo (WFC) reported third-quarter earnings on Wednesday.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

Alphabet (GOOGL) unit Google and several others have invested more than $100 million in newly launched messaging service Symphony, the startup said Monday, showing more big backers for the would-be rival to Bloomberg.
The new capital will be used to "address the high demand it has received in the past few months leading up to its launch and to speed up expansion of its global operations."

Palo Alto-based Symphony, which launched its service in September and has forged content partnerships with News Corp. (NWSA)-owned Dow Jones, McGraw-Hill Financial (MHFI) — which owns Standard & Poor's — and Selerity, is poised to compete with terminals from the likes of Thomson Reuters and Bloomberg. The startup says its cloud-based messaging platform is meant for highly regulated businesses that have compliance needs.

"(W)e now have more than 40,000 users in 100 countries (the 100th country from which we have users is Cote D'Ivoire!) and have booked more than $10M in service orders in just a few months," Symphony CEO David Gurle said in a Monday blog post.

Symphony's roster of new and existing investors includes: Bank of America (BAC), Blackrock (BLK), BNY Mellon (BNY), Citadel, Citigroup (C),Credit Suisse (CS), Deutsche Bank (DB), Alphabet's Google, Goldman Sachs (GS), HSBC (HBC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Jefferies, Lakestar, Maverick, Merus Capital, Morgan Stanley (MS), Natixis, Nomura (NMR), Societe Generale, UBS (UBS) and Wells Fargo (WFC).
Gurle said the company will increase its product-development team and hire sales and account management staff globally.
Symphony raised $66 million a year ago from a consortium of 15 financial institutions that included Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Blackrock, JPMorgan and others.

The support of so many Wall Street banks is important. Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan and other Wall Street banks pay for Bloomberg terminals for thousands of employees. A serious rival or complement could affect demand and pricing for Bloomberg data services.
The latest round of funding puts a $650 million valuation on Symphony, said Wall Street Journal sources last week.
Alphabet shares rose 0.8% to 676.43 in the stock market today.
JPMorgan earnings are due Tuesday night, followed by those of Wells Fargo, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup later this week.

There's strong demand showing for Tesla Motors ' (TSLA) new stock, even as its existing stock has wavered.
The luxury electric car maker said late Wednesday in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it expects net proceeds of $738.3 million from its stock offering that closed Wednesday.
It set up the stock issuance in order to step up the pace of car development, along with its charging network and battery factory.

Showing interest in the new shares, the Tesla SEC filing said that in addition to the sale of 2.7 million shares of Tesla stock, underwriters exercised in full their option to purchase an additional 404,239 shares. The underwriters for the offering are Goldman Sachs (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS) and the securities divisions of JPMorgan (JPM) and Deutsche Bank (DB).

The $738.3 million that Tesla expects to get is after deducting underwriting discounts and commissions and the cost of the offering. Tesla CEO Elon Musk has said he planned to buy $20 million of the new stock.
On Aug. 13, Tesla filed its plan with the SEC to offer 2.7 million shares at $242 a share.

Tesla stock fell 2.1% in the stock market today to 255.25 after rising the previous five trading days. Shares have fallen since mid-July and Tesla gets a Composite Rating of only 57 out of a possible 99 from IBD.

Worries about costs and competition have weighed on Tesla, which has been burning through cash to expand. Its capital expenditures hit $405 million in the second quarter, and it plans to invest $1.5 billion this year.
Follow Donna Howell on Twitter: @IBD_DHowell.

Goldman Sachs (GS) hiked the upper end of its legal loss provisions to $5.9 billion for 2015 as it negotiates settlements with federal and state officials concerning its sale of mortgage bonds prior to the worldwide financial crisis and Great Recession.Unlike the other big U.S. lenders, Goldman Sachs has yet to reach a multibillion-dollar accord with regulators. The top end of the New York-based bank's legal loss is 55% higher than the $3.8 billion it said it set aside in May. The legal loss hike was disclosed Monday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.During the second quarter, Goldman put aside $1.45 billion in legal provisions for a possible settlement related to residential mortgage-backed securities. The resolution of the government's allegations "may result in significant penalties and other costs," the bank said in the filing.Earlier this year, Morgan Stanley (MS) agreed to pay $2.6 billion to settle a federal investigation into its creation and sale of residential mortgage-backed securities. During the last several years, JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) each has paid billions of dollars to the state and federal governments to resolve similar allegations.Goldman shares fell 0.8% to 203.44 by early afternoon in the stock market today. Goldman Sachs stock is up about 5.5% so far this year, but is down 6.5% from a 52-week high it hit on June 23. The bank has traded below its 50-day moving average since July 24 and currently has an IBD Composite Rating of 76, meaning it trades better than 76% of other publicly traded companies' shares.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter: @IBD_CMcEvoy.

Morgan Stanley (MS), US Bancorp (USB) and JPMorgan (JPM) were down more than 1%.The sector is watching developments in the Greece debt crisis. Also, Reuters reported that Brazil is investigating several banks, including JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley, for rigging the Brazilian currency.Energy, automakers and utilities were the day's leaders in the stock market today. The Dow utilities average was up 1.2%, making them the day's winner.Yelp (YELP) swooned 12% in big volume after Bloomberg reported the company has temporarily halted plans to put itself up for sale. The consumer review website is trading at two-year lows and is 56% below its most recent price high.Cepheid (CPHD) dropped 5% in more than triple its usual volume. The molecular diagnostics company touched its 50-day moving average as it bottomed for the day. The stock is still working on a flat base with a 62.10 buy point.

Shares of generic drug maker Perrigo (PRGO) rose as much as 3.1% Tuesday after BMO Capital Markets launched coverage with an outperform rating, saying Perrigo stock is undervalued regardless of whether Mylan (MYL) succeeds in acquiring the company.
Analyst David Maris wrote that trends favor Perrigo's business model, which is divided between private-label over-the-counter and prescription generic drugs.

"The continued movement of consumers from national brands to store brand products and prescription to OTC switches, combined with increased health care costs and an aging population, will drive the global demand for store brands and OTC medications," he wrote.

Maris also said that since Perrigo is trying to resist an unsolicited bid from Mylan, it was likely especially careful with its guidance. "Given that if Perrigo misses estimates during an unsolicited bid period it might weaken its defense to an unwanted deal, we have to think Perrigo's guidance is on the conservative side," he wrote.
Maris admitted that if Mylan's bid fails, Perrigo's stock might fall in the short term, but he says fundamental growth eventually will make up for that loss.

He added that there's also potential upside if Biogen (BIIB) reports positive results from either or both of two trials of Tysabri, a multiple-sclerosis drug on which Biogen is paying Perrigo a royalty, thanks to Perrigo's acquisition of Elan.

The trials, both of which are due for readouts later this year, are testing Tysabri in secondary-progressive MS and in stroke prevention. Wall Street is not giving great odds of success to either, so added revenue from those indications is not in consensus expectations, he wrote.
Maris set a price target of 246 on the stock. In midday trading in the stock market today, Perrigo stock was near 188.50, up nearly 2%.
Follow Amy Reeves on Twitter: @IBD_Areeves.

With its battery Gigafactory under way, a new Tesla Energy division getting going and the Model X coming out soon, Tesla Motors (TSLA) is lining up financing sources.

The luxury electric car maker and its Netherlands subsidiary have entered into a senior secured asset-based revolving credit agreement of up to $500 million with a group of big banks, according to a new Tesla filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The banks are Deutsche Bank (DB), Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Morgan Stanley (MS), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Credit Suisse (CS), and the credit facility lasts through June 10, 2020.
"The proceeds of the loans under the Credit Agreement may be used for working capital and general corporate purposes," Tesla said in the SEC filing.
Tesla faces high capital expenditures this year with all the projects that it has under way.

"TSLA reiterated plans for FY15 capital expenditures approaching $1.5 bn, which includes $1 bn directed toward its existing production facility in Fremont, CA (new paint shop, new robotic assembly line and new tooling/die sets), $200 mm related to the Gigafactory (our sense is $50-100 mm was spent on the Gigafactory in 1Q15), and $200 mm related to stores, service centers and infrastructure expansion," Stifel analyst James Albertine said in a May research note recapping Q1.

"We do expect to be free cash flow positive in Q4," Tesla Chief Financial Officer Deepak Ahuja said on the carmaker's Q1 conference call in May. "And as we go along, clearly, we are optimizing for efficiency, which results in increase of our finished goods inventory. That makes sense for us to then establish some asset pipelines or credit which is backed by our finished goods inventory or raw materials. So we'll take those actions to make sure we have a solid balance sheet."
Tesla will be searching for a new CFO, as Ahuja will retire later this year.
Tesla stock touched a nearly seven-month high Monday and is up 38% from a 13-month low in March. It is forming a cup base with a buy point of 291.52.
The company gets a Composite Rating from IBD of 65 out of a possible 99 — not high but better than in recent months.
Follow Donna Howell on Twitter: @IBD_DHowell.

Five companies, including two e-commerce companies, are set to raise nearly $1 billion this week with IPOs. E-commerce technology provider Baozun plans to raise $143 million by offering 11 million shares at a price range of 12 to 14 per share.Baozun provides e-commerce services designed to help its brand partners establish a market presence and launch products on official brand stores and major online marketplaces in China, such as JD.com (JD) and Tmall, which is owned by Alibaba Group (BABA). With the offering, Alibaba will have an 18.2% stake in Baozun.Baozun's services encompass many aspects of e-commerce, including store operations, digital marketing, customer services, warehousing and fulfillment.Its customers include Microsoft (MSFT), Haagen-Dazs and Nike (NKE). Baozun said it processed $685.4 million in gross merchandise volume in 2014, up 62% from 2013. It reported revenue of $255.6 million in 2014 and a net loss of $9.6 million.The lead underwriters are Morgan Stanley (MS) and Credit Suisse. Baozun will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker BZUN, set to begin trading ThursdayThe other e-commerce initial public offeringset for this week is Shopify. The Ottawa, Ontario-based company plans to raise $100 million by offering 7.7 million shares at 12 to 14.Shopify provides a cloud-based e-commerce platform designed for small- and medium-size businesses. Merchants use its software to run their business across all of their sales channels, including web, tablet and mobile storefronts, social media storefronts, and brick-and-mortar retailers. Its competitors include Amazon (AMZN), Oracle (ORCL) and eBay (EBAY).In the first quarter, Shopify reported revenue of $37.3 million, up 98%, and a net loss of $4.5 million.The lead underwriters are Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse. Shopify will list on the NYSE under the ticker SHOP, set to begin trading Thursday.Black Knight Week's LargestThe largest IPO this week is Black Knight Financial Group, a provider of technology services, including data analytics, to the mortgage industry. The company plans to raise $400 million by offering 17 million shares at a range of 22 to 25.Black Knight said its customers include 21 of the 25 largest U.S. mortgage originators and all of the 25 largest U.S. mortgage servicers, among other financial institutions and real estate professionals.Black Knight is being spun off by Fidelity National Financial (FNF).The lead underwriters are JPMorgan (JPM) and BofA Merrill Lynch. Black Knight will list on the NYSE under the ticker BKFS, starting WednesdayAnother IPO this week is PGA Holdings, or Press Ganey, which provides patient survey and information services for health care organizations. The company says its mission is to help health care organizations reduce patient suffering and improve clinical quality, safety and the patient experience.It plans to raise $205 million by offering 8.9 million shares at 22 to 24. The lead underwriters are Barclays and Goldman Sachs (GS). PGA Holdings will list on the NYSE under the symbol PGND, and is scheduled to trade Thursday.Also on tap is Community Healthcare Trust, a real estate investment trust formed to acquire and own properties that are leased to hospitals, doctors, and health care service providers in non-urban markets. It plans to raise $125 million by offering 6.3 million shares at 19 to 21.The lead underwriters are Sandler O'Neill and Evercore Partners. Community Healthcare will list on the NYSE under the ticker CHCT, and it's set to begin trading Thursday.Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter: @IBD_BDeagon.

Best Mutual Funds 2015: April Performance Report

The country's top-performing stock mutual funds for the past three months have been adding tech issues to their portfolios recently. Computer software firms CyberArk Software (CYBR), Paycom Software (PAYC), Qualys (QLYS), Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Manhattan Associates (MANH) were strong performers.

Managers of leading stock mutual funds were also favoring chip stocks such as Ambarella (AMBA), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and Cirrus Logic (CRUS). As of Tuesday, chip design was ranked No. 3 among 197 industries, up from No. 8 six weeks ago.
A handful of giant medical stocks booked their spots in top funds' portfolios, including Mylan (MYL), United Therapeutics (UTHR), AmerisourceBergen (ABC) and Pharmacyclics (PCYC).
Leisure stock Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings (NCLH) also saw heavy buying among best-performing funds. Forty-three top funds have added the cruise liner, investing an estimated $493 million.

IBD spotted five leading stock mutual funds loading up on CyberArk Software, investing an estimated $12.8 million. The $3.5 billion Wells Fargo Advantage Discovery Fund added shares as of its latest reporting period.
The Israeli-based firm, which IPO'd in September, offers IT security solutions to protect organizations from cyberattacks.

Analysts believe CyberArk will capitalize on the growing need for internal and Internet security. The slew of company databases and client info being hacked in recent years has firms investing more of their budgets in preventative measures.
CyberArk has posted two straight quarters of solid earnings on accelerating double-digit revenue growth.
The stock skyrocketed out of a three-month-long consolidation in February to a high of 70.48. It's etching the handle part of a second stage cup-with-handle base, trading at 10% off its high.
Sell Side

Leading funds have been letting go of some financials such as payment processors Visa (V) and Euronet Worldwide (EEFT), in their latest reporting periods. Banks, such as City National (CYN), Morgan Stanley (MS) and SVB Financial Group (SIVB), have also been sold. Thirty-one net funds unloaded Martin Marietta Materials (MLM). The stock broke out of a flat base last Thursday.Best Mutual Funds 2015: April Performance ReportThe country's top-performing stock mutual funds for the past three months have been adding tech issues to their portfolios recently. Stocks bounced back Monday from Friday's selling, while the level of distribution in the market lightened a bit. Helped by strength in Internet stocks, the Nasdaq jumped 1.3%. It erased the bulk of Friday's loss and poked above the 5000 level before closing below it. The index found support at its 50-day moving average Friday, as it has since late…
After no IPOs last week, four initial public offerings are scheduled for the first week of June and are expected to raise a total of $552 million.

One energy company, two firms in the health care field and a retailer of specialty teas are in the new lineup. There were 17 initial public offerings in May that, combined, raised $4.4 billion, with health care accounting for eight of the offerings.

This week, Evolent Health plans to raise $150 million by selling 10 million shares at 14 to 16 a share. The company provides a software platform designed to help hospitals and health care companies improve the way patient care is delivered.
The Arlington, Va.-based company will list on the NYSE under the ticker EVH and begin trading Friday. JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) are the lead underwriters.
EndoChoice Holdings, a medical device company that designs and makes gastrointestinal endoscopy systems, plans to raise $100 million by offering 6.25 million shares at 15 to 17.
Based in Alpharetta, Ga., EndoChoice plans to list on the NYSE under the symbol GI and begin trading Friday. JPMorgan and Bank of America (BAC) are the lead underwriters.

The largest IPO this week is PennTex Midstream Partners, a limited partnership focused on owning, operating, acquiring and developing midstream energy infrastructure assets, with an initial focus in northern Louisiana. It has contract agreements with Memorial Resource Development (MRD).
PennTex plans to raise around $225 million by offering 11.3 million shares in the range of 19 to 21.
The Houston-based company will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker PTXP and looks to start trading Thursday. Citigroup (C)and Barclays are the lead underwriters.
Also this week is Canada-based DavidsTea, a specialty tea and tea accessory retailer based in Montreal. It operates 161 stores in Canada and the U.S.
DavidsTea plans to raise $77 million by offering 5.1 million shares at 14 to 16.
Competitors include Starbucks (SBUX), which acquired tea retailer Teavana in 2012.
DavidsTea will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker DTEA. The lead underwriters are Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan, with trading set to start Friday.
