Stock futures nosed higher ahead of Monday's open as earnings news contended with the effects of a rising dollar.
Dow futures rose 28.6 points above fair market value, nearly doubling their gain from an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 9.9 points, also rising. S&P 500 futures kept to a 1.9-point gain.

The stock market today rolls out with the Nasdaq fighting to hold fresh highs inked late last week, while the S&P 500 presses against resistance marked at its May 20 high. Stocks set sail under a fresh market status , a plus for investors.

Banks reopened today in Greece, hinting at more progress toward whatever the new normal might be there. And with earnings season continuing to look somewhat better than forecast, the easing of overseas tension allowed currency traders to focus more directly on a potential rate increase by the Federal Reserve later this year. That sent the dollar surging in early trade Monday and placed some downward pressure on U.S. stocks.
The economic calendar is blank today, but picks up with a steady stream of housing data beginning on Wednesday.
In aerospace, Lockheed Martin (LMT) and United Technologies (UTX) each rose 1% after news reports said Lockheed agreed to buy United Tech's Sikorsky helicopter unit for more than $8 billion.
The deal, one of Lockheed's largest since its $10 billion combination with Martin Marietta in 1995, will give Lockheed United Technologies' Black Hawk helicopter business.

Morgan Stanley (MS) topped the early earnings news, climbing 3% after its second-quarter sales and earnings topped analyst projections. Revenue from bonds and securities trading surged 25%, while investment banking revenue slipped 1%. The stock ended Friday in buying range on a rebound from 10-week support.

Halliburton (HAL) ticked up 2% after its revenue and earnings declined less than expected in Q2. Earnings fell 52% and revenue slipped 27% vs. expectations for declines of 67% and 28%, respectively. Revenue in North America fell 39%. Halliburton shares fell in 10 of the past 11 weeks after a stalled attempt to climb out of a deep, 12-month consolidation.

The morning's injured list showed Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) down 8%, but paring some early losses. The Mississippi-based egg producer and distributor's fiscal Q4 revenue and earnings stopped well short of analyst expectations.

The company, focused primarily in Southern and Eastern markets, was widely seen by investors as missing many of the negative effects of the avian flu affecting much of the industry, while benefiting from the corresponding increase in egg prices. The stock ended Friday in a flattish consolidation, testing 10-week support below a May high.
Overseas, Europe's leading indexes sketched out moderate gains near midday. China's markets posted a narrowly mixed close, with Shanghai up, Hong Kong down. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 added 0.9%.

Gold fell nearly 2%, trading below $1,112 an ounce and at its lowest level since early 2010. Oil prices slipped a few pennies, with West Texas Intermediate trading near $50 a barrel. As the world waited over the weekend - the fate of Greece continues to hang in the balance as investors/traders worry about the fall out. Negotiations dragged on and on and the fear continues to build as Greece 'circles the drain'…. The possibility of defaulting on payments to the IMF (International Monetary Fund) and the ECB (European Central Bank) caused…
Glu Mobile (GLUU) continues to mine the celebrity-themed video game niche that it created with "Kim Kardashian: Hollywood" by signing pop singer Britney Spears for a similar game.

Glu stock jumped as much as 27% on the stock market today, a day after the company reported better-than-expected first-quarter results and announced a strategic investment by Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) and a partnership with Spears. In afternoon trading Thursday, Glu stock was up 22%, near 6.60.

For the March quarter, Glu earned 2 cents a share excluding items on sales of $62.4 million. Analysts were expecting a per-share loss of a penny on sales of $51.6 million. Sales were up 33% year over year. Earnings were down 67% from 6 cents a share in the year-earlier quarter.

"The outperformance during the first quarter was driven by the ongoing traction of 'Kim Kardashian: Hollywood,' 'Racing Rivals,' 'Deer Hunter 2014,' and 'Contract Killer: Sniper,'" Glu CEO Niccolo de Masi said in a statement.

Glu, a leading publisher of games for smartphone and tablets, also raised its full-year guidance. The San Francisco-based company now expects to earn 22 cents a share excluding items on adjusted sales of $275 million at the midpoint of guidance.
For the June quarter, Glu expects a per-share loss of 4 cents excluding items on adjusted sales of $51 million at the midpoint of guidance.
Tencent Buying Stake

Late Wednesday, Glu announced that Chinese messaging and games giant Tencent had agreed to buy 21 million shares of Glu's common stock for $6 per share, for total of $126 million. Once the deal is complete, Tencent will own 14.6% of Glu.

"Tencent was attracted to Glu due to its five-year growth track record, high-quality entrepreneurial management and unique approach to methodically building a portfolio of success in the shooter, action (role-playing game), narrative-RPG, time-management, sports and racing genres," Steven Ma, head of Tencent's Interactive Entertainment Group, said in a statement. "Collaboration between our companies will enable Glu to tailor its games more powerfully by tapping Tencent's strength in online, social and MMO capabilities."
Tencent owns Riot Games, maker of "League of Legends," and holds a stake in Activision (ATVI).

Glu also announced late Wednesday that it has signed Spears to its celebrity roster. Glu plans to develop a new mobile game featuring Spears to be launched worldwide in the first half of 2016. The exclusive agreement spans five years with the possibility of a three-year extension.

"Featuring the voice, likeness and creative influence of Ms. Spears, the game will allow players to interact with Britney and experience the glitz and glamour of the entertainment business," Glu said in a press release.
Spears joins Kardashian, as well as singer Katy Perry and reality-TV stars Kylie and Kendall Jenner, in Glu's fast-growing celebrity stable.
RELATED:
Kendall and Kylie Jenner video game could break seventh seal

The volatile stock market and heavier trading volumes should translate into a good first quarter for Goldman Sachs (GS), which also should receive a boost from its financial advisory unit thanks to Q1's strong M&A activity.

When it reports results on Thursday, the investment bank is expected to earn $4.23 a share, up 5.2% from a year ago, while revenue is expected to rise 0.1% to $9.34 billion, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.

Goldman's fixed income currency and commodities unit makes up a significant portion of its overall revenue. The stock market's Q1 gyrations, though a headache for some investors, should pay off for Goldman's bankers.
The S&P 500 fell 3.1% in January, rose 5.5% in February and fell 1.7% in March.
"If the volatility and the volumes were strong in the quarter, that should lead to a strong quarter for Goldman," said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets.

Robust merger-and-acquisition activity in Q1 also bodes well for Goldman, which is expected to see a boost in the advisory fees that it charges clients. Analysts at Barclays have forecast a 17% year-over-year increase in financial advisory revenue.

Goldman advised United Kingdom-based natural gas company BG Group in a $69.6 billion megadeal with Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA). Previously, it advised NPS Pharmaceuticals during its acquisition by Ireland-based drug maker Shire (SHPG) in a $5.2 billion deal announced in January.
The bank has held the position of No. 1 investment bank for M&A since 2011, according to Dealogic. So far this year, it has advised on over 90 deals worth more than $200 billion.
"Although deal numbers are expected to be down (year over year), we look for advisory fees to increase due to bigger deal size," Barclays analysts wrote in an April 10 research note.
Still in the works is a possible settlement of a Justice Department probe into alleged rigging of foreign currency markets by Goldman and other banks.
"Everybody has to settle with the DOJ, which could happen as soon as this month for some of these guys," Cassidy said.

Rival Morgan Stanley (MS) reports its results April 20, but investors will get a peek at Q1 investment banking results on Tuesday when JPMorgan Chase (JPM) reports. A sharp reduction in legal costs and strong mortgage growth weren't enough to help Bank of America (BAC) meet Wall Street's first-quarter expectations despite posting a nice profit.

The Charlotte, N.C.-based lender earned $3.36 billion, or 27 cents a share, a 32-cent turnaround from Q1 '14 but missing analyst estimates by 2 cents. The bank posted a net loss of $246 million a year earlier. Revenue fell 5.9% to $21.42 billion, missing views of $21.51 billion.

BofA missed estimates despite analyst expectations that it would do well because of easy comparisons to the first quarter of 2014, when it reported a 5-cent loss per share on a $6 billion litigation charge stemming from mortgage-related settlements.

Overall, Q1 costs declined 29% year to year to $15.7 billion, with legal expenses plunging 94% to $370 million. BofA, which paid $16.65 billion last year to settle a Justice Department probe into alleged wrongdoing related to mortgage-backed securities, has said the bulk of its financial crisis-related legal woes are behind it.

Bank of America said its revenue slide was due to $211 million in market-related adjustments on its debt securities portfolio as a result of low long-term interest rates. A $757 million drop in equity investment income included a gain on a partial sale of an investment.
The bank's net interest margin — the spread between what it pays on deposits and what it makes on loans and other interest-earning assets — slipped 12 basis points to 2.17%.
Having struggled to pass the Federal Reserve stress test that concluded last month, the bank said it expects $100 million in additional costs related to the test process.
It originated $13.7 billion in mortgages in Q1, a 55% increase from a year earlier.
Client brokerage assets grew 18% to $18.3 billion.

Trading revenues dropped 5% from Q1 '14 to $3.9 billion, lagging peers such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which reported Q1 earnings on Tuesday. Wells Fargo (WFC) also reported its first-quarter results Tuesday.

Fixed-income currency and commodities trading fell 7% from Q1 '14 to $2.75 billion, but the drop was partially offset by strong foreign exchange currency results stemming from increased market volatility.
Total assets at March 31 were $2.14 trillion, down 0.3% from a year earlier.

Shares fell 0.9% to 15.68 by early afternoon trading in the stock market today. The bank's shares have fallen 11.6% so far this year. BofA currently maintains an IBD Composite Rating of 42, meaning its shares are outperformed by 58% of other publicly traded businesses. The stock is trading below both its 50- and 200-day moving averages.

Earnings season continues Thursday for big banks, with Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS) reporting their quarterly results. Biogen missed Wall Street's Q1 estimates Friday as its multiple-sclerosis drug Tecfidera ran into unexpected headwinds, sending its stock to a two-month low. Earnings excluding one-time items rose 55% vs. a year earlier to $3.82 a share, 9 cents short of analysts' consensus. Sales rose 20% to $2.6 billion, about $100 million below estimates.
Biogen (BIIB) stock fell as much as 8% to 395, its lowest since Feb. 17. It closed down 6.6% at 401.71.

The shortfall was mainly due to Tecfidera, the oral MS treatment that launched in 2013. Its sales of $825 million were $110 million below the consensus and 10% below Q4 sales. On the conference call with analysts, Biogen executives said that they'd expected some slowdown due to fewer shipping weeks and some Medicare doughnut-hole issues, but this result was worse than expected.

"We saw moderating patient uptake in our oral MS therapy Tecfidera in the U.S. and Germany, and like some other companies we had foreign-exchange headwinds," said CEO George Scangos. "Our MS franchise continued to gain overall share this quarter, but at a moderating pace."

Scangos said that a case of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a brain infection, reported in a Tecfidera user in October seems to have dampened enthusiasm. PML had been linked to Tecfidera's ingredients before, and the CEO said that while physicians don't seem to have changed their view of the risks, they're reporting more hesitancy among patients.

There was also cannibalizing of Tecfidera sales by Plegridy, a long-acting form of Biogen's older MS drug Avonex, which launched last year. But Plegridy's U.S. sales also missed forecasts, underlining the point that the MS market overall was slow.
On Thursday, Novartis (NVS) reported that sales of Tecfidera's chief rival, Gilenya, also were light, though the miss was much narrower: $638 million vs. the consensus $652 million.
Alzheimer's Update

Biogen also offered updates on aducanumab, the Alzheimer's disease treatment whose phase one results wowed observers last month. On the call, R&D head Douglas Williams said that the phase three study getting underway this year will involve two trials, each involving 1,350 patients with early forms of the disease and two different doses that he did not reveal.

Williams also said that the phase one trial is continuing. Biogen will release new data on the 6 milligram dose in July and on the 10 mg titration dose next year, he said. That is somewhat later than Wall Street expected, according to Evercore ISI analyst Mark Schoenebaum.

"Many investors are concerned that, given the 10 mg titration delay, the major 2015 catalyst has now been moved to 2016," he wrote to clients. "And many investors are not terribly excited about the 6 mg dose data ... because: (1) we already know that ARIA (amyloid-related imaging abnormalities, an adverse side effect) rates in that cohort are relatively high, and (2) the 6 month efficacy data looked similar to placebo."Biogen missed Wall Street's Q1 estimates Friday as its multiple-sclerosis drug Tecfidera ran into unexpected headwinds, sending its stock to a two-month low. Earnings excluding one-time items rose 55% vs. a year earlier to $3.82 a share, 9 cents short of analysts' consensus. Sales rose 20% to $2.6 billion, about $100 million below estimates.Biogen (BIIB) stock fell as much as 8% to 395, its lowest since Feb. 17. It closed down 6.6% at 401.71.The shortfall was mainly due to Tecfidera, the oral MS treatment that launched in 2013. Its sales of $825 million were $110 million below the consensus and 10% below Q4 sales. On the conference call with analysts, Biogen executives said that they'd expected some slowdown due to fewer shipping weeks and some Medicare doughnut-hole issues, but this result was worse than expected."We saw moderating patient uptake in our oral MS therapy Tecfidera in the U.S. and Germany, and like some other companies we had foreign-exchange headwinds," said CEO George Scangos. "Our MS franchise continued to gain overall share this quarter, but at a moderating pace."Scangos said that a case of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a brain infection, reported in a Tecfidera user in October seems to have dampened enthusiasm. PML had been linked to Tecfidera's ingredients before, and the CEO said that while physicians don't seem to have changed their view of the risks, they're reporting more hesitancy among patients.There was also cannibalizing of Tecfidera sales by Plegridy, a long-acting form of Biogen's older MS drug Avonex, which launched last year. But Plegridy's U.S. sales also missed forecasts, underlining the point that the MS market overall was slow.On Thursday, Novartis (NVS) reported that sales of Tecfidera's chief rival, Gilenya, also were light, though the miss was much narrower: $638 million vs. the consensus $652 million.Alzheimer's UpdateBiogen also offered updates on aducanumab, the Alzheimer's disease treatment whose phase one results wowed observers last month. On the call, R&D head Douglas Williams said that the phase three study getting underway this year will involve two trials, each involving 1,350 patients with early forms of the disease and two different doses that he did not reveal.Williams also said that the phase one trial is continuing. Biogen will release new data on the 6 milligram dose in July and on the 10 mg titration dose next year, he said. That is somewhat later than Wall Street expected, according to Evercore ISI analyst Mark Schoenebaum."Many investors are concerned that, given the 10 mg titration delay, the major 2015 catalyst has now been moved to 2016," he wrote to clients. "And many investors are not terribly excited about the 6 mg dose data ... because: (1) we already know that ARIA (amyloid-related imaging abnormalities, an adverse side effect) rates in that cohort are relatively high, and (2) the 6 month efficacy data looked similar to placebo."

Stronger trading revenue and loan growth boosted JPMorgan Chase (JPM) to a solid first-quarter performance, but squeezed net interest margins gave investors some pause over Wells Fargo (WFC). JPMorgan, the nation's largest bank, earned $5.91 billion, or $1.45 a share, up 3.6% from a year earlier, beating by 5 cents estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue grew 4%…
Goldman Sachs (GS) crushed Wall Street's first-quarter expectations, as stock market volatility fueled trading revenue and a string of megadeals boosted advisory fees.

The investment banking giant earned $5.94 a share, up 47.8% from a year earlier and crushing the $4.26 forecast by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue surged 13.8% to $10.6 billion, easily beating estimates of $9.4 billion.

It was the best quarterly profit in five years for Goldman Sachs. Trading revenue soared 23% to $5.46 billion, thanks to signs the Federal Reserve will tighten monetary policy, the Swiss central bank's surprise move to lift a cap on the franc, and the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program.
Shares were down less than 0.1% on the stock market today.
Goldman Sachs "posted a much better quarter than expected," wrote Jason Goldberg, a Barclays analyst.
Net revenues in its financial advisory unit jumped 41% to $961 million, boosted by higher client activity. Goldman was involved in some of the biggest deals so far this year.

It advised United Kingdom-based natural gas company BG Group in its acquisition worth nearly $70 billion with Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA). Previously, it advised NPS Pharmaceuticals when it was acquired by Ireland-based drug maker Shire (SHPG) in a $5.2 billion deal announced in January. So far this year, the bank has advised on more than 90 deals worth more than $200 billion.

Fixed income, currency and commodities revenue rose 10% to $3.13 billion, spurred on by higher volatility levels in the markets. Equities net revenues soared 46% to $2.33 billion. Assets under management rose 8% to $1.03 trillion.
Higher revenue from interest rate products and trading currencies was offset in part by lower revenue from mortgages, commodities and credit products, the bank said.
Operating expenses rose 6% year over year to $6.7 billion, which was 49% higher than Q4 of 2014.

With JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) already having reported Q1 earnings, Morgan Stanley (MS) is the last of the nation's six largest banks to report quarterly results. Politics: So now Hillary Clinton, champion of the middle class, says she wants to "reshuffle" a deck stacked in favor of the rich and "topple" the wealthiest 1% — the latest grenade launch in her class-warfare campaign.
'There's something wrong," the former secretary of state declared last week in Iowa, "when CEOs make 300 times more than the American worker."

This from a woman who makes more in an hour on the speaker circuit (her fee is about $200,000 per speech) than the average worker who waits on the tables at her fundraising galas makes in three years. A sweet deal if you can get it.

But now the fact-checkers are finding that her story of CEO riches is full of holes. Yes, the average CEO of a Fortune 400 company makes about $10 million to $20 million a year in compensation, depending on the measure.

But these are the world's top corporate executives, making decisions that will affect the livelihoods of often tens of thousands of workers, hundreds of thousands of middle-class shareholders and sometimes millions of consumers.

Fred Smith, founder and CEO of FedEx, has become a multibillionaire. He has also created one of the world's most profitable and revered businesses, with hundreds of thousands of employees in mostly high-paying jobs.
Does any reasonable person begrudge him his financial success? He has gotten rich by making our economy and workers richer. This isn't a zero-sum game, Ms. Clinton.

But Smith is an exception. As are most of the other top 399 CEOs whom Hillary has pilloried. It would be like saying that the average basketball player earns $50 million a year, because that's what LeBron James makes.

Mark Perry of the American Enterprise Institute, a frequent contributor to these pages, has pointed out that there aren't just 400 CEOs in America. His research shows that in 2013, the average pay for America's 248,760 chief executives was only $178,400.
"This larger sample of almost a quarter-million CEOs reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics gives us a much better understanding of average CEO compensation," Perry says.

So in her tirade, Hillary referred only to the tiny sample of CEOs she hangs out with — and often shakes down for money. The other 99% earn about 2% of the salary she's using. An average CEO makes closer to five times what an average worker makes, not 300 times.

Other studies have found that CEO pay in most big companies is so tiny compared to the entire cost structure that even if the executives were paid nothing, and the savings were passed on to the workers, it would mean at most a few pennies an hour.
In other words, CEO pay has nothing to do with average worker pay.

Granted, many public company CEOs are overpaid — especially in cases when the stock price is falling. And golden parachutes for failed executives and other oversized compensation schemes happen too often.
But these abuses should be corrected by shareholders and boards of directors, not busybody politicians like Hillary Clinton.
Ours is a free-market economy that rewards excellence, entrepreneurship and hard work. Clinton seems to have decided that the goal in America is to make rich people poor and not vice versa.

When we start storming the Bastille in order to "topple" the rich, we don't make anyone better off. We only destroy the free-enterprise system that makes achieving the American dream of becoming rich possible in the first place.Politics: So now Hillary Clinton, champion of the middle class, says she wants to "reshuffle" a deck stacked in favor of the rich and "topple" the wealthiest 1% — the latest grenade launch in her class-warfare campaign.'There's something wrong," the former secretary of state declared last week in Iowa, "when CEOs make 300 times more than the American worker."This from a woman who makes more in an hour on the speaker circuit (her fee is about $200,000 per speech) than the average worker who waits on the tables at her fundraising galas makes in three years. It's been about 23 years now since Hillary Clinton as part of her climb to power put down
stay-at-home moms in favor of those out in the workplace. A lot of those women
are now involuntarily out of the job market because of the policies of

the Obama administration Clinton is close to.Hillary Clinton has made a career out of wanting to be president of the United States. But in all this elapsed time she's never been able or bothered to explain Why she wants the nation's highest office.The Clintons clearly feel entitled to many things. One of them should not be the Oval Office. (Scroll down for video of 'Saturday Night Live's' searing, hilarious parody of Clinton's announcement.)Now that Hillary is officially in the race for the Democrat nomination and, according to party polls, dominating the vacant field, the 67-year-old ex-first lady has a final opportunity to explain her vision, where she wants to take the country that currently believes nearly two-to-one that America is on the wrong track with Obama.Sunday was not the best day for Hillary Clinton to launch her bid. It was the 16th anniversary of a Federal judge holding hubby Bill in contempt for misleading her about his sexual relationship with that woman, Ms. Lewinsky. A reminder of the tawdry scandals, stonewallings and ethical controversies that seem attracted to the Clintons like swarming barnyard insects.And it's not the best position for Hillary Clinton to credibly argue that her lackluster State Department tenure, including the deadly, avoidable Benghazi incident, qualifies her to be commander-in-chief. "Does America want a third Obama term?” Ted Cruz asked needlessly.Then as always there's history: Since FDR in 1944, U.S. voters have given the same party three consecutive White House terms only once, 1988 when Vice President George H.W. Bush won, in effect, a third Reagan term. But Reagan was popular, 57% approval. Obama not so much (46%).“It’s hard for any party to hang on to the White House for 12 years,” recently noted Hillary's husband, whose two-term legacy was inadequate to boost his own vice president to victory in 2000.In her day-before-the-announcement announcement video Clinton explained: "Everyday Americans need a champion, and I want to be that champion.” Again with the "want."In not the best choice of talking points, reminding Americans of the worst economic recovery since World War II, the ex-Obama cabinet member said: "Americans have fought their way back from tough economic times" under Obama.Then, the woman who claimed to be "dead broke" with two mansions who's been demanding $300,000 plus a crudite assortment for every speech, added: "But the deck is still stacked in favor of those at the top.” Do ya think? And which millionaires would that be?Clinton has a clear path to her party's nomination in Philadelphia 15 months from now. Martin O'Malley and Jim Webb are political nobodies building resumes for speaking fees and possible future runs somewhere. That will save her much of the $1.7 billion money she could raise from "those at the top." But it will not hone her clumsy campaign skills.We know that Elizabeth Warren, who's much more in tune ideologically with the party's activist base, is not running. She's said it so many times, many now doubt her sincerity. The Ready for Warren draft crowd, however, was ready for Hillary Sunday. Said Manager Erica Sagrans:"We look forward to Hillary Clinton and other candidates laying out their platforms and hearing whether they embrace the fights that Senator Warren has spent her life leading -- from taking on Wall Street to ending skyrocketing income inequality so that working families get a fighting chance."To show how in-touch she is with "everyday Americans," Clinton plans an immediate "listening tour" to New Hampshire and Iowa this week, the kind of tour she made in 1993 for her doomed healthcare plan. We'll see if Clinton's staff plants favorable questions among audience members, as it did in Iowa in 2007.Clinton must fake sincerity much better than in the past. After her illegal email deletions and foundation fundraising while in office, polls show a majority now deem her untrustworthy and inauthentic.She's got roughly five months to show her party's big money moguls on the coasts that she's found her voice again. It's the politics of winning. They're totally committed to her until they're not.Like the Bushes, Clinton has a strong national fundraising operation intact. And after the first black president, maybe Americans will buy a proclaimed historical need for the first female president. On Clinton's side, she also has her husband, though he's a simultaneous liability.Another awkward liability Republicans already point out is her close relationship with Obama. And as the email deletion scandal shows, the likelihood of some other ethical eruptions that require misleading explanations and half-truths.Next up today, on the GOP side Marco Rubio reveals his political decision about a 2016 campaign -- for the Senate or White House.RELATED:Can Hillary's hopes survive Benghazi?Has the media finally turned on the Clintons?Hillary's email scandal brings her more 🙁 poll news

Stock futures added to early gains ahead of Thursday's starting bell after a positive reading on weekly unemployment claims.Dow futures jumped 88.6 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures powered up 16 points, while S&P 500 futures were 8.9 points higher.
Stock Market Today

A positive premarket session means little to the stock market today , however, making them a key factor to watch through the end of the week. The Nasdaq ended Wednesday down 1.6% and the S&P 500 down 1.5% so far for the week.
Economic News

Jobless claims fell 19% to 289,000 in the week ended March 7, the Labor Department reported. That sharply undercut expectations for a mild decline to 309,000 claims. The prior week's estimate was revised upward to 325,000. The four-week moving average shifted lower, its first decline in three weeks.

The Commerce Department reported that retail sales slipped 0.6% in February, better than January's 0.8% drop but well below forecasts for a 0.3% gain. Minus auto sales, sales were down 0.1% vs. a 0.9% drop in January. Economists projected a 0.5% gain.

Later this morning, the Commerce Department reports January business inventories at 10 a.m. ET. The Energy Information Administration gives weekly natural gas storage estimates at 10:30. The Treasury Department delivers its February budget figures at 2 p.m.
Stocks
Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) zoomed up 6% in premarket trade, while Shake Shack (SHAK) shed 6%. Both eateries announced fourth-quarter results after Wednesday's close.
Zoe's closed Wednesday 9% below a 35.75 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Shake Shack is in the seventh week of an IPO base, ending Wednesday 123% above its January initial offering price.

Krispy Kreme Doughnuts (KKD) crumbled 9% before the open. The home of the doughnut-bacon-hot dog late Wednesday reported Q4 earnings that narrowly beat forecasts, but revenue missed. Shares have been climbing since August, building the right side of a 16-month correction.

Morgan Stanley (MS) and Citigroup (C) jumped 3% each. Both banks hoisted their dividends and announced massive share buyback initiatives after passing the Federal Reserve's annual stress test requirements. Deutsche Bank (DB) and Banco Santander (SAN) rose 0.6% and 1.6%, respectively, despite the Fed halting their dividend and buyback plans after both received non-passing grades.
Overseas
Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index crept up 0.3%, while the Shanghai Composite vaulted 1.8%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 also jumped, up 1.4%. Europe's markets were mildly mixed near midday.
Currencies/Commodities

The dollar eased a tad vs. the euro and slipped against the yen. Oil prices bounced about 1%, with benchmarks holding near recent lows. Gold bumped up nearly 1% to above $1,158 an ounce. Financial exchange traded funds rallied late last week after 28 of the 31 largest U.S. banks passed the latest Fed stress tests and got approval to boost dividends and buybacks. The results buoyed ETF investors' hopes that the banking sector is stronger than ever since the 2008 fiscal crisis. "Capital levels are high and growing," Todd Rosenbluth, director of fund…

Now the real stress begins. Round 2 results of the Federal Reserve's stress tests for banks are scheduled for release Wednesday, and some big banks that passed last week could find themselves getting the stink eye from regulators this week.

The Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) tests the nation's 31 largest banks, including seven foreign-owned lenders, on their plans to return capital to investors via dividend payouts, share buybacks and major acquisitions or sales in the event of a severe recession.
It's regulators' most high-profile method of keeping banks in check after the financial crisis and taxpayer bailouts that ensued.

Overall, Barclays analysts wrote in a research note that they expect payout ratios to increase to 79% this year compared with 65% in last year's CCAR. Dividend payouts should be below historical averages (28% vs. 41%) while share repurchases should be above the historic norms (53% vs. 39%), Barclays analysts said.
"We ... look for most (banks) to continue or increase their share repurchase activity (this year)," Barclays noted.

Last week, all 31 banks passed the Dodd-Frank Act Stress Test (DFAST), which showed they all met minimum capital ratio requirements in the hypothetical situation that the unemployment rate hits 10%, stocks plunge and the housing market declines 25%.

But passing Round 1 — even with flying colors — does not mean getting through Round 2 is assured. Last year, Citigroup (C) passed the first round, only to stumble when the Fed rejected its investor payout plan, citing its concern with the New York-based bank's ability to foresee losses in "material parts of its global operations."

Since that time, Citi has sold off its OneMain Financial unit for personal loans to Springleaf Holdings (LEAF) for $4.25 billion in cash. It also said it will pull its retail banking business out of 11 markets — mostly in Central and South America — as well as leave the consumer banking markets of Japan, Egypt, the Czech Republic and elsewhere.

With CEO Michael Corbat and CFO John Gerspach's jobs reportedly on the line, at least one analyst thinks Citi's senior management will lean on the side of conservatism when it comes to putting forth its capital return plan.

"I think they're going to be fine because they've had a full year to go back and address the things the Fed was concerned with," said Jeff Harte, an analyst at Sandler O'Neill & Partners. "Getting approved for $7 billion (in investor paybacks) would be good news."

Bank of America (BAC) passed Round 1, but memories remain of its bungled CCAR submission last year that led the Charlotte, N.C.-based lender to abandon a 5-cent dividend payout. As a result, the Fed could be tougher on it in terms of analyzing its payouts.
"They're one where I'm a little more cautious that a qualitative issue could prove a disappointment," Harte said.

Goldman Sachs (GS) underwhelmed at the DFAST level by posting a minimum total risk-based capital ratio of 8.1%, compared to the 8% minimum, but its 6.3% Tier 1 common capital ratio, which gauges high-quality capital as a percentage of risk-weighted assets, bested the 5% minimum.
After last year's exams, the New York-based bank responded by cutting its total assets by $55 billion from a year earlier to $856 billion as of Dec. 31, 2014.
"The total capital is easier to rectify than common equity," Harte said. "We think they'll have a pretty good buyback."

Morgan Stanley (MS) reached a $2.6 billion residential mortgage-backed securities settlement with the Department of Justice last month and the deal wiped out about half a year's worth of earnings. That could result in the Fed demanding more conservative capital plans, Harte noted.
JPMorgan Chase (JPM), the nation's largest bank, has the highest capital requirements and is expected to pass CCAR. Wells Fargo (WFC) too is expected to get a Round 2 passing grade.
Given all the rigorous testing, perhaps it could be argued that the Fed, which was accused of lax regulation pre-financial crisis, has overlearned the crisis' lessons.

"Over the next couple of years, we're going to be looking at massively overcapitalized banks under any scenario unless they're allowed to return more capital to shareholders," Harte said.Now the real stress begins. Round 2 results of the Federal Reserve's stress tests for banks are scheduled for release Wednesday, and some big banks that passed last week could find themselves getting the stink eye from regulators this week.The Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) tests the nation's 31 largest banks, including seven foreign-owned lenders, on their plans to return capital to investors via dividend payouts, share buybacks and major acquisitions or sales in the event of a severe recession.It's regulators' most high-profile method of keeping banks in check after the financial crisis and taxpayer bailouts that ensued.Overall, Barclays analysts wrote in a research note that they expect payout ratios to increase to 79% this year compared with 65% in last year's CCAR. Dividend payouts should be below historical averages (28% vs. 41%) while share repurchases should be above the historic norms (53% vs. 39%), Barclays analysts said."We ... look for most (banks) to continue or increase their share repurchase activity (this year)," Barclays noted.Last week, all 31 banks passed the Dodd-Frank Act Stress Test (DFAST), which showed they all met minimum capital ratio requirements in the hypothetical situation that the unemployment rate hits 10%, stocks plunge and the housing market declines 25%.But passing Round 1 — even with flying colors — does not mean getting through Round 2 is assured. Last year, Citigroup (C) passed the first round, only to stumble when the Fed rejected its investor payout plan, citing its concern with the New York-based bank's ability to foresee losses in "material parts of its global operations."Since that time, Citi has sold off its OneMain Financial unit for personal loans to Springleaf Holdings (LEAF) for $4.25 billion in cash. It also said it will pull its retail banking business out of 11 markets — mostly in Central and South America — as well as leave the consumer banking markets of Japan, Egypt, the Czech Republic and elsewhere.With CEO Michael Corbat and CFO John Gerspach's jobs reportedly on the line, at least one analyst thinks Citi's senior management will lean on the side of conservatism when it comes to putting forth its capital return plan."I think they're going to be fine because they've had a full year to go back and address the things the Fed was concerned with," said Jeff Harte, an analyst at Sandler O'Neill & Partners. "Getting approved for $7 billion (in investor paybacks) would be good news."Bank of America (BAC) passed Round 1, but memories remain of its bungled CCAR submission last year that led the Charlotte, N.C.-based lender to abandon a 5-cent dividend payout. As a result, the Fed could be tougher on it in terms of analyzing its payouts."They're one where I'm a little more cautious that a qualitative issue could prove a disappointment," Harte said.Goldman Sachs (GS) underwhelmed at the DFAST level by posting a minimum total risk-based capital ratio of 8.1%, compared to the 8% minimum, but its 6.3% Tier 1 common capital ratio, which gauges high-quality capital as a percentage of risk-weighted assets, bested the 5% minimum.After last year's exams, the New York-based bank responded by cutting its total assets by $55 billion from a year earlier to $856 billion as of Dec. 31, 2014."The total capital is easier to rectify than common equity," Harte said. "We think they'll have a pretty good buyback."Morgan Stanley (MS) reached a $2.6 billion residential mortgage-backed securities settlement with the Department of Justice last month and the deal wiped out about half a year's worth of earnings. That could result in the Fed demanding more conservative capital plans, Harte noted.JPMorgan Chase (JPM), the nation's largest bank, has the highest capital requirements and is expected to pass CCAR. Wells Fargo (WFC) too is expected to get a Round 2 passing grade.Given all the rigorous testing, perhaps it could be argued that the Fed, which was accused of lax regulation pre-financial crisis, has overlearned the crisis' lessons."Over the next couple of years, we're going to be looking at massively overcapitalized banks under any scenario unless they're allowed to return more capital to shareholders," Harte said.

All but three of the 31 big banks examined by the Federal Reserve won approval of any plans to return capital to investors in the second round of annual stress tests. In other words: more payouts for shareholders.

The U.S. units of Spain's Banco Santander (SAN) and Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB) failed round 2 of the Fed's stress tests, while the Fed ordered Bank of America  (BAC) to resubmit its capital plan by the end of the third quarter.
It's the second straight year Santander failed the test. And the Fed cited "numerous and significant deficiencies" in Deutsche Bank's capital planning.
Meanwhile, Wells Fargo (WFC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) boosted their dividends and Morgan approved a new buyback plan, joining other banks that received the Fed's OK of their capital plans.
Shares of BofA fell 1% late, while Morgan Stanley rose 2% and Wells Fargo edged up 0.1%.

The second round of the exams — the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) — is more stringent than round one, the Dodd-Frank Act Stress Tests (DFAST), because it examines banks' abilities to pay dividends, buy back shares and still serve borrowers during times of severe economic distress.

This year, the Fed examined 31 banks, each with assets exceeding $50 billion. All 31 banks passed DFAST last week, which means they met the Fed's minimum capital requirements. It was the first time they all passed since the test's 2009 inception.
A More Likely Place To Trip

Round 2 is where banks are more likely to stumble. Michael Corbat, the CEO of Citigroup (C), should be breathing easier, since the New York-based lender passed this year's tests after failing two out of the last three years. Last year's failure resulted in Citi's selling overseas branches as well as selling its consumer finance unit, OneMain Financial, for $4.25 billion.

This is the first year Citigroup will be able to boost its dividend since the financial crisis. Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach's jobs reportedly were on the line during this year's stress tests. Citi's passage comes as a big win for them. Citi shares rose 3.7% in after-hours trading.
HSBC (HSBC) and Zions Bancorp (ZION) failed last year's CCAR but passed this year's exam.
Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Morgan Stanley met minimum capital requirements on a post-test basis after submitting adjustments.

"This is becoming less and less an adversarial process between the organizations," said Ernest Patrikis, a former New York Fed official now with the White & Case law firm. "I think for the banking system as a whole, we should feel a bit better."
Musing Over Board Control

While CCAR has become the key test of banks' health since the Great Recession, Patrikis said he'd like to see the day when a bank's board — not the Fed — again has the power to return money to owners. "Banks should be allowed to have more freedom to raise dividends," he said.

In addition to the banks listed above, the Federal Reserve had no objections to the plans of Ally Financial (ALLY), American Express (AXP), Bank of New York Mellon (BK), BB&T (BBT), BBVA Compass (BBVA), Bank of Montreal Quebec (BMO), Capital One Financial (COF), Citizens Financial Group (CFG), Comerica (CMA), Discover Financial Services (DFS), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB), Huntington Bancshares (HBAN), Keycorp (KEY), M&T Bank (MTB), MUFG Americas Holdings (MTU), Northern Trust (NTRS), PNC Financial Services (PNC), Regions Financial (RF), State Street (STT), SunTrust Banks (STI) and U.S. Bancorp (USB).All but three of the 31 big banks examined by the Federal Reserve won approval of any plans to return capital to investors in the second round of annual stress tests. GoDaddy plans to raise $396 million in an initial public offering that places a $3 billion valuation on the Web-hosting company. Known for its racy commercials staring Nascar race car drive Danica Patrick, GoDaddy provides domain-name registration and website-hosting services.It plans to offer 22 million shares at 17 to 19 per share.GoDaddy reported revenue of $1.39 billion in 2014, up 23%. It reported a net loss of $143 million, compared with a $200 million loss in 2013.The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company, founded in 1997, says it has 13 million customers.Company plans to go public in 2006 flopped. In December 2011, GoDaddy was acquired by private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Silver Lake Partners and the venture capital firm Technology Crossover Ventures, in a $2.25 billion deal.The lead underwriters for the IPO are Morgan Stanley (MS) and JPMorgan (JPM). It plans to list on the NYSE under the ticker GDDY.It's been a slow start for technology initial public offerings this year, with just three on the books.The first was data storage and file-sharing service provider Box (BOX), which raised $175 million on Jan. 23 by offering 12.5 million shares at 14. Box closed Thursday at 17.06.Inovalon Holdings (INOV), a provider of data analytics for the health care industry, raised $600 million by offering 22.2 million shares at 27. Inovalon closed Thursday at 30.MaxPoint Interactive (MXPT), which provides a digital-ad automation platform, raised $75 million by pricing its 6.5 million shares at 11.50. MaxPoint ended trading Thursday at 10.01.Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter: @IBD_BDeagon.

The U.S. financial system is well positioned for round 2 of regulators' annual stress tests — meaning possible dividend hikes and stock buybacks — after all 31 of the largest banks cleared required capital levels in round 1 on Thursday. The banks' combined Tier 1 common capital ratio, which gauges high-quality capital as a percentage of risk-weighted assets, was 8.2%…
Some of the nation's big-bank executives could be feeling anxious this week about the release of the Federal Reserve's stress tests, scheduled for Thursday afternoon.

Perhaps most under the microscope is Citigroup (C), which failed last year's Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review, an annual exam performed each year since 2009 to evaluate how banks would endure another financial crisis. The tests were written into the Dodd-Frank Act the following year.

The New York-based lender's chief executive officer, Michael Corbat, and two other senior executives are expected to face increasing pressure to resign if Citigroup fails the stress test for a second consecutive year.

Corbat, John Gerspach, the bank's chief financial officer, and Brian Leach, Citigroup's head of financial risk and strategy, would face increasing calls from investors to resign and little sympathy from the Citigroup board of directors, according to a report from the Financial Times, citing two unnamed executives.

The first part of the test determines whether the company being tested has enough capital to endure nine quarters of difficult economic conditions. Part two of the test analyzes the companies' ability to pay dividends, repurchase stock or make acquisitions during economic difficulties.
Round 1 results are scheduled for release Thursday. Round 2 results are scheduled for March 11.
Despite the Citigroup scrutiny — it currently maintains an underwhelming IBD Composite Rating of 35 — analysts are optimistic about its 2015 stress test results.
"We believe (Citigroup) has made progress in improving its qualitative approach, while quantitatively it is in a strong capital position, in our view," wrote Barclays analysts.

Citigroup has also improved its standing since last year by scaling back its global consumer banking business, exiting 11 more markets. It cut back institutional clients and is about to sell its consumer lending unit, OneMain Financial Holdings.
"This may help reduce the complexity of the bank in the eyes of the regulators," Barclays said.

Skeptical regulators also have turned to Bank of America (BAC), which UBS analyst Brennan Hawken downgraded, cutting it to "neutral" from "buy." BofA noted in a Feb. 25 filing that it was discussing some internal models with federal regulators.
Since that filing was made public, Bank of America has traded below both its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.
Last year, the Fed made the Charlotte, N.C.-based lender resubmit its capital plans after a mistake was discovered in the original plans.

Goldman Sachs (GS) resubmitted its capital plan last year after failing to meet a minimum leverage ratio. As a result, the New York-based bank scaled back lines of business with low returns, reducing total assets as of June 30, 2014, by $56 billion to $860 billion.
The nation's largest bank, JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which is facing calls for its breakup, is also expected to pass the tests, and analysts aren't expecting anything dramatic from it.

"We do not expect the company to push the envelope beyond its recent and steady 50% payout of earnings in the form of dividends and share buybacks," Keefe, Bruyette & Woods (KBW) reported in a research note.

But JPMorgan is already implementing plans to slim down its operations and raise capital ratios. Last week, the company said that it will close 5% of its bank branches, impose surcharges on some large, uninsured deposits and shed $100 billion of such deposits.
Wells Fargo (WFC), one of the more conservatively managed big banks, is expected to pass. KBW analysts remain optimistic that Wells Fargo — along with Morgan Stanley (MS) — will pass the stress test.

Of the foreign banks to fall under the Fed's stress test, the U.S. units of Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB) and Spain's Banco Santander (SAN) are expected to fail as a result of weaknesses in their methods of predicting and measuring potential losses and risks, the Wall Street Journal reports.

If these banks fail the tests, their failure would mark the second consecutive year that large foreign banks stressed out on risk management grounds. Big foreign banks were drawn into the Fed's stress tests beginning last year.

Last week, the European Union's financial services commissioner, Jonathan Hill, said that U.S. capital requirements on foreign banks may be too onerous.Some of the nation's big-bank executives could be feeling anxious this week about the release of the Federal Reserve's stress tests, scheduled for Thursday afternoon.Perhaps most under the microscope is Citigroup (C), which failed last year's Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review, an annual exam performed each year since 2009 to evaluate how banks would endure another financial crisis. War On Terror: The head of U.S. Southern Command has warned lawmakers that IS is radicalizing converts and other Muslims in Latin America and could train and send them north via human traffickers.Gen. John Kelly issued his warning in a hearing Thursday before the Senate Armed Services Committee on defense appropriations for fiscal 2016.He's concerned that in addition to the Iranian terrorist puppet Hezbollah being active in Latin America, the Islamic State is promoting and recruiting for jihad against the United States in the region."Last year, IS adherents posted discussions on social media calling for the infiltration of the U.S. southern border," Kelly told lawmakers.He added that while no evidence of IS recruits using this entry route has been seen thus far, he was "deeply concerned that smuggling networks are a vulnerability that terrorists could seek to exploit."So why would IS, with so many of its trainees possessing Western passports, seek to use "coyotes" to transport their minions into the U.S.? Not every IS trainee has a passport, and tracking those who enter the U.S. to do us harm is less likely if they hide among the flood of "immigrants" the Obama administration is openly encouraging.The war in Syria has thus far attracted roughly 100 foreign fighters from the Caribbean who could easily make their way here, Kelly said. A hundred might not seem like a lot until we remember just 19 Muslims brought down the World Trade Center and attacked the Pentagon, killing 3,000, on Sept. 11, 2001.What makes Kelly's words resonate is confirmation from the FBI that IS is indeed already walking our streets. "We have active investigations of people in various stages of radicalizing in all 50 states," FBI Director James Comey told the National Association of Attorneys General recently.This isn't a New York or Washington phenomenon. This is in all 50 states and in ways that are very hard to see.We already see pockets of potential recruits in places such as "Little Mogadishu" in Minneapolis. Fox affiliate KMSP-TV in Minneapolis-St. Paul has reported the case of Abdirahmaan Muhumed.Before going to Syria to fight and die for IS, he worked at Delta Global Services, a wholly owned subsidiary of Delta Air Lines. His job was to clean aircraft, and he had a security clearance that gave him unfettered access to the tarmac and passenger jets.Abu-Salha, a 22-year-old Floridian, managed to return home for a time without U.S. authorities noticing, before returning to Syria and carrying out a massive suicide truck bombing. From the grave, he's recruiting other Americans to join the jihad in a widely distributed martyrdom video."Sunni extremists, while small in number, are actively involved in the radicalization of converts and other Muslims in the region and also provide financial and logistical support to designated terrorist organizations within and outside Latin America," Kelly told the panel.Kelly also expressed his concern that the Iranian-backed Lebanese terrorist group Hezbollah continues to exploit and expand its penetration of the region.Kelly noted that Iran has established 80 "cultural centers" in the area, ostensibly to promote Iran's image and Shi'a Islam.But as we have found, they can be recruiting centers for radicalized terrorists.Last year, as we noted then, Kelly used the term "existential threat" to describe the influx of people from countries that harbor terrorists, as well as violent transnational gangs such as Mara Salvatrucha, or MS-13, which specializes in extortion and human trafficking and has criminal franchises throughout the U.S.We concur. They're coming to kill us, and some are already here or on their way via our porous southern border.

It turns out that Hillary Clinton's Tweet last week on her still-downloading private email scandal was insufficient to quiet the PR sandstorm in Washington.So, Team Hillary has "announced" by old-fashioned leak to sympathetic reporters that at some point soon, possible even today, she will address the smoldering fire that threatens her coronation as president. This should be good, watching this rusty politician try to talk her way out of a clear violation of her own department's strict regulations.She bumbled her way through last year's book tour. The books didn't sell as well as expected. But what does Clinton care? She got her huge advance up front. Actual sales only determine if she gets even more money. No give-backs, especially if you're a Clinton dealing with money. That's why the couple never really was "dead-broke."But last summer's book-signings and all of her high-priced speaking engagements did not include a feeding frenzy of cloistered news media hungry for a new story to replace Barack Obama's ongoing bumble-fest. So, she'll probably duck the Washington media and try her excuse-a-thon in New York City.You would think after 25 years of public controversies, scandals, lies and denials that these two Clintons and their minions would learn the first lesson of politics: When you have bad news, get it out immediately -- all of it.Embarrassing dribs and drabs emerging every day -- she had her own private email server, her aides had off-line email accounts too, there are no released emails for times when she was photographed clearly sending emails -- are like those medical drips in the hospital if they were poison.Here's why the Clintons don't follow that rule: They're entitled. So, they get away with not.Think about all those Clinton scandals in the nineties -- Travelgate, Cattlegate, Hillarycare, BedroomGate and, of course, "that woman, Ms. Lewinsky."OK, don't think about all of them. They were mind-numbing. But there were a lot. That pair just denies any wrongdoing. And they and their minions talk each one to death until everyone is tired of trying to follow the complications they've thrown up. And then Hill and Bill declare it's old news.That's what Obama is trying to do with the IRS and Benghazi scandals. It worked on Fast & Furious, Solyndra and others.Stall to make the details old. Then, point out they're old. Do you remember Hillary denouncing the Bush White House for secret emails? Probably not. Blatant hypocrisy. But it works in that swamp.Bill tried that this weekend. He said hey, our foundation got money from foreign nations. You bet. We have before too. We believe in transparency. Just put it all out there and let everyone make up their minds. Uh-huh.The entire point of having your own email server is to control what gets out and what gets "lost." That's the opposite of transparency.But Hillary will likely try that this week: I released 55,000 emails. What more do you want?Well, for starters ALL four years of her emails. There could be 400,000 for all we know. Or two million. She controls every single one because Obama's crowd let her get away with it.The White House revealed Monday that Obama did exchange emails with Hillary but -- wait for it -- he didn't know it was illegal until he saw news reports. What's a poor president to do? Obama has transcripts of Angela Merkel's cellphone calls with hubby, but he just didn't notice the header on his secretary of State's emails. For four years.What's so dangerous for Hillary's unannounced candidacy is all the stalling, the prevarications and equivocations remind so many voters of why we were tired of them and so glad when the moving vans took their stuff to one of their mansions.And let's be honest: If Hillary's forced to drop out of a contest she hasn't entered, who's left for Democrats in 2016? Seriously. Martin O'Malley? Didn't he own the Dodgers? Or Chief Elizabeth Warren?Despite being a used car, Hillary remains very popular in polls -- among Democrats. The new Wall Street Journal / NBC News Poll finds that 44% of all voters and 73% of Democrats believe the 67-year-old Hillary Clinton will bring fresh, new ideas to the country. Didn't say it made sense, just that those are the poll numbers.But here's a real IED for the nascent Clinton campaign. She's become a negative meme in pop culture: Her artificial, calculated personality is now the subject of an opening skit for 'Saturday Night Live.' The people who remember her will nod and laugh. Those who don't will learn. (Scroll down to see video of that sketch from last weekend.)RELATED:Media tries to edit President Bush out of the Selma eventHow Netanyahu's Iran speech undermines Obama's deceitful deal
Naming Democrats who turned their back on Netanyahu's speechGiven Obama's vows, how could a U.S. ambassador be so vulnerable?

Scandal: The email plot thickens with news that Hillary Clinton's deputy chief of staff also used a private email account on the Clintons' server to conduct government business.Watchdog group Judicial Watch, which doesn't like being lied to or jerked around any more than the House Benghazi Select Committee does, has filed a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit against the Department of State seeking all communications, including emails, between Secretary of State Clinton and Huma Abedin with Nagla Mahmoud, wife of ousted Egyptian president Mohammed Morsi between Jan. 21, 2009, and Jan. 21, 2013.The lawsuit — which also seeks a thorough search of Clinton's newly discovered private email accounts connected to a home-based server to exclusively conduct government business — comes alongside the issue of subpoenas by the Benghazi Select Committee. Both have long been curious about the scarcity of produced emails with Clinton's name on them.Abedin, perhaps best remembered as the wife of disgraced former congressman Anthony Wiener, is a longtime Hillary friend and confidante. She served as Clinton's deputy chief of staff at the same time she worked as a consultant to the Clinton Foundation and a New York advisory firm tied to the Clintons, one that did business before the government.Foreign contributions to the Clinton Foundation — including from governments and sources which might not have our best interests at heart, during and after Clinton's tenure as secretary of state — are raising questions about conflicts of interest and possible quid pro quos.Abedin made $135,000 a year as Clinton's deputy, a period in which she is reported to have raked in as much as $355,000 from consulting contracts. Having a pipeline into the Clinton inner circle is invaluable to some. This reminds us of Johnny Chung's famous comparison of the Clinton White House to a subway turn style — you had to put money in to gain entry.Abedin also has some interesting family connections. Her father is said to be close with the Saudi government's Muslim World League, and her mother is said to be a member of the Muslim Sisterhood. World Trade Center bombing prosecutor Andrew McCarthy wrote in National Review: "The ties of Ms. Abedin's father, mother and brother to the Muslim Brotherhood are both specific and substantiated."The Muslim Brotherhood took power in Egypt with the Obama administration's approval after it had all but abandoned the government of Hosni Mubarak, a long-time ally and friend. It was while Abedin was advising Hillary that State dropped its long-standing policy of having no dealings with the Muslim Brotherhood.The Benghazi terrorist attack also happened on the Obama-Clinton watch. It would be interesting to see what Benghazi-related emails went through Clinton's private server. Were there some discussing the Benghazi video lie or planning Clinton's political cover?According to Gawker.com, among several email addresses linked to Abedin's name in records maintained by Lexis-Nexis is one for [email protected] Emails sent by Gawker to that to that email address went through without error.In the hidden emails might be information pertaining to just who benefited both politically and financially from their relationship with Clinton and Abedin, whose relationship seems to mirror the one between Obama aide Valerie Jarrett and the president.So who benefited, and how, from their connections with the two?What is the relationship between donors to the Clinton Foundation and U.S. foreign policy?And why won't Abedin disclose the complete list of her consulting contracts when she worked for Clinton?Slick Willie, move over. Slick Hillary is taking your place in history.

Nymex futures contracts for U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude on Friday priced oil for delivery in January 2016 about 19% above the current spot price. Economic Systems: The alarmists keep telling us their concern about global warming is all about man's stewardship of the environment. But we know that's not true. A United Nations official has now confirmed this.At a news conference last week in Brussels, Christiana Figueres, executive secretary of U.N.'s Framework Convention on Climate Change, admitted that the goal of environmental activists is not to save the world from ecological calamity but to destroy capitalism."This is the first time in the history of mankind that we are setting ourselves the task of intentionally, within a defined period of time, to change the economic development model that has been reigning for at least 150 years, since the Industrial Revolution," she said.Referring to a new international treaty environmentalists hope will be adopted at the Paris climate change conference later this year, she added: "This is probably the most difficult task we have ever given ourselves, which is to intentionally transform the economic development model for the first time in human history."The only economic model in the last 150 years that has ever worked at all is capitalism. The evidence is prima facie: From a feudal order that lasted a thousand years, produced zero growth and kept workdays long and lifespans short, the countries that have embraced free-market capitalism have enjoyed a system in which output has increased 70-fold, work days have been halved and lifespans doubled.Figueres is perhaps the perfect person for the job of transforming "the economic development model" because she's really never seen it work. "If you look at Ms. Figueres' Wikipedia page," notes Cato economist Dan Mitchell: Making the world look at their right hand while they choke developed economies with their left.

Inovalon (INOV) raised the estimated price range of its initial public offering, suggesting strong demand for the health care data analytics company. Inovalon now plans to sell 22.2 million shares at 24 to 26 a share, up from 21 to 24, and raise about $578 million. IPO research firm IPO Boutique said its channel checks indicate the demand for shares…

Shares of Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS), the big banks that suffered during the financial crisis, have cast a gradual, upward trajectory over the past year. Yet as they prepare to report Q4 results in the coming days, their recent quarterly gains have come largely from opposing sources: Morgan Stanley's from stability, Goldman Sachs' from volatility.
Despite strong performances the previous quarter, analysts seem to be keeping their expectations in check.

Analysts expect Goldman Sachs, which reports Friday, to earn $4.32 a share during the quarter, down 6% from the period last year. Revenue is expected to fall 13% from the year-ago period to $7.635 billion.

Those results would follow a third quarter in which the investment bank scorched past analysts' expectations for EPS growth and solidly beat revenue forecasts. Those gains — EPS up 59% to $4.57, revenue up 25% to $8.4 billion — were led by strong fixed-income trading resulting from a more volatile environment.

Shares sold off the day the company reported results on concerns that earnings were juiced by constrained compensation. Analysts have also worried whether Goldman Sachs' most-depended-upon growth driver — its fixed-income, commodities and currencies trading — was also the likeliest to suffer from U.S. capital requirements and other regulations.

Zacks last month said those regulations "are expected to weigh on its financials in the coming quarters," but added that the firm could gain "from its well-managed global franchise" and solid capital.

Barclays in a research note on Tuesday said a reduced compensation ratio could offset lower revenues. As mergers and acquisitions accelerate, Goldman Sachs also stands to rake in enough in fees to offset struggles in equity and debt underwriting, Barclays added. Analysts there also see a continuation in share buybacks, which boost EPS.
Susquehanna, however, expressed concern last month in a downgrade note that sinking oil prices could affect Goldman Sachs' loans segment this year.
Goldman shares gapped down 2.8% to 179.72 in the stock market today.
After risky mortgage bonds contributed to the housing-market bust and financial crisis, many banks backed off fixed-income trades due to the losses and the wave of regulations that resulted.

While Goldman Sachs is still holding out for a rebound in fixed-income, rival Morgan Stanley has moved away from such trades to focus more on its wealth-management business, an effort that has proved to be less risky but still profitable.
In Q3, Morgan Stanley's EPS jumped 30% to 65 cents and revenue rose 7.3% to $8.7 billion, beating expectations, boosted by wealth management.
When Morgan Stanley reports Q4 results Jan. 20, analysts expect EPS to fall by 2 cents year over year to 48 cents. Revenue is forecast to fall slightly to $8.077 billion.

JMP on Monday downgraded Morgan Stanley to market perform. Barclays in a research note Tuesday also cited concerns about "a more challenging trading outlook" and lower credit and commodities revenue, but expected wealth management to remain strong. Like Goldman Sachs, Barclays said M&A fees could make up for struggles in equity.

Morgan Stanley's Q4 will also reflect a $1.3 billion tax benefit resulting from the change in its wealth-management unit, Morgan Stanley Smith Barney, from a partnership to a corporation. Barclays said much of that would be offset by $1.2 billion spent to speed up the vesting of deferred cash-incentive compensation.
Still, S&P Capital IQ expects Morgan Stanley's wealth management to propel growth for the fourth quarter.

"Compared to other global banks, Morgan Stanley has a differentiated mix of businesses that are less exposed to market trends, especially in trading activity," they said in a research note quoted by International Business Times.

Swiss drug giant Novartis (NVS) said Monday that its oral multiple-sclerosis drug Gilenya failed a late-stage clinical trial for a particularly virulent form of the disease.

The company said Gilenya didn't do better than a placebo in patients with progressive primary multiple sclerosis (PPMS). Unlike the more common relapsing-remitting form of the disease, PPMS brings neurologic decline from the outset but with fewer visible symptoms, often leading to a late diagnosis. Novartis said about 10% of all MS patients suffer from PPMS.

Gilenya is already drawing some $2 billion a year treating relapsing MS, and expectations for the trial seemed to be low, as Novartis' stock was up a fraction after the news came out. RBC Capital Markets analyst Michael Yee wrote in a note Monday that he'd expected failure, and this has "minimal read-through" for an ongoing trial of Biogen Idec's (BIIB) blockbuster Tysabri in treating secondary progressive MS, which occurs later in life than the primary form.

"While the news is not a positive for Tysabri, we note that Tysabri has a different endpoint — Phase IIIb ASCEND will measure a composite endpoint ... in secondary-progressive multiple sclerosis," he wrote. "Furthermore, expectations are already super low for BIIB and this result supports that."
Biogen's stock was also up a fraction in midmorning trading, near 309.

Skin-deep success didn't satisfy Ophelia DeVore-Mitchell, one of America's first black models. She landed jobs — the first in 1938 — partly because of her fair complexion. But professional chances remained scarce for blacks, and that frustrated the career-minded Southerner. So she did something about it. Years before the 1960s' "Black Is Beautiful" movement, DeVore (1922-2014) became a pioneering modeling…

Shares of big banks gapped up Friday after the Labor Department reported a strong employment report, raising speculation that the Federal Reserve would soon begin raising short-term interest rates, thereby expanding banks' net interest margins.
The U.S. economy added 257,000 jobs last month, better than expected, with big upward revisions to November and December.

"This report helps the case of those at the Fed arguing for starting the normalization process sooner (June) rather than later," Jim O'Sullivan, chief U.S. economist of High Frequency Economics, said in a statement.
The banks' strong showing in the stock market today wiped away the declines they suffered after reporting mostly disappointing quarterly results last month.

Bank of America (BAC) stock rose 4.8% to 16.74, retaking its 200-day line and just shy of its 50-day average. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) advanced 3.4% while Citigroup (C) rose 2.8%, Wells Fargo (WFC) climbed 2.5%, Goldman Sachs (GS) 1.9% and Morgan Stanley (MS) 3.8%.
The banks' quarterly results were hit by greater market volatility and weaker trading revenue.

The employment figures released Friday were stronger than expected. The U.S. unemployment rate inched up to 5.7% from 5.6% in December, but that reflected the re-entry of more people into the labor force to look for jobs.

Hourly wages in January rose 0.5% from December, topping expectations and marking the strongest growth in six years.Shares of big banks gapped up Friday after the Labor Department reported a strong employment report, raising speculation that the Federal Reserve would soon begin raising short-term interest rates, thereby expanding banks' net interest margins.The U.S. economy added 257,000 jobs last month, better than expected, with big upward revisions to November and December."This report helps the case of those at the Fed arguing for starting the normalization process sooner (June) rather than later," Jim O'Sullivan, chief U.S. economist of High Frequency Economics, said in a statement.The banks' strong showing in the stock market today wiped away the declines they suffered after reporting mostly disappointing quarterly results last month.Bank of America (BAC) stock rose 4.8% to 16.74, retaking its 200-day line and just shy of its 50-day average. Morgan Stanley (MS) on Tuesday picked up where other big banks left off last week, turning in disappointing fourth-quarter results that the company attributed to "choppy market conditions, " sending shares lower.

The investment bank reported fourth-quarter adjusted earnings per share of 39 cents, down 22% from a year earlier and well short of analyst forecasts of 48 cents. Revenue fell 2% to $8.009 billion, just shy of consensus.

Fixed-income and commodities trading fell 13% from last year to $599 million. Morgan's fixed-income desk struggled due to low oil prices, the company's CFO told Reuters. Oil prices and other forms of market volatility have pushed many investors to the sidelines, hurting other big banks' Q4 results.
Morgan Stanley's compensation expenses, meanwhile, rose 27.5% to $5.1 billion. The bank has said it would defer fewer payments to cut down on future costs.

Shares fell 1.2% on the stock market today to 34.46 in afternoon trading. Morgan Stanley's stock hit a six-year high of 39.18 on Dec. 29, but have pulled back since then. Shares fell below their 50-day moving average last week and now are trying to find support above the 200-day line.

Rival Goldman Sachs (GS) on Friday reported a 29% drop in its fixed-income, currency and commodity trading. Analysts have also worried that Goldman has tried to boost the bottom line by lowering its compensation expenses, and that its fixed-income segment, which it depends on for a lot of its revenue, would suffer due to regulations.
Goldman shares were down 1.1% intraday.
Citigroup (C), Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) also reported lower FICC revenue for Q4. Shares of all three fell fractionally Tuesday afternoon.
While Goldman has remained to committed to fixed-income trading, Morgan Stanley has moved away from it since the financial crisis and put more weight behind its safer wealth-management business.

Morgan's Q4 wealth-management revenue grew to $3.8 billion, up from $3.7 billion last year and a quarterly record for the company, it said. But the segment's pre-tax profit margin in that division was 19%, unchanged from last year, down from the last two quarters. The margin was dragged down by compensation costs, the company said.

Morgan Stanley also benefited from a wave of mergers and acquisitions in Q4, with advisory revenue increasing 8% to $488 million. Revenue in equity rose around 7% to $1.6 billion, led by prime brokerage.Morgan Stanley (MS) on Tuesday picked up where other big banks left off last week, turning in disappointing fourth-quarter results that the company attributed to "choppy market conditions, " sending shares lower.The investment bank reported fourth-quarter adjusted earnings per share of 39 cents, down 22% from a year earlier and well short of analyst forecasts of 48 cents. Stock futures showed healthy gains early Tuesday as Europe's markets rebounded, oil prices recovered from lows, and economic news was fair to positive.

Dow futures traded 75.5 points above fair market value, down from 100.5 points an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures added to early gains and were up 29.1 points. S&P 500 futures moved up 11.7 points, even with hour-earlier levels.

The stock market today has its eye on Wednesday afternoon as the Federal Open Market Committee members head into their two-day powwow. Expectations are high for a policy shift when the group announces its decision on Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.

Consumer prices were flat in November, the Labor Department reported. That was down from a 0.2% gain in October and in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — equal to October's increase and meeting consensus projections.

Manufacturing activity in the New York region slowed at an improved rate in December, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey. It showed a -4.6 performance vs. a -10.7 showing in November. That was better than the -7 reading expected by economists.
At 10 a.m., the National Association of Home Builders releases its builder confidence index. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury international capital flow for October at 4 p.m.

Oil prices took a modest bounce in early trade, lifting West Texas Intermediate less than 1% and Brent crude more than 1%, although still trading below $37 and $39 a barrel, respectively. That, and the late-day recovery of U.S. markets on Monday, fed a rebound across European markets. The leading indexes bounced up from 10-week lows, sending the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 2% near midday.

In stocks, miners and steel markets were rebounding, with issues like Vale (VALE) up 5% and Arcelor-Mittal (MT) ahead more than 4%. On the Dow, diversified operator 3M (MMM) — the old Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co., tanked more than 4% after lowering its 2015 earnings guidance. Chevron (CVX) topped the index in premarket trade with a 0.8% gain.
3M also notched the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. F5 Networks (FFIV) took the second hardest hit, down a bit more than 2%.
Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) topped the list, all up better than 3%.

Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) bolted 27% higher after news reports detailed a letter from Kase Capital Management Managing Partner Whitney Tilson, declaring that he had covered his short position against the stock.

Tilson had weighed in against the company following allegations that some of its flooring contained unsafe levels of formaldehyde. Tilson concluded that management probably did not know about the problem, according to Bloomberg, which means "the company was sloppy and naive, but not evil," Tilson wrote. The stock ended Monday down 80% since news of the investigation broke in February.

Leading stocks stuck to moderate moves in premarket action. Hawaiian (HA) topped the IBD 50 list, up slightly more than 1% in premarket trade.
