On a full-year  basis, earnings growth for the S&P 500 is expected to remain solid. Double-digit gains are expected on both a median firm and total net income basis. On a median basis, growth for the current and next fiscal year is expected to be 13.1% and 12.9%, respectively. This growth rate has stayed relatively stable over the last several weeks. On a total earnings basis, the growth rates are more skewed towards this year, at 15.1% versus 10.4% next year. While the total growth rate is certainly predicted to slow, by no means is a 10.4% year-over-year growth rate tantamount to predicting a near-term recession. On the other hand, if the recent trend toward more downward revisions than upward revisions continues, those expected growth rates will deteriorate.

We would point to a couple of technical points which are affecting the expected growth rates. The rates are based on the forecasts of EPS, and then multiplied by current shares outstanding to get total earnings. Recently firms have been pumping enormous, and unprecedented, sums into share repurchase. In the first half, over $216 billion was spent by S&P 500 firms to buy back their own stock. The shrinks the number of shares outstanding and boosts the EPS growth rate. Add in dividends paid out and over 80% of earnings were returned to shareholders rather than reinvested by the companies. As mentioned above, stock options expensing counteracts this effect, and depresses the 2005 versus 2006 EPS comparisons.

Unlike the growth rates in our Earnings Scorecard, the numbers in the table below represent the expected growth for all of a sectors firms. Energy is expected to post rock-solid growth for both years on a median basis, with earnings climbing over 34% this year and over 20% next year. However, there is a real disparity for 2007 in the Energy sector, where it is at the front of the pack on a median firm basis but near the back on a total earnings basis. The key to that difference is that a handful of giant super majors (XOM, CVX, COP) account for over half of the sectors total expected earnings. Their earnings are currently expected to be flat to slightly down in 2007 relative to 2006, while the oil service and many of the E&P firms are expected to continue growing at a rapid clip. The Materials sector shows a similar disparity for 2007. Going the other way, total earnings growth in 2006 is much higher than median growth from the Financial Services sector. This is largely due to the very large insurance losses in 2005 due to the storms. The Financial Services sector has more firms in it, and accounts for more of the S&Ps total earnings than the Energy and Health Care sectors combined.

When making investment decisions, growth should always be looked at in conjunction with how much you are paying for a stock. Thus, it makes sense to look at the total earnings expected for a sector, relative to that sectors total market capitalization. This is basically a variation on looking at the P/E.

The chart below shows the share of total earnings for 2005, 2006 and 2007, as well as the share of total market capitalization for each sector (the final bar shown). Since the S&P 500 is a market cap weighted index, this is the same as its index weight. On the chart below, the difference between the sizes of the first three bars shows if a sector is gaining or losing earnings share. The difference between the final bar and the first three bars shows if the sector is selling for an above or below market P/E. If the final bar is smaller than the other bars, the sector is selling for a below market P/E. However, as opposed to just showing the sector P/Es, it also shows the relative importance of the sectors to the overall index.

Clearly the Financials are the biggest influence on the market, with a weight of 21.7%, it has more influence than the Consumer Staples, Utilities, Materials and Telecom sectors combined. However, that sector is also relatively cheap on an earnings basis, and thus serves to hold the overall P/E of the index down. In other words, Financials deserve to be the biggest influence on the market, since they contribute 26.3% of the total expected earnings for 2006, or more than the total earnings of the Tech, Industrial and Utility sectors combined.

Energy looks to be under represented in its influence on the market since it is expected to provide 14.5% of total earnings for 2006, but represents only 8.9% of the total market capitalization of the index. While its earnings share is currently expected to decline to 14.0% in 2007, even on this basis it is still much cheaper than the overall market. Clearly at 8.9%, Energy is far from being in a bubble phase. Frankly, I find the notion of an Energy stock bubble to be absurd. Even though the NASDAQ is at only 40% of its early 2000 peak, a much stronger case could be made for Tech being bubbly than for Energy.

Looked at another way, Energy will provide 20.5% of the total incremental earnings in the S&P 500 this year, while that is down from the 43.8% of the total it provided last year, it is still far above its weight in the index. In more conventional terms, the Energy sector is trading for 9.7x 2006, and 9.0x 2007 earnings. Tech on the other hand is trading for 22.4x 2006 and 19.1x 2007 earnings. The S&P is trading for 15.7x and 14.2x, respectively. The P/E for 2007 equates to an earnings yield of 7.0% which is very attractive relative to a 10 year t-note yield of 4.8%. The second chart below shows the sector P/Es ranked from lowest to highest based on estimated 2007 P/E ratios.
Matt Thurmond contributed significantly to this report.

The third quarter earnings season is beginning, first with a trickle, but it will soon turn into a flood. For the 25 companies reported thus far, 22 have reported above expectations. Negative revisions for both this year and next however, put a shade of grey on these preliminary results. Our revisions ratio, which is calculated by dividing positive analysts revisions by negatives, is below one. This means that of the 1,250 fiscal 2006 analysts revisions compiled over the last four weeks, 657 were negative. This gives an 2006 EPS revisions ratio of 0.90. While the rise in the revisions ratio is good news, eight of the ten sectors had negative revisions ratios for the year, with only the financials showing significant strength. The ratio for fiscal 2007 is even worse, at 0.80. On the bright side, the 2006 revisions ratio has been climbing for the past two weeks, after having bottomed out at 0.71. The unfavorable 2007 ratio however, has held solid at its current value. If both ratios remain at their current levels as third quarter reporting picks up, it could be the canary in the coal mine. The high expected earnings growth rates indicate that the economy will remain healthy, despite disturbing indicators such as an inverted yield curve and a plunging housing market. So far the negative revisions ratios have yet to put a meaningful dent in the earnings expectations. This is mostly due to the low absolute numbers of revisions during this slow season.

The S&P 500 is set to post double-digit median growth for both this year and next. This is true regardless if measured on a total net income basis or a median firm basis. Current downward revisions would have to lower EPS values substantially and across multiple industries before our overall earnings outlook turns bearish.

The total number of 2006 earnings revisions over the past month, as mentioned above, was 1,250. This is down from the 3,243 at the peak of the second quarter reporting season, a level we will most likely ramp up to over the next month. At current levels, it is clear that there is less new data for analyst to work with and thus, fewer EPS revisions.

Over the last four weeks, there were 593 upward revisions and 657 downward. This makes for a total revisions ratio of 0.90, slightly up from last weeks 0.82. The downtrend has now been reversed and the full-year 2006 revisions ratio is headed upward. Strong third quarter earnings could once again loft it well above 1, which is where it sat during most of the second quarter reporting season. The ratio was 1.35 five weeks ago.

The revisions ratio should be looked at in combination with two other metrics. The first is the average four-week change in EPS estimates. The average 2006 estimate change during the past month remains slightly negative, at -0.29%. This estimate change pretty much mirrors the revisions ratio in being a bearish signal, though not quite as extreme.

The other useful ratio we utilize compares the number of firms with EPS increases versus decreases. This ratio has now been negative for two weeks and currently sits at 0.96. The big story here is energy. 21 companies in the sector saw analyst decreasing full-year EPS numbers, compared to only four companies with increasing estimates. As can be clearly seen with oils recent swoon from nearly $80 a barrel to just under $60, the fossil fuel boom has come down from its peak. Whether this is temporary or not is someone elses argument to take on. It has however, had a drastic effect on the outlook for companies in the oil patch.

Looking more closely at individual revisions ratios, Energy saw a sharp decline, as would be expected. The ratio was a dismal 0.30. Two weeks ago, energys ratio was 1.15. Negative revisions were across the board here, from the super majors (Exxon Mobil (XOM  -  Free Report), Chevron (CVX  -  Free Report) and ConocoPhilips (COP  -  Free Report)) to the independents (Devon Energy (DVN  -  Free Report) to the drillers and refiners (Rowan (COP  -  Free Report) and Valero (COP  -  Free Report)).. On the upside of the revisions story, the Financials sector once again saw a sharp week-to-week ratio increase, from 1.10 to 1.60. Behemoth investment banks like Lehman (LEH), Morgan Stanley (MS  -  Free Report), and Goldman Sachs (GS  -  Free Report) each had double-digit positive revisions following strong third quarter reports.

The bright point this week regarding 2007 revisions is clearly Utilities. The sectors ratio is an impression 1.89. The longer fossil fuel prices stay low, the more likely utilities are to negotiate favorable supply contracts and secure higher forward margins. It is noteworthy that the rest of the strength for next year was in the relatively defensive Telecom and Consumer Staples sectors, wile along with Energy, the economically sensitive Materials and Consumer Discretionary sectors were weak.

While earnings revisions and average EPS estimate changes have been negative indicators recently, the small amount of third-quarter reports coming in have been positive. We define a third quarter earnings report as having an end date in either August, September or October.

25 companies have reported third-quarter earnings and 22 of them have had positive surprises. The median surprise is 6.1% and the median company growth rate is 15.1%. Note that these numbers are not very significant in the grand scheme since they only represent 5% of the S&P 500. Still, positive surprises are positive surprises, and bulls should be crossing their fingers for more of the same. All in all, the pattern looks remarkably similar to three months ago, when earnings growth for the quarter was expected to drop to single-digits, and the early reports where overwhelmingly positive. The first quarter also followed a similar pattern. If this pattern of positive surprises keeps up, the revisions ratio will increase, and previous growth forecasts will prove accurate, or possibly even conservative. This would be terrific news for the economy.

Clearly at 8.9%, Energy is far from being in a bubble phase. Frankly, I find the notion of an Energy stock bubble to be absurd. Even though the NASDAQ is at only 40% of its early 2000 peak, a much stronger case could be made for Tech being bubbly than for Energy.

Looked at another way, Energy will provide 20.5% of the total incremental earnings in the S&P 500 this year, while that is down from the 43.8% of the total it provided last year, it is still far above its weight in the index. In more conventional terms, the Energy sector is trading for 9.5x 2006, and 9.0x 2007 earnings. Tech on the other hand is trading for 21.9x 2006 and 18.7x 2007 earnings. The S&P is trading for 15.6x and 14.1x, respectively. The P/E for 2007 equates to an earnings yield of 7.1% which is very attractive relative to a 10 year t-note yield of 4.7%. The second chart below shows the sector P/Es ranked from lowest to highest based on estimated 2007 P/E ratios.
Matt Thurmond contributed significantly to this report.

Ever since the economic recovery began, the leading internal cause of concern among market watchers has been the inevitable rise of interest rates.  The drumbeat to the June Fed meeting, where a vast consensus believe rates will begin to rise, has taken a larger toll on some industries than others.  The brokerage houses industry is one of those spaces where Fed policy becomes nerve-wracking.  Nevertheless, the space still enjoys a Zacks Industry rank of 2.55, according to Nick Raichs  Weekly Earnings and Sector Update,  which places it 35th out of more than 200 industries.  All of the analysts are paying close attention to rates right now, but many of them also feel the hype has been overblown and the industry continues to exhibit positive trends.

May experienced a bit of a rebound for brokerage stocks after a rather disappointing April.  Brokerage stocks gained about +2% during the month, almost doubling an approximate +1% gain for the S&P 500.  Over the next couple of weeks, a number of companies will be reporting second quarter numbers, including Lehman Brothers, Bear Stearns, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs.  Analysts expect these companies to at least meet and probably beat the earnings expectations set by Wall Street.  However, they caution that these second quarter results will not be as robust as the first quarters.  In addition to the interest rate paranoia and the typical summer swoon, the numbers must contend with an unusually successful first quarter where, by some accounts, brokers saw a more than +60% jump in earnings per share from the prior year.

The good news for the industry moving forward is analysts believe the short-term sluggishness is temporary in nature, and the longer-term outlook for this space remains positive.  Our economy, as well as many others around the globe are improving, and rising interest rates do not necessarily mean the end of the recovery.  There are, of course, external factors that must be considered, such as the Iraq situation and rising oil prices, which usually do not inspire much desire for investing.  But many are convinced that the strong fundamentals will be enough to boost this space after the summer burns itself out, and it wouldnt hurt if some of the countrys geopolitical strife eased as well.

With so many factors that could potentially impact the brokerage houses industry, investors would be wise to ask for some help when entering the space.  The economy is moving in the right direction, and these companies are in a good position to capitalize on that strength, but there are obstacles that must be considered.  Analysts are in a unique position to maximize your investing dollar in this industry, while helping you to broker a better deal for higher profits.  What Do the All Stars Recommend?

Perhaps one of the few saving graces of an economic downturn is that companies are forced to become more efficient, and thereby are put into prime positions to prosper once conditions improve.  During our most recent foray into the doldrums, equities were not high on the priority list for many people, nor were many other services offered by brokerage houses for that matter.  But now with the economy back on course, and the efficiency programs in place, the brokerage firms industry enjoys a Zacks Industry Rank of 2.50, according to Nick Raich's  "Weekly Earnings and Sector Update,"  placing it 16th out of more than 200 industries.

"The companies are doing pretty well," said 5-Star analyst Jeffery Harte, senior research analyst at Sandler O'Neill & Partners, L.P.  "There's an evolving recovery at the corporate activity level, and companies are taking out operating expenses and getting more efficient."

As many companies and industries had to do during the downturn, brokerage firms saw the writing on the wall and decided to pull back on expenses.  The economy was on the ropes and the market was down for the count, which left consumers, and former investors, grappling to stay on their feet.  But while there were signs that the economy was slowly but surely recovering in the second half of 2003, the +8.2% GDP surge in the third quarter seemed to crystallize the idea that better days were ahead.  A glimpse at the last two quarters for this industry's big boys shows their confidence that the tide has turned.

"We've essentially just moved through the door of this recovery," said Harte, who says that it should have legs moving into the future.  He expects a strong 2004 and a decent 2005.  At this time of rising revenues, Harte is looking for companies with a low valuation and a position to exceed profit margins.

As Harte sees it, the main risk to this recovery is if the recovery falters.  There are currently numerous theories as to the sustainability of the rise, with a special interest now on the lack of job growth.  The tempo of this debate will only become louder as the presidential election heats up.  But most of the companies in the space appear to be rather optimistic for the future.  One of the best ways to guard against making unwise decisions - whether they be company specific or concerning the economy in general - is to consult the Wall Street analysts that make it their business to know the present and future conditions of your profit potential. The stock market's robust rise over the past several months has helped many industries make up some ground, but perhaps no more so than for investment brokerages.  Except for fixed income and mortgages businesses, these companies had a very hard time operating in a difficult market that was shedding investors at a rapid pace.  But much like the prodigal son, these investors are slowly but surely creeping back into the marketplace as anticipation of a sustainable recovery becomes more tangible.  Currently, the investment brokerages industry has a Zacks Industry Rank of 2.37, or 11th out of more than 200 industries, according to Nick Raich's  "Weekly Earnings and Sector Update."   The pieces seem to be in place for this industry to make some strides coming up, which goes for investors as well if they make the right moves.

"I think the industry is clearly turning around," said Richard Bove, managing director at Hoefer & Arnett, "and coming at a time with an extraordinarily low cost base."  That low cost base came primarily because these businesses had cut employees to help cope with the challenging market.  When you combine the renewed interest in the stock market with this low cost base, a spike upward in earnings estimates isn't too far behind.

That improved stock market cannot be understated.  Bove has been seeing some encouraging trends coming out of businesses that had previously been stunted from the environment, including investment management and retail brokerage.  Both of these businesses tend to feed off of a thriving stock market, as investors become more willing to let their money leave the bank.  Furthermore, there is also evidence that merger & acquisitions are beginning to pick up some steam.

However, in spite of the market's meteoric rise, there remains plenty of apprehension surrounding the industry.  Because the fixed income and mortgages segments held up rather well during the downturn, many believe that these spaces are now set up for a collapse as conditions improve.  But Bove disagrees.  He does expect a decline in those two fields, but nothing like a collapse.  Instead the fixed income and mortgages spaces should experience a more moderate, gradual decline.  In fact, that gradual decline is one of two aspects that Bove believes investors should take into consideration before entering the industry.  The other aspect is an increase in investment banking.
